; PREFACE

[Page-ix+ 39]
<H>PREFACE
<P>It is with a sense of diffidence that I am placing my
<>{%Indian Epigraphical Glossary%} in the hands of the students of
<>Indian epigraphy and lexicography. Originally it was my
<>intention to insert it in my {%Indian Epigraphy%} as an Appendix
<>to the Chapter on “Technical Expressions”. But, as my collec-
<>tion of the material progressed, I felt that it would be rather too
<>big for an Appendix. At the same time, I also realised that
<>it was not possible for a single man to collect all interesting
<>words and expressions from all published epigraphic records
<>in the various Indian languages in a short period of time.
<>But I was eager to do as much as it was possible for me in the
<>limited time I could devote to the work, and the result of the
<>attempt is this nucleus now placed in the hands of readers
<>interested in inscriptions. I am fully conscious of my own
<>limitations as well as of the possibility of errors of judgment
<>and of omission and commission creeping into the work.
<>There may be cases wherein I have been misled by earlier
<>writers, or accepted their doubtful suggestion as correct, or
<>misunderstood them. It is hoped, nevertheless, that the work
<>may be of some help to the students and to the future compiler
<>of a fuller Glossary of this type.
<P>The majority of words collected in this Glossary occur
<>in inscriptions in Sanskrit or in the Sanskritic and Dravidian
<>languages. My aim has primarily been to collect Sanskrit
<>words, and generally the Prakrit and {%tadbhava%} words have been
<>given in their Sanskrit forms, although some Dravidian or
<>Deśī words have also been included. Sanskrit words used
<>in Tamil with {%ṉ%} and {%m%} suffixed to them have been ususally
<>quoted without the suffixes; e. g., {%varāhaṉ%} and {%liṅgam%} have
<>been recognised as {%varāha%} and {%liṅga.%} Likewise, the suffix {%mu%}
<>in Sanskrit words used in Telugu has been generally omitted.
<>Feminine words ending in {%a%} and {%i,%} as used in the Dravidian
<>languages, have often been quoted with the vowels lengthened.
<>In Tamil words, intervocalic {%k, c, ṭ, t%} and {%p%} have sometimes
<>been represented by {%g, j, d, d%} and {%b%} respectivly. It is felt that,
<>while weeding out words without special significance from my
<>original collection, some were left over. There are also some
<>words collected from sources other than epigraphic records.
[Page-x+ 40]
<P>There are three Appendices at the end of the volume,
<>the first of which contains passages indicating the privileges,
<>etc., enjoyed by the donees of rent-free (or partially rent-free)
<>holdings. Appendix II contains a list of various levies that
<>are known from inscriptions in Dravidian languages, especially
<>Tamil. These Appendices are expected to throw light on
<>the rights and obligations of the tenants of ancient and
<>medieval India and on the meanings of some of the Sanskritic
<>words in the Glossary. The third Appendix contains words
<>of numismatic interest.
<P>The words have been mostly taken from my {%Indian Epi-%}
<>{%graphy%} and the Indices and Glossaries appended to various
<>epigraphical publications, and references to these have been
<>indicated in short. Full references with the indication of
<>pages, etc., have, however, been provided in certain cases
<>especially when the words occur in the epigraphic texts, but
<>are not noticed in the Indices, etc., pertaining to the Volumes
<>in question. A key to the shortened references is supplied
<>below separately. The references cited under a word are of
<>course not exhaustive in all cases. The Index has been
<>prepared by Sri Dipak Ranjan Das, Lecturer, Sanskrit College,
<>Calcutta, to whom my sincere thanks are due.
<P>While it is a matter of satisfaction that I have probably
<>succeeded in explaining a number of expressions, which were
<>previously unintelligible or misunderstood, and in grouping
<>together connected items by cross-references in numerous cases,
<>I am sorry to feel that it is difficult to compile a work of this
<>type without errors, and even more difficult is to print it with-
<>out technical blemishes including misprints. I therefore crave
<>the indulgence of sympathic readers for all kind of mistakes
<>that might have crept into the book and request them to be
<>so kind as to draw my attention to the defects they may notice
<>in it.
{%Pramāṇa-siddhānta-viruddham = atra%}
<>{%yat = kiñcid = uktaṃ mati-māndya-doṣāt |%}
<>{%mātsaryam = utsārya tad = ārya-cittāḥ%}
<>{%prasādam = ādhāya viśodhayantu ||%}
<HS>D. C. SIRCAR
<>645, New Alipore, Culcutta-53,
<>November 15, 1965.
;

<H>SPECIAL ABBREVIATIONS TO THE SECTIONS OF
<>{%INDIAN EPIGRAPHY%} AND TO OTHER GLOSSARIES
<>AND INDICES
<HI>ASLV = {%Administration and Social Life under Vijayanagara%} by
<>T. V. Mahalingam, pp. 418-76 (Index).
<HI>BL = Bhandarkar's List = {%A List of Inscriptions of Northern%}
<>{%India in Brāhmī and its Derivative Scripts from about%}
<>200 {%A. C.%} by D. R. Bhandarkar, Appendix to the
<>{%Epigraphia Indica,%} Volumes XIX-XXIII, pp. 297-
<>365 (Index).
<HI>Chamba = {%Antiquities of Chamba State,%} Part II, by B. Ch.
<>Chhabra, pp. 180-93 (Index).
<HI>CII = {%Corpus Inscriptionum Indicarum;%} e. g., CII 2-1 =
<>{%Corpus Inscriptionum Indicarum,%} Volume II, Part i,
<>pp. 181-85 (Index); CII 3, 4 = Indices to {%Corpus%}
<>{%Inscriptionum Indicarum,%} Volumes III and IV.
<HI>CITD = {%Corpus of Inscriptions in the Telingana Districts of%}
<>{%H. E. H. the Nizam's Dominions%} by P. Sreenivasachar,
<>Part II, pp. 201-12 (Glossary).
<HI>EI = {%Epigraphia Indica;%} e. g., EI 1 = {%Epigraphia Indica,%}
<>Volume I, pp. 461-78 (Index); EI 2, 6, 12 =
<>Indices to {%Epigraphia Indica,%} Volumes II, VI and XII.
<HI>HA = {%Holy Abu%} by Muni Jayantavijaya, translated by
<>U. P. Shah, pp. 198-204 (Glossary).
<HI>HD = {%History of Dharmaśāstra%} by P. V. Kane, Volume
<>III, pp. 975-1007 (Glossary styled ‘Appendix--
<>Note 191’).
<HI>HRS = {%Hindu Revenue System%} by U. N. Ghoshal, pp. 289 ff.
<>(Glossary and Index).
<HI>IA = {%Indian Antiquary;%} e. g., IA 5 = {%Indian Antiquary,%} Volume
<>V, pp. 363-71 (Index); IA 8, 15, 20 = Indices to
<>{%Indian Antiquary,%} Volumes VIII, XV and XX.
<HI>IE = {%Indian Epigraphy,%} by D. C. Sircar; e. g., IE 8-2 =
<>{%Indian Epigraphy,%} Chapter VIII, Section ii; IE
<>7-1-2 = {%Indian Epigraphy,%} Chapter VII, Section i,
<>Subsection 2.
[Page-xii+ 20]
<HI>LL = Lüders' List = {%A List of Brāhmī Inscriptions%} by H.
<>Lüders, Appendix to the {%Epigraphia Indica,%} Volume
<>X, pp. 213-24 (Index).
<HI>LP = {%Lekhapaddhati,%} G. O. S., No. XXI, pp. 97-128
<>(Glossary).
<HI>ML = Majumdar's List = {%A List of Kharoṣṭhī Inscriptions%}
<>by N. G. Majumdar in the {%Journal of the Asiatic%}
<>{%Society of Bengal,%} New Series, Vol. XX, 1924, pp.
<>35-39 (Index).
<HI>PJS = {%Prācīna Jaina-lekha Sandoha%} by Muni Jayantavijaya,
<>p. 61 (Glossary).
<HI>SII = {%South Indian Inscriptions;%} e. g., SII 1 = {%South Indian%}
<>{%Inscriptions,%} Volume I, pp. 171-83 (Index); SII
<>11-2 = {%South Indian Inscriptions,%} Volume XI, Part ii,
<>pp. 267-72 (Index); SII 1, 3, 12-2 = Indices to
<>{%South Indian Inscriptions,%} Volumes I, III, and XII,
<>Part ii.
<HI>SITI = {%South Indian Temple Inscriptions%} by T. N. Subra-
<>manian, Volume III, Part ii, pp. i-civ (Glossary
<>in an ‘Annexure’ at the end of the volume).

; SYSTEM OF TRANSLITERATION
;
<H>SYSTEM OF TRANSLITERATION
<P>{#A#} = ā, {#I#} = ī, {#U#} = ū,
<>{#f#} = ṛ, {#F#} = ṝ, {#x#} = ḷ,
<>{#F#} = ḹ, {#e#} (long) = e, {#e#} (short) = {%ĕ,%}
<>{#o#} (long) = o, {#o#} (short) = ŏ, {#Na#} = ṅ,
<>{#ca#} = c, {#Ya#} = ñ, {#wa#} = ṭ,
<>{#qa#} = ḍ, {#Ra#} = ṇ, {#Sa#} = ś,
<>{#za#} = ṣ, {#q2a#} = ḏ {#La#} = ḻ,
<>Dravidian palatal alveolar {%n%} = ṉ,
<>Dravidian palatal alveolar {%r%} = ṟ,
<>Dravidian cerebral voiced fricative (i. e. voiced {%ṣ%}) = l13,
<>anusvāra = ṃ, visarga = ḥ,
<>upadhmānīya = ḣ, jihvāmūlīya = h
[Page-xvi+ 1]
<>NIL
;
; ENTRIES
;
[Page-001+ 37]
<H>A

<L>1<pc>001<k1>AbADa<k2>AbADa
{%ābādha%}¦ (CII 1), illness.
<LEND>

<L>2<pc>001<k1>AbADA<k2>AbADA
{%ābādhā%}¦ (EI 15), same as {%bādhā%} or {%vādhā;%} obstacle.
<LEND>

<L>3<pc>001<k1>abAtamAla<k2>abAtamAla, abAtamAlA
{%abātamāla, abātamālā,%}¦ Prakrit; meaning doubtful (cf. {%Ep.%}
<div n="lb">{%Ind.,%} Vol. XV, p. 272; {%ZDMG,%} Vol. XL, pp. 345-46); explained
<div n="lb">as a kind of sculptured slab (LL).
<LEND>

<L>4<pc>001<k1>abdapa<k2>abdapa
{%abdapa%}¦ (IA 16), the entrance of the sun into the
<div n="lb">Aries ({%Meṣa%}).
<LEND>

<L>5<pc>001<k1>abdapUjA<k2>abda-pUjA
{%abda-pūjā%}¦ (EI 32), a rite.
<LEND>

<L>6<pc>001<k1>AbdArKAnah<k2>AbdArKAnah
{%ābdārkhānah%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 31), Persian; ‘water-house’;
<div n="lb">cf. {%Pānīy-āgārika.%}
<LEND>

<L>7<pc>001<k1>abDi<k2>abDi
{%abdhi%}¦ (IE 7-1-2), ‘four’; see {%sāgara.%}
<LEND>

<L>8<pc>001<k1>AbdikaSrAdDa<k2>Abdika-SrAdDa
{%ābdika-śrāddha%}¦ (CII 4), an annual rite in honour of a
<div n="lb">dead person.
<LEND>

<L>9<pc>001<k1>ABAvya<k2>ABAvya
{%ābhāvya%}¦ (EI 11, 16), income or proceeds; cf. {%rāja-rāja-%}
<div n="lb">{%puruṣ ādibhiḥ svaṃ svam = ābhāvyaṃ parihartavyam;%} see also {%rāja-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhāvya,%} etc. Cf. ‘the income ({%ābhāvya%}) derived from the
<div n="lb">loads on bullocks going on their way or coming to Nāḍlāi’
<div n="lb">({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XI, p. 36).
<LEND>

<L>10<pc>001<k1>aBaya<k2>aBaya
{%abhaya%}¦ (EI 24), pose of hand ({%mudrā%}); see {%abhaya-mudrā.%}
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), place of security to persons in distress; called
<div n="lb">{%añjinānpugal-idam%} in Tamil. Cf. {%abhaya-śāsana.%}
<LEND>

<L>11<pc>001<k1>aBayahasta<k2>aBaya-hasta
{%abhaya-hasta%}¦ (SII 2), pose of hand known as {%abhaya-mudrā%}
<div n="lb">(q. v.).
<LEND>

<L>12<pc>001<k1>aBayamudrA<k2>aBaya-mudrA
{%abhaya-mudrā%}¦ (HA), pose of hand offering protection, in
<div n="lb">which the palm of the right hand, facing the devotee, is held
<div n="lb">with fingers upwards. Cf. {%abhaya-hasta.%}
<LEND>

<L>13<pc>001<k1>aBayaSAsana<k2>aBaya-SAsana
{%abhaya-śāsana%}¦ (EI 12, 27; SITI), ‘grant of shelter’,
<div n="lb">‘charter of security’; a deed offering protection; a grant
<div n="lb">recording the provision of shelter.
<LEND>

<L>14<pc>001<k1>ABigAmikaguRa<k2>ABigAmika-guRa
{%ābhigāmika-guṇa%}¦ (CII 3, 4), certain attractive qualities.
<LEND>

<L>15<pc>001<k1>aBiGAta<k2>aBiGAta
{%abhighāta%}¦ (LP), an injury.
<LEND>

<L>16<pc>001<k1>aBihAra<k2>aBihAra
{%abhihāra%}¦ (CII 1), a reward.
<LEND>

<L>17<pc>001<k1>aBijYAna<k2>aBijYAna
{%abhijñāna%}¦ (LP), a token by which the identity of a
<div n="lb">person is recognised.
<LEND>

<L>18<pc>001<k1>aBikAra<k2>aBikAra
{%abhikāra,%}¦ cf. {%kṛt-ābhikāra%} (CII 1), probably, one who has
<div n="lb">committed an offence under the instigation of another.
<LEND>
[Page-002+ 40]

<L>19<pc>002<k1>aBileKitaka<k2>aBileKitaka
{%abhilekhitaka%}¦ (IE 8-8), probably, a written complaint.
<LEND>

<L>20<pc>002<k1>aBinava<k2>aBinava
{%abhinava%}¦ (EI 5; IA 18), name of a tax; cf. {%abhinava-mārga-%}
<div n="lb">{%ṇaka-prabhṛti-sarv-ādāyair = upetaḥ,%} epithet of the gift village. It
<div n="lb">may also mean ‘new’ and the reference may be to the new
<div n="lb">{%mārgaṇaka%} tax. See {%abhinava-mārgaṇaka.%}
<LEND>

<L>21<pc>002<k1>aBinavamArgaRaka<k2>aBinava-mArgaRaka
{%abhinava-mārgaṇaka%}¦ ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. III, p. 264,
<div n="lb">note 1), name of a tax. See {%mārgaṇaka, mārg-ādāya,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>22<pc>002<k1>aBipreta<k2>aBipreta
{%abhipreta%}¦ (CII 1), intention.
<LEND>

<L>23<pc>002<k1>ABIra<k2>ABIra
{%Ābhīra%}¦ (IE 8-3), member of the cowherd community.
<LEND>

<L>24<pc>002<k1>aBirakta<k2>aBirakta
{%abhirakta%}¦ (CII 1), beloved one.
<LEND>

<L>25<pc>002<k1>aBizeka<k2>aBizeka
{%abhiṣeka%}¦ (EI 4), coronation; cf. {%abhiṣeka-kkāṇi, abhiṣeka-%}
<div n="lb">{%kkāṇikkai%} (SITI), Sanskrit-Tamil; presents offered to the
<div n="lb">king at the time of his coronation.
<LEND>

<L>26<pc>002<k1>aBizekamaRdapa<k2>aBizeka-maRdapa
{%abhiṣeka-maṇdapa%}¦ (SITI), a hall where ceremonial baths
<div n="lb">are taken; the coronation hall; also called {%tiru-mañjana-%}
<div n="lb">{%śālai%} and {%kuḻikkum-iḍam%} in Tamil.
<LEND>

<L>27<pc>002<k1>aBizekanAman<k2>aBizeka-nAman
{%abhiṣeka-nāman%}¦ (SITI), the name or title assumed by a
<div n="lb">king at the time of his coronation.
<LEND>

<L>28<pc>002<k1>aBizikta<k2>aBizikta
{%abhiṣikta%}¦ (CII 1), cf. {%dvādaśa-varṣ-ābhiṣikta,%} ‘when one has
<div n="lb">been anointed twelve years’, ‘when twelve years have elapsed
<div n="lb">from one's coronation’. See {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXIII, pp. 333 ff.
<LEND>

<L>29<pc>002<k1>aBIzwadevatA<k2>aBIzwa-devatA
{%abhīṣṭa-devatā%}¦ (IA 18), same as {%iṣṭa-devatā;%} the favourite
<div n="lb">deity; the tutelary deity.
<LEND>

<L>30<pc>002<k1>aBisTAna<k2>aBisTAna
{%abhisthāna,%}¦ correctly {%abhiṣṭhāna;%} used in the sense of
<div n="lb">{%adhiṣṭhāna,%} ‘the residence’, ‘a city’, or ‘the headquarters’.
<div n="lb">Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXIV, p. 219.
<LEND>

<L>31<pc>002<k1>aBitvaramARa<k2>aBitvaramARa, aBitvaramARaka
{%Abhitvaramāṇa, Abhitvaramāṇaka%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 31; HD),
<div n="lb">the letter-carrier or a special kind of messenger. Cf
<div n="lb">{%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XVII, p. 321 ({%dūta-praiṣaṇika-gamāgamik-ābhi-%}
<div n="lb">{%tvaramāṇaka%}); Vogel, {%Ant. Ch. St.,%} pp. 125-26.
<LEND>

<L>32<pc>002<k1>ABoga<k2>ABoga
{%ābhoga%}¦ (IE 8-4), a territorial unit; similar to {%bhoga;%}
<div n="lb">cf. {%Gorajj-ābhoga.%}
<LEND>

<L>33<pc>002<k1>aBra<k2>aBra

<div n="lb">426. But cf. also {%Ābhyantarika, Abhyantar-opasthāyaka.%}

<L>36<pc>002<k1>aByantaraBARqArADikArin<k2>aByantara-BARqAr-ADikArin

<L>37<pc>002<k1>AByantarAdAya<k2>AByantar-AdAya
{%ābhyantar-ādāya,%}¦ cf. {%bāhy-ābhyantar-ādāya%} (IE 8-5); internal
[Page-003+ 40]
<div n="lb">revenue income of a village; probably, taxes payable to the
<div n="lb">village authorities as against those payable to the king. Cf.
<div n="lb">{%antar-āya, abhyantara-siddhi, antaḥ-kara,%} etc. See {%bāhya.%}
<LEND>

<L>38<pc>003<k1>aByantarasidDi<k2>aByantara-sidDi, aByantara-sidDika
{%abhyantara-siddhi, abhyantara-siddhika%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 20, 22),
<div n="lb">same as {%ābhyantara-siddhi;%} internal income or revenue, or taxes
<div n="lb">payable to the village authorities as against those payable to the
<div n="lb">king; cf. {%tribhog-ābhyantara-siddhi, bāhy-ābhyantara-siddhi, bāhy-%}
<div n="lb">{%ābhyantar-ādāya;%} also {%sarv-ābhyantara-siddhi%} (EI 20), and {%antaḥ-%}
<div n="lb">{%siddhika%} (CII 4), a privilege of the donee of rent-free land.
<div n="lb">According to some (CII 4), it refers to the privilege of the
<div n="lb">donee offering full power of adjudication in law-suits.
<div n="lb">But expressions like {%tribhog-ābhyantara-siddhi%} (q. v.) render it
<div n="lb">doubtful. See {%bāhya, siddhi, siddh-āya.%}
<LEND>

<L>39<pc>003<k1>AByantarasidDi<k2>AByantara-sidDi
{%ābhyantara-siddhi%}¦ (CII 4), same as {%abhyantara-siddhi;%}
<div n="lb">explained by some as ‘the powers of adjudication’; probably,
<div n="lb">taxes payable to the village authorities as against those payable
<div n="lb">to the king. See {%abhyantara-siddhi,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>172<pc>010<k1>agrahAra<k2>agrahAra
{%agrahāra%}¦ (IE 8-4; EI 30; CII 4; SII 1; HRS; Chamba), rent-
<div n="lb">free land given to Brāhmaṇas; a rent-free village; a Brāhmaṇa
<div n="lb">village; sometimes suffixed to names of localities especially
<div n="lb">in South India. It was primarily, ‘a rent-free village in
<div n="lb">the possession of Brāhmaṇas’; but there are occasional references
[Page-011+ 40]
<div n="lb">to {%dev-āgrahāra%} (rent-free holding in the possession of a deity),
<div n="lb">{%vaiśy-āgrahāra%} (rent-free holding in the possession of the
<div n="lb">Vaiśyas), etc.; sometimes spelt {%agrāhāra%} (CII 3). See {%mah-%}
<div n="lb">{%āgrahāra, brahmapurī, caturvedi-maṅgala,%} etc.; also {%aṅga-bhoga.%}
<LEND>

<div n="lb">in this sense though they really mean ‘seven’.

<L>205<pc>012<k1>AjivakakAsu<k2>Ajivaka-kAsu
{%ājivaka-kāsu%}¦ (SITI), same as Tamil {%āśuva-kkāśu, āśuvikaḻ-%}
<div n="lb">{%kāśu, āśuva-kkaḍamai;%} tax payable by Ājīvakas or for the

<L>206<pc>012<k1>AjYA<k2>AjYA
{%Ājñā%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 27; BL; CII 3), an order or command;
<div n="lb">same as {%ājñapti%} or {%ājñāpti%} supposed to be connected
<div n="lb">with giving the order for the drawing up of a charter; person
<div n="lb">receiving a king's order regarding the preparation of a charter;
<div n="lb">usually translated as ‘executor of a grant’; standing alone,
<div n="lb">the word is supposed to indicate the office of the {%Dūtaka,%}
<div n="lb">though the latter seems to have been additionally responsible
<div n="lb">for giving the donee the possession of the gift land. Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%}
<div n="lb">Vol. XIV, p. 362 (of the Gaṅga year 149) where the words are
<div n="lb">{%ājñā mahāmahattara-Śivarmā;%} also {%svayam = ājñā%} ({%CII,%} Vol.
<div n="lb">III, p. 115; {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XVI, p. 19) taken to mean that
<div n="lb">the king employed no {%Dūtaka%} to convey the details of his grant
<div n="lb">to the local officers, but that he gave the details in person.
[Page-013+ 40]
<div n="lb">The expression {%sva-mukh-ājñā%} (literally, the oral order of the
<div n="lb">king) is also explained in the same way. The suggestion that
<div n="lb">{%Ājñādāpaka%} sometimes occurs as a synonym of {%Dūtaka%} is wrong.
<div n="lb">See {%Ājñapti, Ājñā-sañcārin,%} etc. Cf. {%Ind. Ep.,%} pp. 143-44.
<div n="P">{%Cf.%} Tamil {%āṇai%} (EI 23), sign; the insignia.
<LEND>

<L>207<pc>013<k1>AjYABogika<k2>AjYA-Bogika
{%Ājñā-bhogika%}¦ (EI 21; BL), {%Ājñā%} and {%Bhogika%} wrongly
<div n="lb">made into a single official designation. See {%Ājñā%} and {%Bhogika.%}
<LEND>

<L>270<pc>016<k1>alIpaka<k2>alIpaka
{%alīpaka,%}¦ also read as {%alīyaka%} (EI 32), a fiscal expression of
<div n="lb">uncertain import; see {%nidhān-ālīpaka.%} The word {%alipaka%} means
<div n="lb">‘a bee’. Thus {%ālipaka%} may refer to the right over wax, bee-hives,

<L>280<pc>016<k1>amAnta<k2>amAnta
{%amānta%}¦ (CII 3), the technical name for the scheme of the
<div n="lb">lunar months in Southern India, according to which a month
<div n="lb">ends with the new-moon day, and the bright fortnight precedes
<div n="lb">the dark. According to Fleet, it is always this arrangement
[Page-017+ 40]
<div n="lb">that is taken for calculation in astronomical works, though, even
<div n="lb">in Southern India, the arrangement was not applied to the
<div n="lb">Śaka years, for the civil reckoning, till between 804 and 866
<div n="lb">A. D.; on the other hand, according to him, even in Northern
<div n="lb">India, this arrangement was used in Nepal with the years of
<div n="lb">the Newār era, though it was abandoned there when the Newār
<div n="lb">era was followed by the Vikrama era in its northern
<div n="lb">variety. For its prevalence in Indonesia, see {%Sel. Ins.,%} p. 470.
<LEND>

<L>281<pc>017<k1>amara<k2>amara
{%amara%}¦ (IE 7-1-2), ‘thirtythree’ [being the original
<div n="lb">number of the gods].
<div n="P">({%SITI;%} ASLV), land or revenue granted by a ruler to his
<div n="lb">retainers for military service; land assigned to military officers
<div n="lb">who were entitled to collect only certain revenues with the
<div n="lb">obligation to raise a contingent of army ready for service when-
<div n="lb">ever called upon and also to pay tribute to the king; same as
<div n="lb">{%amara-māgaṇi.%} Cf. {%Amara-nāyaka.%}
<LEND>

<L>282<pc>017<k1>amaramAgaRi<k2>amara-mAgaRi
{%amara-māgaṇi%}¦ (SITI; ASLV), same as {%amara;%} estate
<div n="lb">given to an {%Amara-nāyaka.%}
<LEND>

<L>283<pc>017<k1>amaranAyaka<k2>amara-nAyaka
{%Amara-nāyaka%}¦ (EI 16; SITI; ASLV), a retainer chief
<div n="lb">enjoying {%amara,%} i. e. land or its revenue, for military service
<div n="lb">to be rendered to his master.
<LEND>

<L>334<pc>020<k1>aNgaBoga<k2>aNga-Boga
{%aṅga-bhoga%}¦ (EI 17; CITD), often associated with {%raṅga-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhoga%} as {%aṅga-raṅga-bhoga,%} usually explained as ‘decora-
<div n="lb">tions and illuminations of a deity’. That {%aṅga-bhoga%} means
<div n="lb">decoration of the image of a deity is clear from the fact
<div n="lb">that a queen is known to have received a village as an {%agrahāra%}
<div n="lb">for her {%aṅga-bhoga,%} i. e. as her pin-money ({%Bomb. Gaz.,%} Vol. I,
<div n="lb">Part ii, p. 448). Sometimes the land granted for the {%aṅga-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhoga%} of a deity came to be known as the deity's {%aṅga-bhoga%}
<div n="lb">({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXIII, p. 182); cf. {%aṅga,%} same as {%gātra%}
<div n="lb">(IA 11).
<LEND>

<div n="lb">of a rent-free holding, believed to be grouped into eight
<div n="lb">classes which are sometimes enumerated as {%nidhi, nikṣepa, jala,%}
<div n="lb">{%pāṣāṇa, akṣīṇin, āgāmin, siddha%} and {%sādhya.%} Cf. {%aiśvary-āṣṭaka%}
<div n="lb">and {%aṣṭa-bhūti%} (EI 33); also {%aṣṭabhoga-tejaḥsvāmya.%}
<div n="P">({%CITD%}), the eight privileges associated with the enjoy-
<div n="lb">ment of rent-free land, also enumerated as (1) {%nidhi%} (a
<div n="lb">treasure or a hoard, i. e. a natural hoard such as a mine),
[Page-031+ 40]
<div n="lb">(2) {%nikṣepa%} (a treasure hidden or stored up by some one),
<div n="lb">(3) {%akṣīṇa%} (permanent or lasting benefits), (4) {%āgāmin%} (future
<div n="lb">benefits); (5) {%sañcita%} (benefits already stored up), (6) {%jala%}
<div n="lb">(waters); (7) {%taru%} (trees) and (8) {%pāṣāṇa%} (stones). See
<div n="lb">{%JAHRS,%} Vol. X, p. 124. {%Pāṣāṇa%} seems to mean ‘hilly area’.
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), eight kinds of rights in enjoying landed property;
<div n="lb">mentioned sometimes as {%vikraya, dāna, vinimaya, jala, taru,%}
<div n="lb">{%pāṣāṇa, nidhi%} and {%nikṣepa,%} and also as {%nidhi, nikṣepa, jalāmṛta,%}
<div n="lb">{%pāṣāṇa, akṣīṇin, āgāmin, siddha%} and {%sādhya.%}
<LEND>

<L>558<pc>031<k1>azwaBogatejaHsvAmya<k2>azwaBoga-tejaHsvAmya
{%aṣṭabhoga-tejaḥsvāmya%}¦ (IA 8), unbridled ownership
<div n="lb">endowed with all the rights associated with the enjoyment of
<div n="lb">property; translated as ‘with the eight rights of full possession’
<div n="lb">though {%aṣṭa%} probably means ‘all’ and not merely ‘eight’ (cf.
<div n="lb">{%aṣṭādaśa,%} etc.); cf. {%aṣṭabhoga-tejaḥsvāmyaṃ ca krayeṇ = ādāya%} (EI
<div n="lb">23), ‘having secured the {%aṣṭabhoga-tejaḥsvāmya%} rights by pur-
<div n="lb">chase’; (IA 19), translated as ‘the proprietorship of all the
<div n="lb">glory of the {%aṣṭa-bhoga%}’, and {%aṣṭa-bhoga%} explained as ‘the
<div n="lb">deposits of buried treasure ({%nidhi-nikṣepa%}), water, stones, the
<div n="lb">{%akṣīṇī,%} that which may accrue, that which has been made
<div n="lb">property, that which may be made property, and augmen-
<div n="lb">tation’. But there is probably no justification for taking
<div n="lb">{%nidhi-nikṣepa%} as a single unit.
<div n="P">{%Cf. aṣṭabhoga-tejassvāmya-daṇḍaśulka-yukta%} ({%Ind. Ant.,%}
<div n="lb">Vol. XIX, p. 247, text line 102), mentioned along with {%nidhi-%}
<div n="lb">{%nikṣepa-pāṣāṇ-ārām-ādi-catuṣ-prakāra-bīravaṇa-pārikh-āya-sahita.%} The
<div n="lb">separate mention of these two groups shows that {%aṣṭa-bhoga%}
<div n="lb">vaguely indicated all kinds of proprietary rights.
<LEND>

<L>559<pc>031<k1>azwaBUti<k2>azwa-BUti
{%aṣṭa-bhūti%}¦ (EI 33), same as {%aṣṭa-bhoga.%}
<LEND>

<L>560<pc>031<k1>azwAdaSa<k2>azwAdaSa
{%aṣṭādaśa,%}¦ cf. {%aṣṭādaśa-jāti-parihāra%} (IE 8-5); literally,
<div n="lb">‘eighteen’; actually, ‘all’ ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXX, p. 115). Cf.
<div n="lb">Oḏiyā {%aṭhara-gaḍajāta%} (EI 26). See {%aṣṭa, ṣaṭtriṃśat, ṣaṭpañcāśat,%}
<div n="lb">{%bāhattara,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>561<pc>031<k1>azwAdaSadoza<k2>azwAdaSa-doza
{%aṣṭādaśa-doṣa%}¦ (SII 1), the eighteen or all sins.
<LEND>

<L>562<pc>031<k1>azwAdaSajAti<k2>azwAdaSa-jAti
{%aṣṭādaśa-jāti%}¦ (CITD), same as {%aṣṭādaśa-prajā;%} the 18
<div n="lb">castes. Kittel enumerates the 18 castes of the Kannaḍa-
<div n="lb">speaking area as the Brāhmaṇa, Kṣatriya, Vaiśya, Liṅgavanta,
<div n="lb">Baṇajige, Gaṅgaḍikāra-vokkaliga, Maḍivāli, Kelasiga, Kuṟuba,
<div n="lb">Kumbāṟa, Kaṭuka, Baḍagi, Akkasālĕ, Toreya, Uppāra, Besta,
<div n="lb">Holeya and Mādiga. But really the number 18 means ‘all’
<div n="lb">in such cases. The number 36 has the same meaning in the
[Page-032+ 40]
<div n="lb">Bengali expression {%chatriś-jāti,%} ‘36 castes’. See {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol.
<div n="lb">XXX, p. 115.
<LEND>

<L>563<pc>032<k1>azwAdaSaprajA<k2>azwAdaSa-prajA
{%aṣṭādaśa-prajā%}¦ (CITD), same as {%aṣṭādaśa-jāti, aṣṭādaśa-%}
<div n="lb">{%prakṛti.%}
<LEND>

<L>564<pc>032<k1>azwAdaSaprakfti<k2>azwAdaSa-prakfti
{%aṣṭādaśa-prakṛti,%}¦ cf. {%s-āṣtādaśa-prakṛty = opeta%} (EI 2);
<div n="lb">all classes of tenants; tenants belonging to all communities.
<div n="P">({%IA%} 17), ‘the eighteen (i. e. all) officials (i. e. classes of
<div n="lb">officials)’.

<L>568<pc>032<k1>azwAhnika<k2>azw-Ahnika, azw-AhnikA
{%aṣṭ-āhnika, aṣṭ-āhnikā%}¦ (EI 8, 33), Jain festival held in the
<div n="lb">months of Phālguna, Āṣāḍha and Kārttika; also called {%aṣṭ-%}
<div n="lb">{%āhnika-parvan;%} same as {%aṭṭhāi-mahotsava.%} See the Halsi plates

<div n="lb">Vol. VI, pp. 25-26. Cf {%The Successors of the Sātavāhanas,%}

<div n="lb">(SII 13), share-holders in a land. See {%dvādaśaka.%}

<L>570<pc>032<k1>azwakula<k2>azwa-kula
{%aṣṭa-kula,%}¦ cf. Tamil {%ūr-ĕṭṭu%} (SITI); the committee of eight
<div n="lb">members of the village assembly ({%ūr%}); taxes payable for the
<div n="lb">expenses of the committee (cf. {%eṇ-per-āyam%} which may also refer
<div n="lb">to the eight major items of revenue). See {%añjaṣṭa-sabhā.%}
<div n="P">{%Cf. aṣṭakul-ādhikaraṇa%} (IE 8-3; EI 31), an administrative
<div n="lb">board (like the {%Pañcāyat%}) consisting of eight (or more)
<div n="lb">members representing various classes or communities of people;
<div n="lb">cf. {%grām-āṣṭa-kul-ādhikaraṇa; mahattar-ādy-aṣṭakul-ādhikaraṇa.%}

<L>574<pc>032<k1>azwANga<k2>azwANga
{%aṣṭāṅga%}¦ (CITD), the eight constituents of {%yoga%} consisting
<div n="lb">of (1) {%niyama%} (restraint of the mind), (2) {%āsana%} (a parti-
<div n="lb">cular posture or mode of sitting), (3) {%prāṇāyāma%} (restraining or
<div n="lb">suspending the breath during the mental recitation of the names
[Page-033+ 40]
<div n="lb">or attributes of a deity), (4) {%yama%} (self-control), (5) {%pratyā-%}
<div n="lb">{%hāra%} (restraining the organs), (6) {%dhāraṇa%} (the faculty of
<div n="lb">retaining in the mind, steady abstraction of mind), (7)
<div n="lb">{%dhyāna%} (abstract contemplation, religious meditation), and
<div n="lb">(8) {%samādhi%} (perfect absorption of thought in the one object
<div n="lb">of meditation, i. e. the Supreme Spirit); mentioned in connec-
<div n="lb">tion with obeisance, it means the 8 parts of the body, viz., the
<div n="lb">two hands, chest, forehead, two knees and two feet (cf. {%aṣṭāṅga-%}
<div n="lb">{%namaskāra%}).
<LEND>

<L>575<pc>033<k1>azwANgaBaktikrama<k2>azwANga-Bakti-krama
{%aṣṭāṅga-bhakti-krama%}¦ (EI 19), eight forms of worship;
<div n="lb">same as {%aṣṭa-vidh-ārcana,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>576<pc>033<k1>azwANganamaskAra<k2>azwANga-namaskAra
{%aṣṭāṅga-namaskāra%}¦ (HA), obeisance with the eight
<div n="lb">limbs (viz. forehead, chest, two hands, two knees and two feet)
<div n="lb">done by lying straight on the ground, face downwards. See
<div n="lb">{%pañc-āṅga-namaskāra.%}
<LEND>

<L>601<pc>034<k1>aSvameDa<k2>aSvameDa
{%aśvamedha%}¦ (CII 3, 4), a sacrificial ceremony centering
<div n="lb">in a horse, generally performed by independent monarchs.
<div n="lb">Kings celebrating the sacrifice sometimes assumed suitable
<div n="lb">titles (cf. {%Aśvamedha-parākrama%} and {%Aśvamedha-Mahendra%} claimed
<div n="lb">respectively by Samudragupta and Kumāragupta I on their
<div n="lb">coins). Some kings performed two, four or more horse-sacri-
<div n="lb">fices. For a list of the performers of {%aśvamedha%} known form
<div n="lb">epigraphic and numismatic records, see {%Sundaram Pillai Com.%}
<div n="lb">{%Vol.,%} pp. 93 ff.
<LEND>

<L>604<pc>034<k1>aSvapati<k2>aSvapati
{%Aśvapati%}¦ (IE 8-2; CII 4)), cf. {%Aśvapati-Gajapati-Nara-%}
<div n="lb">{%pati-rāja-tray-ādhipati;%} royal title; the king as ‘the leader of the
<div n="lb">cavalry’; title of the Vijayanagara kings on account of their
<div n="lb">strength in horses (ASLV); title assumed by the rulers of
<div n="lb">some royal families.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 9, 21; CII 3; HD), an official title meaning either the
<div n="lb">master of the stables or the commander of the cavalry; cavalry
<div n="lb">officer; cf. {%Aśv-ādhyakṣa%} (EI 18). See {%CII,%} Vol. III,
<div n="lb">p. 259.

<L>620<pc>035<k1>aWagAnI<k2>aWa-gAnI
{%aṭha-gānī,%}¦ a coin equal to a {%ṭaṅka;%} there are {%do-gānī%}
<div n="lb">((1/4) {%ṭaṅka%}), {%cau-gānī%} ((1/2) {%ṭaṅka%}), {%cha-gānī%} ((3/4) {%ṭaṅka%}), {%bārah-%}
<div n="lb">{%gānī%} (1(1/2) {%ṭaṅkas%}), {%caubīs-gānī%} (3 {%ṭaṅkas%}), {%aḍatālīs-gānī%}
<div n="lb">(6 {%taṅkas%}). See {%JNSI,%} Vol. XXII, pp. 198-99.

<L>631<pc>036<k1>atIlarAjya<k2>atIla-rAjya
{%atīla-rājya%}¦ (IA 19), indicates that so many years
<div n="lb">‘since [the commencement of] the reign have [now] passed’;
<div n="lb">used in connection with the regnal reckoning of Govindapāla
<div n="lb">and Lakṣmaṇasena and rarely with the years of an era (e. g.
<div n="lb">the Vikrama-saṃvat associated with the reign of a legendary
<div n="lb">king named Vikramāditya). See also {%gata-rājya%} and {%vinaṣṭa-%}
<div n="lb">{%rājya.%} Cf. {%JAS,%} Letters, Vol. XX, 1954, pp. 43 ff.

<L>714<pc>040<k1>AvAta<k2>AvAta
{%āvāta%}¦ (IE 8-5), same as {%vāta,%} storm; cf. {%udvāta.%}
<div n="P">({%EI%} 32; CII 3; etc.), a fiscal term referring to the
<div n="lb">income from lands as a result of changes caused by natural
<div n="lb">agencies; an income probably resulting from storms. See
<div n="lb">{%vāta,%} probably meaning ‘a storm or tempest’; also {%āvāt-āya.%}
<LEND>

<L>730<pc>041<k1>Aya<k2>Aya
{%āya%}¦ (IE 7-1-2), ‘four’.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 33; CII 3; SII 1, 2), a fiscal term meaning ‘revenue’,
<div n="lb">‘tax’.
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), literally, income; a general term denoting
<div n="lb">‘taxes’; cf. {%va%}l13{%iy-āyam%} (SITI), tolls on the roadway.
<div n="P">({%HRS%}), revenue in general according to the {%Arthaśāstra%}
<div n="lb">and other authorities; a special branch of revenue according to
<div n="lb">the inscriptions of the Uccakalpa kings and later epigraphs.
<div n="P">({%CITD%}), profit, income, receipt; tribute; corn given
<div n="lb">by the well-to-do villagers to the hereditary servants of the
<div n="lb">village as their established fees of office.
<LEND>

<L>764<pc>043<k1>badi<k2>ba-di
{%ba-di%}¦ (IE 8-1; CII 3; etc.), contraction of {%bahula-pakṣa-dina%}
<div n="lb">or {%ºdivasa;%} also spelt {%va-di,%} cf. {%śu-di;%} abbreviations of separate
<div n="lb">words (see {%ba, di, śu%} and {%va%}) and not words in themselves,
<div n="lb">{%ba-di%} or {%va-di%} referring to the dark fortnight and {%śu-di%} the
<div n="lb">bright fortnight; they denote the fortnight and the solar
<div n="lb">or civil day, with reference to the lunar {%tithi,%} in the fortnight.

<L>779<pc>043<k1>bAhya<k2>bAhya
{%bāhya,%}¦ cf. {%bāhy-ābhyantar-ādāya%} (IE 8-5; {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol.
[Page-044+ 40]
<div n="lb">XVI, p. 276, text line 14); ‘income from the sale of things
<div n="lb">imported in a village’, same as Tamil {%pu%}ṟ{%av-āyam%} (SITI),
<div n="lb">‘revenue from external sources (collected mainly in cash)’ or
<div n="lb">Tamil {%pu%}ṟ{%a-kaḍamai%} (SITI), ‘external taxes’, explained as
<div n="lb">taxes and fees payable to the State. But {%pu%}ṟ{%a-kaḍamai%} is the
<div n="lb">same as {%pu%}ṟ{%av-āyam. Bāhya%} and {%ābhyantatra%} may thus mean
<div n="lb">respectively taxes payable to the king and those payable to
<div n="lb">the village authorities. See {%ābhyantara.%} Cf. {%samudaya-bāhy-%}
<div n="lb">{%ādya-stamba%} (EI 23), ‘land covered with original shrubs,
<div n="lb">i. e. waste which does not yield any revenue to the State’.
<div n="P">({%HD%}), a class of royal servants distinguished from
<div n="lb">{%Antaraṅga.%} See {%Rājataraṅgiṇī,%} VIII. 426, 680, 1542.
<LEND>

<L>796<pc>045<k1>bali<k2>bali
{%bali%}¦ (IE 8-5; HRS), voluntary gift (afterwards, com-
<div n="lb">pulsory contribution) and tribute from the subjects as indicated
<div n="lb">by Vedic literature; later, tax in general as suggested by the
<div n="lb">standard lexicons; king's grain share, identical with {%bhāga%}
<div n="lb">but different from {%kara%} according to the {%Arthaśāstra,%} but not
<div n="lb">the Junagadh inscription of Rudradāman (cf. {%bali-śulka-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhāga%} in line 14). The Rummindei inscription of Aśoka also
<div n="lb">distinguishes between {%bali%} and {%bhāga%} and seems to identify
<div n="lb">{%bali%} with {%kara%} (or with pilgrims' tax). See {%Select Inscriptions,%}
<div n="lb">pp. 71, 173.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 10, 23, 32; CII 3, 4), an offering to creatures; one
<div n="lb">of the five {%mahāyajñas%} or sacrificial rites. Cf. {%bali-caru-vaiśvadev-%}
<div n="lb">{%āgnihotra-kratu%} (EI 26), the five rites of a Brāhmaṇa.
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), offering of flowers, fruits, uncooked rice, etc.,
<div n="lb">to the gods; same as {%śrībali.%} Cf. {%Nārāyaṇa-baly-upahāra%} in the
<div n="lb">sense of {%Nārayaṇa-pūjā%} ({%Ind. Ant.,%} Vol. VI, p. 363).
<div n="P">{%Cf. varāha-bali,%} ‘pig sacrifice’ ({%Ep Ind.,%} Vol. XXXVI,
<div n="lb">p. 39). Cf. {%śrī-bali, havir-bali.%}
<LEND>

<L>838<pc>047<k1>BAga<k2>BAga
{%bhāga%}¦ (IE 8-5; CII 3, 4; EI 30; HRS), the king's share
<div n="lb">of the produce, distinguished from {%bali%} in the Rummindei
<div n="lb">inscription and the Junagadh inscription of Rudradāman and
<div n="lb">from {%kara%} in many other records; later, tax in general,
<div n="lb">identical with {%bali%} and {%kara%} (according to lexicons); cf.
<div n="lb">references in the {%Arthaśāstra%} to (1) {%lavaṇa-bhāga%} (king's share
<div n="lb">of salt sold by private merchants), (2) {%udaka-bhāga%} (king's
<div n="lb">grain share levied as water-tax upon irrigated fields),
<div n="lb">(3) king's share of the produce of mines leased out to private
<div n="lb">persons; (4) share paid to the king by merchants for selling
<div n="lb">the royal merchandise.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-5), dues (see {%kara%}); generally, the king's share of
<div n="lb">grains, which was originally one-sixth.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-4), a subdivision of a district or a territory.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 23, 33), an allotment; a share.
<LEND>

<L>839<pc>047<k1>BAgaBoga<k2>BAga-Boga
{%bhāga-bhoga%}¦ (CII 3; etc.), a fiscal expression in which
[Page-048+ 40]
<div n="lb">{%bhāga%} means the king's share of the produce and {%bhoga%} the
<div n="lb">periodical supplies made by tenants to the king; cf. {%bhāga-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhog-ādika, bhāga-bhoga-kara-hirany-ādika%} ({%EI%} 23), meaning
<div n="lb">‘royal dues’; see {%bhāga,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>840<pc>048<k1>BAgaBogakara<k2>BAga-Boga-kara
{%bhāga-bhoga-kara%}¦ (HRS), taken by some as a single levy
<div n="lb">and explained as the king's grain-share, identical with {%bhāga%}
<div n="lb">of the {%Arthaśāstra%} and {%bali%} of the Smṛtis, though distinguished
<div n="lb">from {%dhānya%} in a Maitraka record, where it has been supposed
<div n="lb">to mean a fixed contribution in kind as distinguished from
<div n="lb">the contribution consisting of a share of the produce. If
<div n="lb">{%bhāgabhogakara%} was a single levy (and did not indicate
<div n="lb">{%bhāga, bhoga%} and {%kara%}), it may have really been a tax collected
<div n="lb">in lieu of {%bhāga%} (grain share) and {%bhoga%} (periodical offerings).
<LEND>

<L>841<pc>048<k1>BAgaduGa<k2>BAgaduGa
{%Bhāgadugha%}¦ (HD), an official title; probably the same
<div n="lb">as {%Bhāgahāra.%} See Ghoshal, {%H. Rev. Syst.,%} p. 9.

<L>848<pc>048<k1>Bagavat<k2>Bagavat
{%Bhagavat%}¦ (ML; CII 3, 4), ‘the lord’ or ‘the divine’; an
<div n="lb">epithet of divinities such as Viṣṇu, Buddha, Jinendra, Nārāyaṇa,
<div n="lb">Śiva, the Sun-god, Kārttikeya, etc; also applied to sages, etc.
<div n="lb">in the sense of ‘venerable’, e. g. to Vyāsa, the arranger of the
<div n="lb">Vedas; rarely applied to kings apparently on account of their
<div n="lb">saintliness (cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXX, p. 19).

<L>882<pc>050<k1>BARqAra<k2>BARqAra
{%bhāṇḍāra,%}¦ cf. Tamil {%paṇḍāra-kkal%} (SITI), stone of standard

<div n="lb">officer, supervisor of the treasury.

<div n="lb">e. g., Jārandāya, etc.
<div n="P">{%Cf. paṇḍāram%} (SII 1), a treasury; a Śaiva mendicant.

<L>898<pc>051<k1>Bawa<k2>Bawa
{%Bhaṭa%}¦ (IE 8-3; CII 3, 4; EI 30; HD), same as {%Bhaṭa-%}
<div n="lb">{%manuṣya;%} probably derived from {%bhṛta%} which is sometimes used
<div n="lb">in its place. Generally used along with {%cāṭa%} or {%chātra;%} literally,
<div n="lb">‘a soldier’; but really a {%Pāik, Barkandāz%} or {%Piāda,%} i. e. a constable.
<div n="lb">It is spelt as {%bhaṭṭa%} in the medieval inscriptions of Eastern
<div n="lb">India, though rarely the two are distinguished. See {%Bhaṭṭa.%}
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), a personal servant or soldier.

<L>910<pc>052<k1>BawwAraka<k2>BawwAraka
{%Bhaṭṭāraka%}¦ (IE 8-2; CII 3; EI 30), title used in Sanskrit
<div n="lb">but really Prakrit derived from Sanskrit {%bhartṛ%} through the
<div n="lb">plural form {%bhartāraḥ%} = Prakrit {%bhaṭṭāra%} (see {%Svāmin%}); often
<div n="lb">suffixed to the personal names of paramount sovereigns as
<div n="lb">well as of feudatory {%Mahārājas,%} or {%Yuvarājas%} (crown-princes);
<div n="lb">applied to gods and priests in the sense of ‘worthy of worship
<div n="lb">or sacred’. Cf. {%bappa-bhaṭṭāraka-pāda-parigṛhīta, bhaṭṭāraka-%}
<div n="lb">{%Mahāsena-parigṛhīta,%} etc.

<div n="P">({%SII%} 1), title of Jain religious teachers.
<div n="P">({%CII%} 4), title of Śaiva ascetics, etc.
<div n="P">({%LP%}), a respected man.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 11), probably, epithet of the chief priest of a temple.
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), a deity; a spiritual preceptor.

<L>957<pc>054<k1>Boga<k2>Boga
{%bhoga%}¦ (IE 8-4; CII 3; EI 23, 33), literally, ‘enjoyment’
<div n="lb">(cf. {%bhukti%}); a {%jāgīr%} (cf. {%Mahārāja-Sarvanātha-bhoga, Mahā-%}
<div n="lb">{%sāmantādhipati-Śrīdhara-bhoga,%} etc.); possession (cf. {%bhog-%}
<div n="lb">{%ādhīnā gṛhītā%}). Originally ‘enjoyment’; then ‘property’,
<div n="lb">‘a {%jāgīr%}’; then also a territorial unit which was generally the
<div n="lb">subdivision of a district (IE 8-4; EI 25; 28; CII 4). See
<div n="lb">{%bhukti, āhāra.%}
<div n="P">{%Cf. Kaivarta-bhoga%} (IE 8-4; EI 2; CII 1), the fishermen's
<div n="lb">preserve.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-5; EI 29, 30; HRS), periodical supplies of fruits,
<div n="lb">firewood, flowers and the like which the villagers had to
<div n="lb">supply to the king; sometimes explained as ‘tax in kind’
<div n="lb">(CII 4).
<div n="P">({%EI%} 1), [an object of] enjoyment.
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), tax-free land set apart for the enjoyment of a
<div n="lb">person for the performance of specified services; same as
<div n="lb">{%mānya.%} See {%bhogottara, Bhogin,%} etc.
<div n="P">{%Cf. bhoge%} (LP), ‘for the right of enjoyment’.
<div n="P">{%Cf. sa-bhoga%} (IA 9), privilege of the donee of rent-free
<div n="lb">land; probably refers to {%aṣṭabhoga-tejaḥsvāmya%} (q. v.).
<LEND>
[Page-055+ 40]

<L>958<pc>055<k1>BogaBAga<k2>Boga-BAga

<div n="lb">{%bhoga-bhāga-kara-hiraṇy-ādi%} (EI 23), royal dues; see {%bhoga,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>959<pc>055<k1>Bogajanapada<k2>Boga-janapada

<L>969<pc>055<k1>Bogika<k2>Bogika

<div n="lb">{%bhoga%} or {%jāgīr;%} a {%Jāgīrdār%} or {%Ināmdār;%} same as {%Bhogin.%} See
<div n="lb">{%Bhoktṛ.%} Explained by some as the head of a district, or the
<div n="lb">collector of the State's share of the produce of lands taken in
<div n="lb">kind ({%Bomb. Gaz.,%} Vol. I, Part i, p. 82). See {%CII,%} Vol. III,
<div n="lb">pp. 96, 104.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3); EI 18; 23), a groom or horse-keeper, accord-
<div n="lb">ing to lexicons; cf. its Telugu modification {%Bhoi,%} ‘a palanquin-
<div n="lb">bearer’. But these meanings may have been derived from the
<div n="lb">first as the people appear to have enjoyed rent-free land for
<div n="lb">their services.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 33), same as {%Bhojaka%} meaning a {%Jāgīrdār%} or {%Ināmdār.%}
<div n="P">({%CII%} 4), explained as ‘the head of a {%bhoga%}’.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 5), explained as ‘a village proprietor’.

<L>1000<pc>057<k1>BujaNga<k2>BujaNga
{%bhujaṅga%}¦ (IA 20), an ogre. The word {%bhujaṅga%} was
<div n="lb">adopted in Javanese in the sense of a ‘pupil, disciple, scholar;
<div n="lb">a philologist, poet, literary councillor; an officially appointed
<div n="lb">professional usually residing at or near the court’. It has been
<div n="lb">suggested on this basis that Bhavadeva-bhaṭṭa's title
<div n="lb">{%Bālavalabhī-bhujaṅga%} may really mean ‘the pupil of the
<div n="lb">Bālavalabhī school’. See {%IHQ,%} Vol. XXVII, pp. 80-82.

<L>1010<pc>058<k1>BUmicCidra<k2>BUmicCidra

<L>1011<pc>058<k1>BUmicCidranyAya<k2>BUmicCidra-nyAya
{%bhūmicchidra-nyāya%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 30; CII 3, 4; HRS),
<div n="lb">literally, ‘the maxim of the fallow land’; the principle of the
<div n="lb">rent-free enjoyment of land by one who brings it under cultiva-
<div n="lb">tion for the first time. See {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol XXIX, p. 86. The
<div n="lb">maxim is based on the old custom of allowing a person, who
<div n="lb">first brings a plot of fallow or jungle land under cultivation
<div n="lb">for the first time, to enjoy it without paying rent. {%Bhūmi-%}
<div n="lb">{%cchidra%} gradually came to mean ‘uncultivable land’. See
<div n="lb">{%bhūmicchidrapidhāna-nyāya, avanirandhra-nyāya.%}
<LEND>

<L>1012<pc>058<k1>BUmicCidrapiDAnanyAya<k2>BUmicCidrapiDAna-nyAya
{%bhūmicchidrapidhāna-nyāya%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 11), the same as
<div n="lb">{%bhūmicchidra-nyāya;%} but it means ‘the maxim of covering up the
<div n="lb">hole in the land’ referring probably to the reclamation of
<div n="lb">fallow land for the first time; cf. {%bhūmicchidra%} understood
<div n="lb">in the sense of {%kṛṣy-ayogyā bhū,%} ‘land unfit for cultivation’.
<div n="lb">See {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXIX, p. 86.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">{%nyāya, bhumicchidrapidhāna-nyāya. Chidra-vidhāna = furrowing.%}

<L>1062<pc>061<k1>brahmakzatra<k2>brahma-kzatra, brahma-kzatriya
{%Brahma-kṣatra, Brahma-kṣatriya%}¦ (EI 5, 12, 24), a Kṣatriya
<div n="lb">family claiming descent from a Brāhmaṇa parent; a family in
<div n="lb">which the blood of the Brāhmaṇas and Kṣatriyas has been
<div n="lb">mixed. See {%Vishveshvaranand Ind. Journ.,%} Vol. I, pp. 87 ff., etc.
<div n="lb">In one record ({%Journ. Karnatak Univ.,%} Vol. II, No 2, January
<div n="lb">1959, p. 47), the Nāgavaṃśa, to which a Kadamba king's
<div n="lb">minister Māyideva belonged, is called {%Brahma-kṣatra%} because it
<div n="lb">originated from the intercourse of its progenitor Nāgarāja with
<div n="lb">a Brāhmaṇa girl. {%Brahma-vaiśya%} should be likewise explained.
<LEND>

<L>1136<pc>065<k1>cakravartikzetra<k2>cakravarti-kzetra
{%cakravarti-kṣetra%}¦ (IE 8-2; EI 33), the sphere of influence
<div n="lb">of an Indian imperial ruler lying between the Himalayas and
<div n="lb">the three seas, viz. Bay of Bengal, Indian Ocean and
<div n="lb">Arabian Sea; sometimes regarded as conterminous with
<div n="lb">{%Āryāvarta%} or {%Dākṣiṇātya.%} See Sircar, {%Stud. Geog. Anc. Med. Ind.,%}
<div n="lb">pp. 1 ff.
<LEND>

<L>1137<pc>065<k1>cakravartin<k2>cakravartin
{%Cakravartin%}¦ (IE 8-2; EI 21, 28; CII 3, 4), a title of para-
<div n="lb">mount sovereignty; the title of an emperor. See {%Saptama-%}
<div n="lb">{%cakravartin;%} also {%Cakreśvara, Cakrin.%}
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-2), often suffixed to expressions like {%Pratāpa, Prau-%}
<div n="lb">{%ḍhapratāpa, Bhujabalapratāpa, Niḥśaṅkapratāpa,%} etc., and some-
<div n="lb">times also to dynastic names like {%Yādava.%}

<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-2), cf. {%cakravarti-kṣetra.%}

<L>1182<pc>067<k1>cAwa<k2>cAwa
{%Cāṭa%}¦ (HD), irregular soldiers according to Fleet and
<div n="lb">Bühler. Vogel ({%Ant. Ch. St.,%} pp. 130-32) points out that
<div n="lb">Chamba is the only place where the ancient word {%Cāṭa%} is still
<div n="lb">extant in the modern form {%Cā%}ḏ meaning ‘the head of a Parganā’.
<div n="lb">An important privilege of a gift village was ‘not to be entered
<div n="lb">by {%Cāṭas%} and {%Bhaṭas%}’. Inscriptions ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XI,
<div n="lb">p. 221) often specify that the granted land was not to be entered
<div n="lb">by {%Cāṭas%} and {%Bhaṭas%} except for seizing robbers and those guilty
<div n="lb">of harm or treason to the king (cf. {%a-cāṭa-bhaṭa-praveśyaṃ cora-%}
<div n="lb">{%drohaka-varjam%} in op. cit., Vol. VIII, p. 287). Sometimes we
<div n="lb">have {%bhaṭa-cāṭa-sevak-ādīn%} ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. IV, p. 211) and
<div n="lb">{%caṭṭa-bhaṭṭa-jātīyān janapadān%} (ibid., Vol. XIV, p. 160).
[Page-068+ 40]
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3; CII 3, 4), generally mentioned along with
<div n="lb">{%bhaṭa;%} sometimes replaced by {%cāra%} (spy) and {%chātra%} (literally,
<div n="lb">‘umbrella-bearer’, but really, a constable, i. e. a {%Pāik%} or {%Piāda%});
<div n="lb">probably indicates the leader of a group of {%Bhaṭas,%} i. e. {%Pāiks%}
<div n="lb">and {%Piādas;%} a policeman leading a group of {%Pāiks.%} See {%caṭṭa.%}
<div n="lb">Yājñavalkya, I. 336, speaks of the duty of the king to
<div n="lb">protect people from the harassment caused by {%cāṭas,%} robbers
<div n="lb">and {%Kāyasthas%} and the {%Mitākṣarā%} explains {%cāṭa%} as persons
<div n="lb">who deprive people of their wealth after creating false confi-
<div n="lb">dence in them. According to Bṛhaspati quoted by Aparārka,
<div n="lb">‘dangers common to all are those arising from the {%cāṭas%} and
<div n="lb">thieves’. The word {%cāṭa%} in the passage {%tārkika-cāṭa-bhaṭa-rāj-%}
<div n="lb">{%āpraveśya%} in Śaṅkara's {%Bhāsya%} on the {%Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad%}
<div n="lb">is explained by Ānandagiri by saying that the {%cāṭas%} are those
<div n="lb">that transgress the rules of conduct for decent people and that
<div n="lb">{%bhaṭas%} are servants telling falsehood ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. IX, p. 296).
<div n="lb">But {%cāṭa%} is used in inscriptions in the sense of a royal official.
<LEND>

<L>1200<pc>069<k1>caturDarapratIhAra<k2>caturDara-pratIhAra
{%Caturdhara-pratīhāra,%}¦ cf. Kannaḍa {%Sodare-vadiyara%} ({%Hydera-%}
<div n="lb">{%bad Archaeological Series,%} No. 18, p. 34); explained as ‘the chief
<div n="lb">of the royal guards’. {%Caturdhara%} is modern {%Caudhari,%} written
<div n="lb">in Kannaḍa as {%Saudore, Saudare, Caudore, Cavudore%} and {%Cavudari%}
<div n="lb">and explained as ‘an officer of the royal guard’.
<LEND>

<L>1206<pc>069<k1>cAturmAsI<k2>cAturmAsI

<LEND>

<L>1207<pc>069<k1>cAturmAsIpakza<k2>cAturmAsI-pakza
{%cāturmāsī-pakṣa%}¦ (IA 18), the fortnight ending in a {%cātur-%}
<div n="lb">{%māsī%} (i. e. the full-moon of Phālguna, Āṣāḍha and Kārttika).
<LEND>

<L>1208<pc>069<k1>cAturmAsya<k2>cAturmAsya
{%cāturmāsya%}¦ (SII 11-1, CITD), the season consisting of 4
<div n="lb">months, viz. {%grīṣma%} consisting of the {%pūrṇimānta%} months of Caitra,
[Page-070+ 40]
<div n="lb">Vaiśākha, Jyeṣṭha and Āṣāḍha, {%varṣā%} consisting of Śrāvana,
<div n="lb">Bhādrapada, Āśvina and Kārttika; and {%hemanta%} consisting of
<div n="lb">Mārgaśīrṣa, Pauṣa, Māgha and Phālguna. This was the
<div n="lb">official division of the year which was popularly divided into six
<div n="lb">seasons, viz. {%grīṣma%} (Jyeṣṭha-Āṣāḍha), {%varṣā%} (Śrāvaṇa-Bhādra-
<div n="lb">pada), {%śarad%} (Āśvina-Kārttika), {%hemanta%} (Mārgaśīrṣa-Pauṣa),
<div n="lb">{%śīta%} (Māgha-Phālguna) and {%vasanta%} (Caitra-Vaiśākha). Some
<div n="lb">times, the word {%cāturmāsya%} specially means the four months of
<div n="lb">the year, containing the two seasons of {%varṣā%} and {%śarad,%} i. e.
<div n="lb">from Śrāvaṇa to Kārttika. During this period, Viṣṇu is
<div n="lb">supposed to sleep, so that religious celebrations are avoided.
<div n="lb">During the period, religious mendicants desisted from roving.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 7; BL), related to the {%cāturmāsī%} or the full-moon day
<div n="lb">of Phālguna, Āshāḍha and Kārttika; a rite; same as {%cātur-%}
<div n="lb">{%māsya-vrata.%}
<LEND>

<L>1209<pc>070<k1>cAturmAsyavrata<k2>cAturmAsya-vrata
{%cāturmāsya-vrata%}¦ (EI 32), a rite. See {%cāturmāsya.%}
<LEND>

<L>1231<pc>071<k1>cOravarjam<k2>cOra-varjam
{%caura-varjam%}¦ (CII 3; HRS), cf. {%cora-varjam, coradaṇda-%}
<div n="lb">{%varjam, cora-rājāpathyakāri-varjam;%} ‘with immunity from the
<div n="lb">police tax’ according to some; may really mean ‘without any
<div n="lb">right to inflict punishment on thieves and persons committing
<div n="lb">the crime of treason or to levy fines from them’; may also be
<div n="lb">connected with {%a-bhaṭa-praveśa%} so as to indicate that the {%bhaṭas%}
<div n="lb">should not enter except for catching thieves and persons
<div n="lb">committing the crime of treason; cf. {%Cāṭa.%}
<LEND>

<L>1257<pc>073<k1>CAtra<k2>CAtra
{%Chātra%}¦ (IE 8-3, 8-8; EI 23, 30), cf. {%a-bhaṭa-cchātra-%}
<div n="lb">{%prāveśya%} (IE 8-5); literally, ‘one bearing an umbrella’ or ‘the
<div n="lb">king's umbrella-bearer’; but probably the same as the {%Cāṭa%}
<div n="lb">or the leader of a group of {%Bhaṭas%} ({%Pāiks%} or {%Piādas%}) as in {%a-cāṭa-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhaṭa-prāveśya;%} a peon of the law-court. See {%Chatracchāyika.%}
<div n="P">({%CII%} 3), used in composition with {%bhaṭa%} and also singly;
<div n="lb">literally, ‘an umbrella-bearer’; but actually, a constable like
<div n="lb">a {%Pāik%} or {%Piāda.%}
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), celibate ({%Brahmacārin%}) in charge of a temple
<div n="lb">and the {%śālai%} attached to it; also called {%Śaṭṭar, Śāttirar.%}
<LEND>

<div n="lb">{%dharma-śālā.%}

<L>1273<pc>074<k1>CuriprabanDa<k2>Curi-prabanDa
{%churi-prabandha%}¦ (BL), name of a grant made in favour of
<div n="lb">a {%Churikāra,%} ‘a maker of {%churis%}’. The word {%churi%} may be the
<div n="lb">same as {%kṣurikā,%} ‘a knife’, and a {%Churikāra%} may have been an
<div n="lb">officer in charge of the production of knives and swords.
<LEND>

<L>1274<pc>074<k1>Cuw<k2>Cuw
{%chuṭ%}¦ (LP), cf. {%choṭanīya;%} Gujarātī {%cho%}ḏ{%āvavuṃ;%} also cf.
<div n="lb">{%granthi-baddhair = api drammaiḥ kṣetraṃ choṭayituṃ dhāraṇiko na%}
<div n="lb">{%labhate,%} ‘[when the date is already over], the debtor will not
<div n="lb">get his farm liberated by the ready money tied in a piece of
<div n="lb">cloth’.

<div n="lb">also Gujarātī {%chaṭśe.%}

<L>1307<pc>075<k1>coradaRqavarjya<k2>cora-daRqa-varjya
{%cora-daṇḍa-varjya%}¦ (CII 3), a fiscal term which means either
<div n="lb">that no fines for theft should be collected from the gift village
<div n="lb">or, more probably, that the donee was not entitled to fines
<div n="lb">realisable on thieves in the gift villages. But see also {%caura-varjam.%}
<LEND>

<L>1308<pc>075<k1>coradrohakavarja<k2>cora-drohaka-varja
{%cora-drohaka-varja%}¦ (CII 3, etc.), a fiscal term which is
<div n="lb">similar to {%coradaṇḍa-varja.%} The word {%drohaka%} means one
<div n="lb">committing a crime against the king. See {%caura-varjam, Cāḷa.%}
<LEND>

<div n="lb">verse 18; also Kātyāyana quoted by Aparārka).

<L>1310<pc>075<k1>corarAjApaTyakArivarjam<k2>cora-rAjApaTyakAri-varjam
{%cora-rājāpathyakāri-varjam%}¦ (HRS), ‘with immunity from
<div n="lb">the police tax’, according to some; seems to mean ‘without any
[Page-076+ 40]
<div n="lb">right to inflict punishment on or levy fines from thieves and
<div n="lb">rebels’. But see {%caura-varjam;%} also {%Cāṭa.%}

{%damma%}¦ (SITI), same as {%dramma;%} name of a coin; derived
<div n="lb">from Greek {%drachma.%}

<L>1367<pc>078<k1>dAna<k2>dAna, dAnA
{%dāna, dānā%}¦ (ML), a gift.
<div n="P">({%HRS%}), known from Maitraka records to mean the so-
<div n="lb">called voluntary gifts of subjects.
<div n="P">{%Cf. dānā-sambandhe%} (LP), ‘as regards the sale-tax’.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">duties; cf. the official designation {%Dāṇī%} (Sanskrit {%Dānin%}).
<LEND>

<L>1369<pc>078<k1>dARacori<k2>dARa-cori
{%dāṇa-cori%}¦ (EI 32), smuggling.

<L>1370<pc>078<k1>dAnAdAyadAnIBoga<k2>dAnAdAya-dAnIBoga
{%dānādāya-dānībhoga%}¦ (LP), explained as ‘local cess or road-
<div n="lb">cess’; {%dāya%} is explained as ‘a gift to Brāhmaṇas or temples’,
[Page-079+ 40]
<div n="lb">{%dānī%} as ‘land tax’ and {%bhoga%} as ‘right of enjoyment’; but probably,
<div n="lb">{%dāṇ-ādāya%} means excise or customs duties and {%dāni-bhoga%} a
<div n="lb">tax for the maintenance of the tax-collector.
<LEND>

<L>1371<pc>079<k1>dAnADikArin<k2>dAn-ADikArin
{%Dān-ādhikārin%}¦ (EI 12), officer in charge of gifts, mentioned
<div n="lb">along with the {%Śāsan-ādhikārika,%} ‘officer in charge of grants
<div n="lb">(or their writing)’. See {%Dharm-ādhikārin.%} It may also mean
<div n="lb">‘a tolls-collector’ (cf. {%dāna, Dānin%}).
<LEND>

<L>1381<pc>079<k1>daRqa<k2>daRqa
{%daṇḍa%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 12), fine or tax, mentioned along with
<div n="lb">{%suṅka (śulka);%} a levy or free service (cf. {%prayāṇa-daṇda%}).
<div n="P">({%EI%} 24), fines; authority.
<div n="P">({%HRS%}), fines; distinguished from {%atyaya%} in the {%Artha-%}
<div n="lb">{%śāstra.%}
<div n="P">({%CII%} 1), punishment.
<div n="P">({%ASLV%}), judicial punishment; sometimes possibly also
<div n="lb">‘administration’.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 25), ‘five’.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 30; LP), contraction of {%Daṇdanāyaka.%}
<div n="P">({%EI%} 28), Oḏiyā; a path (cf. {%daṇḍā%}).
<div n="P">{%Cf. taṇḍu (SITI),%} a palanquin; a pole for carrying the
<div n="lb">vehicle on which the image of a deity is set up.
<div n="P">{%Cf. daṇḍu, taṇḍu%} (SITI), an army; going on a military
<div n="lb">expedition.
<div n="P">{%Cf. taṇdam%} (SII 1; CITD); fine, penalty or punishment;
<div n="lb">a punitive tax; a fine or tax payable as penalty.
<LEND>
[Page-080+ 40]

<L>1397<pc>080<k1>daRqanAyaka<k2>daRqanAyaka
{%Daṇḍanāyaka%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 30; CII 4; BL), probably a
<div n="lb">translation of Greek {%Strategos;%} a general; a leader of forces,
<div n="lb">an army officer; a military commander; also called {%Daṇḍa-%}
<div n="lb">{%nātha, Daṇdanetṛ,%} etc.; sometimes also called {%Mahāsāmanta,%}
<div n="lb">{%Senādibāhattaraniyogādhiṣṭhāyaka, Mahāpradhāna, Sarvādhikārin,%}
<div n="lb">{%Mahāpasāyita,%} etc., additionally; see {%Mahādaṇḍanāyaka, Sarva-%}
<div n="lb">{%daṇḍanāyaka, Mahāsarvadaṇḍanāyaka.%}
[Page-081+ 40]
<div n="P">({%LP%}), generally, the viceroy or governor of a province;
<div n="lb">representative of the king.
<div n="P">({%ASLV%}), the commander of forces and officer in charge
<div n="lb">of administration; title of the provincial governors; similar to
<div n="lb">the {%Mansabdār%} of the Mughal period.
<div n="P">({%HD%}), a prefect of the police, according to Stein ({%Rāja-%}
<div n="lb">{%taraṅgiṇī,%} VII. 951); ‘a General or Magistrate’, according to
<div n="lb">some (cf. Kielhorn's Southern List, Nos. 291, 292, 296). In
<div n="lb">the {%Bṛhatsaṃhitā%} (7. 2-4), the queen, {%Yuvarāja, Senāpati%} and
<div n="lb">{%Daṇḍanāyaka%} are placed on the same level in the matter of the
<div n="lb">staff ({%daṇḍa%}) to be prepared for them.
<div n="P">{%Cf. Taḍeya-daṇḍanāyaka,%} explained as ‘the general in
<div n="lb">charge of reserves’, from Kannaḍa, {%taḍĕ,%} ‘far, restraint’.
<LEND>

{%Dāṇḍanāyaka%}¦ (EI 23; HD), same as {%Daṇdanāyaka.%} See
<div n="lb">{%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XIX, p. 269.

<L>1449<pc>084<k1>daSabanDa<k2>daSabanDa
{%daśabandha%}¦ (SITI), variously explained as (1) one-tenth
<div n="lb">of the revenue set apart for repairs to the tanks and wells for
<div n="lb">irrigation purposes; (2) land, the income from which would
<div n="lb">be equal to the amount thus set apart; (3) the right of collect-
<div n="lb">ing one-tenth of the produce of lands irrigated from the waters
<div n="lb">of a tank or well by the person who repairs the water source;
<div n="lb">also explained as tax equal to one-tenth of the income of the
<div n="lb">subject (Ray, {%DHNI,%} Vol. II, p. 1113). See {%daśavandha.%}
<div n="P">({%SITI%}) tax or cess levied to keep the source of water
<div n="lb">supply like the tanks, etc., in good repair.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 4), rent-free land or probably land paying only
<div n="lb">one-tenth of the actual rent.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 20), one-tenth share.
<div n="P">{%Cf. daśa-bandhe%} (LP), ‘at 10 per cent’.
<div n="P">{%Cf. daśavandha%} (SII 3), a tax.
<LEND>

<L>1457<pc>085<k1>daSApacAra<k2>daS-ApacAra

<L>1458<pc>085<k1>daSAparADa<k2>daS-AparADa
{%daś-āparādha%}¦ (CII 3, 4), literally, ‘the ten offences’; but
<div n="lb">really, the fines for the ten offences; cf. {%sa-daś-āparādha%} (IE 8-5);
<div n="lb">power to punish and realise fines for the ten offences; also
<div n="lb">called {%daś-āpacāra.%} According to the Buddhists, the ten sins
<div n="lb">were murder, theft, adultery, lying, calumny, insult, idle
<div n="lb">talk, hatred, covetousness and dogmatic error (A. Getty, {%The%}
<div n="lb">{%Gods of Northern Buddhism,%} p. xxv, note). For a Brahmanical
<div n="lb">list, see {%Dāśāparādhika;%} cf. {%pañca-mahāpātaka, pañc-āparādha.%}
<LEND>

<L>1459<pc>085<k1>dASAparADika<k2>dASAparADika
{%Dāśāparādhika%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 29; HD), a judge dealing
<div n="lb">with the ten offences (viz. theft, murder of women, adultery, use
<div n="lb">of abusive language, violation of order, mixing of castes, illegal
<div n="lb">pregnancy, obscenity, assault and abortion, according to some).
<div n="lb">It has been said that the ten offences or {%aparādhas%} are those
<div n="lb">of which the king could take cognisance {%suo moto.%} For the ten
<div n="lb">{%aparādhas,%} see Kane, {%Hist. Dharm.,%} Vol. III, p. 264; cf. {%Ep.%}
<div n="lb">{%Ind.,%} Vol. XVII, p. 321.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">tendent of the procession of idols’; but probably, the superin-

<div n="lb">general; same as {%Devadroṇī-sambaddha;%} cf. {%deva-droṇī%} (EI 13).

<L>1691<pc>098<k1>ditya<k2>ditya
{%ditya%}¦ (EI 9, 12, 28; CII 4; HRS), known from Maitraka
<div n="lb">records; name of a tax, according to some; probably, the
<div n="lb">same as {%datti,%} i. e. a gift or occasional present to be offered
<div n="lb">to the landlord; cf. {%sarva-ditya-viṣṭi-prātibhedikā-parihīna%} or
<div n="lb">{%ºparihṛta%} ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. VI, p. 298, text line 20); also cf.
<div n="lb">{%sa-ditya-dāna-karaṇa%} ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXI, p. 301, text line 14),
<div n="lb">an epithet of the gift land. {%Ditya%} is probably derived from
<div n="lb">Prakrit {%dijja%} = Sanskrit {%deya,%} ‘to be given’, ‘an object that has
<div n="lb">been given away’ in the sense of ‘customary presents’. For
<div n="lb">{%ditta,%} cf. {%Bhār. Vid.,%} Vol. XVII, Nos. 3-4 pp. 125-26. See
<div n="lb">{%Dity-odgrāhaka.%}
<LEND>

<L>1720<pc>100<k1>dramma<k2>dramma
{%dramma%}¦ (EI 25, 30; CII 4; SITI; BL), name of a coin;
<div n="lb">originally derived from Greek {%drachma.%}
<div n="P">(IE 8-8), a silver coin, equal to one-sixteenth of a gold
<div n="lb">{%niṣka%} according to the {%Līlāvalī.%}
<div n="P">{%Cf. pañciyaka-dramma%} (EI 30), {%Śrīmadādivarāha-dramma,%}
<div n="lb">{%Vigraha-dramma, Vigrahapāla-dramma, Vigrahapāla-satka-dramma,%}
<div n="lb">{%Vigrahapālīya-dramma, Vigrahatuṅgīya-dramma%} (IE 8-8; EI 1);
<div n="lb">{%Bhīmapriya-dramma%} (IE 8-8); {%poruttha-dramma%} (EI 23).--(IE 8-8),
<div n="lb">cf. {%gara-dramma, dāya-dramma, belliya-dramma%} (i. e. silver {%dramma%}),
<div n="lb">etc., of Kannaḍa inscriptions; the name {%dramma%} was also applied
<div n="lb">to the silver coin called {%purāṇa, dharaṇa%} or {%kārṣāpaṇa,%} though it
<div n="lb">was often used as the name of copper coins; money. For gold
<div n="lb">and ordinary (copper) {%dramma,%} cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXX, p. 111.
<div n="P">{%Cf. vāśal-tiramam%} (SITI), door tax.
<LEND>

<L>1726<pc>101<k1>drANgika<k2>drANgika
{%Drāṅgika%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 10, 30; CII 3, 4; HD), probably, an
<div n="lb">officer in charge of a city-station or watch-tower for collection
<div n="lb">of customs duties. {%Draṅga%} means either ‘a town’ (Bhandarkar's
<div n="lb">List, No. 810) or ‘a watch-station’ ({%Rājataraṅgiṇī,%} VIII. 2010).
<div n="lb">{%Drāṅgika%} was an officer in charge of a {%draṅga%} probably mean-
<div n="lb">ing a watch station or a station for revenue collection; similar
<div n="lb">to {%Audraṇgika%} in the latter sense; mentioned along with the
<div n="lb">{%Dhruvasthān-ādhikaraṇa%} or ‘the collector of the king's grain-
<div n="lb">share’. Cf. {%draṅga, Draṅgapāla,%} etc. See {%CII,%} Vol. III, p. 169.

<L>1770<pc>103<k1>dUta<k2>dUta
{%Dūta%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 23, 30; CII 1; HD), a messenger or
<div n="lb">envoy. See {%Viṣṇudharmottara,%} II. 24. 13-14, 28; {%CII,%} Vol. I,
<div n="lb">p. 67.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 23; CII 3, 4), an occasional substitute for {%Dūtaka,%}
<div n="lb">the executor of a grant.
<LEND>

<L>1771<pc>103<k1>dUtaka<k2>dUtaka
{%Dūtaka%}¦ (IE 8-3; HD), messenger; conveyor of a request
<div n="lb">or message; cf. the Khalimpur plate of Dharmapāla ({%Ep.%}
<div n="lb">{%Ind.,%} Vol. IV, p. 250), according to which the king was reques-
<div n="lb">ted to make a grant by a {%Mahāsāmantādhipati%} through prince
[Page-104+ 40]
<div n="lb">Tribhuvanapāla as the {%Dūtaka.%} His function is called {%dūtya%}
<div n="lb">in the Nalanda plate of Devapāla ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XVII,
<div n="lb">318 ff., text line 51).
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3; EI 23, 30; CII 3, 4), according to some, the
<div n="lb">technical title of an officer connected with royal charters,
<div n="lb">whose duty it was to carry the king's orders to the local officials
<div n="lb">by whom the charter was then drawn up and delivered. But
<div n="lb">the {%Dūtaka%} seems to have been responsible for putting the
<div n="lb">document and also perhaps the gift land in the donee's possession.
<div n="lb">There are instances of more {%Dūtakas%} than one (IA 19). See
<div n="lb">also {%Ājñā, Dūta,%} and {%sva-mukh-ājñā.%} Cf. {%Ind. Ep.,%} pp. 143-44.
<LEND>

<L>1772<pc>104<k1>dUtaprEzaRika<k2>dUta-prEzaRika
{%Dūta-praiṣaṇika%}¦ (HD), officer in charge of sending
<div n="lb">envoys; same as {%Dūta-preṣaṇika.%} See {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XVII, p.
<div n="lb">321; {%Ind. Ant.,%} Vol. XV, p. 306. Cf. {%Preṣaṇika.%}
<LEND>

<div n="lb">and {%Dūta-praiṣaṇika;%} the officer who despatched {%Dūtas.%}

{%dvāra%}¦ (CII 1), a way or means.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 7-1-2), ‘nine’.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 4), the mouth of a river.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3), cf. ‘the lord of the {%dvāra%}’ which was the desig-
<div n="lb">nation of a commander of forces in Kashmir; possibly, a pass
<div n="lb">[leading into the Kashmir valley].
<div n="P">{%Cf.%} Tamil {%vāśal-paṇam,%} ‘door-tax’; periodical payment
<div n="lb">due to the palace. Cf. {%dvār-ādeya.%}

<div n="lb">Ghoshal, {%H. Rev. Syst.,%} p. 60, note. But cf. Tamil {%vāśal-paṇam%}
<div n="lb">explained as ‘door-tax’, i. e. the periodical payment due to
<div n="lb">the palace.’

<L>1807<pc>106<k1>eqUka<k2>eqUka
{%eḍūka,%}¦ cf. {%eḍuo%} (CII 2-1), supposed to be ‘a wall into which
<div n="lb">bones (meaning planks and other hard substances) have been
<div n="lb">inserted in order to strengthen the structure’, because it is
<div n="lb">explained in a commentary as {%asthy-aṅkita kuḍya;%} but {%asthy-%}
<div n="lb">{%aṅkita-kuḍya%} seems to mean a Buddhist {%stūpa%} raised on cor-
<div n="lb">poreal relics which were an object of worship. Although
<div n="lb">the word {%kuḍya%} is reckoned in the lexicons in the sense of a wall,
<div n="lb">it seems to mean ‘a mound’ in this case. The word {%aidūka%}
<div n="lb">derived from {%eḍūka%} is used in Buddhist Sanskrit in the
<div n="lb">sense of a Buddhist {%stūpa.%} See {%IHQ,%} Vol. XXIX, pp.
<div n="lb">302-03.
<LEND>

<L>1808<pc>106<k1>ekaBoga<k2>eka-Boga

<div n="lb">land or village in the sole enjoyment of a single owner. Same
<div n="lb">as {%eka-bhogya.%} Cf. {%gaṇa-bhoga.%}

{%gadyāṇa%}¦ (IE 8-8; EI 27, 30), also called {%gadyāṇaka,%} often

<div n="lb">{%gadyāṇa-ponnu%} indicating that it was a gold coin; sometimes
[Page-108+ 40]
<div n="lb">called {%suvarṇa;%} cf. {%bhairava-gadyāṇa, lokki-gadyāṇa%} (SII 11-2),
<div n="lb">{%aṅka-gadyāṇa, gāva-gadyāṇa, komarina-gadyāṇa, priyaśrāha-gaja-%}
<div n="lb">{%malla-gadyāṇa, ambili-gadyāṇa, jagadalaṃ-gadyāṇa,%} etc. Cf. also
<div n="lb">{%a%}ṟ{%u-gadyāṇa%} (IA 12) and {%kula-gadyāṇa%} (EI 17), names of coins.
<div n="lb">Cf. {%parameṣṭhi-gadyāṇa-ponna%} ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXVI, p. 61).
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), name of a coin, probably equal to a {%varāha%} or
<div n="lb">{%pagoda;%} cf. {%bṛhad-bhairava-gadyāṇa%} (EI 30); also {%kaṭhāri-%}
<div n="lb">{%aṅkuśa-gadyāṇa%} (EI 8), name of a coin with the representation
<div n="lb">of a dagger and a goad; {%varāha-gadyāṇa%} (EI 8), name of the
<div n="lb">gold coin called both {%varāha%} and {%gadyāṇa.%}
<LEND>

{%gadyāṇa%}¦ (CITD), same as {%gadyāṇa;%} a coin like a farthing

<L>1941<pc>113<k1>gOrIvarAwikA<k2>gOrI-varAwikA
{%gaurī-varāṭikā,%}¦ ‘virgin-money’. {%Gaurī%} means ‘a virgin’
<div n="lb">and {%varāṭikā%} is used primarily in the sense of {%varāṭa%} or {%varāṭaka,%}
<div n="lb">‘a cowrie-shell’, and secondarily in that of ‘money’. In the
<div n="lb">records of Mithilā, {%gaurī-varāṭikā%} means ‘money to be paid
<div n="lb">to the master of a slave girl of marriageable age by the master
<div n="lb">of her bridegroom’. See {%JNSI,%} Vol. XVI, pp. 264 ff.
<LEND>

<L>1942<pc>113<k1>gOtamIputra<k2>gOtamI-putra
{%Gautamī-putra%}¦ (IE 2-8), metronymic meaning ‘the son of
<div n="lb">a lady born in a family belonging to the Gautama {%gotra%}’. Such
<div n="lb">metronymics refer to the absence of {%gotr-āntara%} (i. e. the change
<div n="lb">of the bride's paternal {%gotra%} to that of her husband at the time
<div n="lb">of marriage) in a popular form of ancient Indian marriage.
<LEND>

<L>2014<pc>117<k1>gokarRa<k2>gokarRa

<L>2048<pc>119<k1>gotra<k2>gotra
{%gotra%}¦ (CII 3; IA 19; CITD), a family or clan, a tribe or
<div n="lb">lineage; a caste. No Hindu can marry a girl of his own {%gotra%}
<div n="lb">or stock, though some forms of ancient Indian marriages did
<div n="lb">not involve the {%gotr-āntara,%} i. e. the change of the wife's {%gotra%}
<div n="lb">to that of the husband at the time of marriage ({%Proc. IHC,%}
<div n="lb">Annamalainagar, 1945, pp. 48 ff.). Cf. {%Gautamī-putra,%} etc.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 33), abbreviation of {%gotra-śailikā,%} a memorial pillar
<div n="lb">raised for the dead members of one's family.
<LEND>

<L>2049<pc>119<k1>gotrAntara<k2>gotr-Antara
{%gotr-āntara%}¦ (IE 8-2), the change of the wife's paternal {%gotra%}
<div n="lb">to that of her husband, which was absent in some popular forms
<div n="lb">of marriage in ancient India ({%Proc. IHC,%} Annamalainagar,
<div n="lb">1945, pp. 48 ff.).
<LEND>

<L>2050<pc>119<k1>gotraSElikA<k2>gotra-SElikA
{%gotra-śailikā%}¦ (EI 33), a pillar raised in memory of the
<div n="lb">dead members of one's family.
<LEND>

<L>2060<pc>119<k1>grAma<k2>grAma
{%grāma%}¦ (IE 8-4), ‘a village’; often suffixed to the names of
<div n="lb">localities.
[Page-120+ 40]
<div n="P">({%EI%} 24), a village assembly.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-4), sometimes used to indicate the number of villages
<div n="lb">in a territory or geographical unit; but the number was often
<div n="lb">either exaggerated or traditional without relation to reality;
<div n="lb">sometimes wrongly interpreted as ‘a unit of revenue assess-
<div n="lb">ment’. Cf. {%navanavati-sahasra-grāma-bhāj%} (IE 8-4), epithet of
<div n="lb">a territory. See Sircar, {%Stud. Geog. Anc. Med. Ind.,%} pp. 200 ff.
<div n="P">({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXV, pp. 146-47), a villager; same as
<div n="lb">{%Grāmeyaka.%}

<L>2558<pc>144<k1>kara<k2>kara
{%kara%}¦ (IE 8-5), explained by a commentator as ‘the dues
[Page-145+ 40]
<div n="lb">({%bhāga%}) to be realised by the king for the enjoyment of royal
<div n="lb">land by using it for cultivation and for grazing cattle’; tax in
<div n="lb">general.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-5) rent or tax to be paid in grains when mentioned
<div n="lb">side by side with {%hiraṇya.%}
<div n="P">({%HRS%}), tax in general, according to the lexicons; accord-
<div n="lb">ing to the {%Arthaśāstra,%} (1) periodical tax over and above the
<div n="lb">king's customary grain-share; (2) emergency tax levied upon
<div n="lb">the villagers over and above the normal grain-share; (3)
<div n="lb">tax upon merchants' profits.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 29; Chamba; CITD), a tax or impost; royal revenue;
<div n="lb">rent, dues; toll, tribute.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 7-1-2), ‘two’.
<LEND>

<L>2565<pc>145<k1>karaRa<k2>karaRa
{%Karaṇa%}¦ (EI 4), an accountant.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 28; HD), a clerk; a scribe. Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXII,
<div n="lb">p. 155.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 19), same as Marāṭhī {%Kulkarṇī.%}
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), a type of law-court lower in rank than an
<div n="lb">{%adhikaraṇa.%}
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-1, 8-8; EI 28, 30), same as or a shortened form of
<div n="lb">{%adhikaraṇa;%} a court of law.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3), an office or department.
<div n="P">({%CII%} 4), a committee.
<div n="P">({%LP%}), a department, according to the editors of the
<div n="lb">{%Lekhapaddhati,%} the thirtytwo {%karaṇas%} or departments being the
<div n="lb">following; {%śrī-karaṇa, vyaya-karaṇa, dharm-ādhikaraṇa, maṇḍapikā-%}
<div n="lb">{%karaṇa, velākula-karaṇa, jala-karaṇa, [sthala] patha-karaṇa, ghaṭi-%}
<div n="lb">{%kāgṛha-karaṇa, ṭaṅkaśālā-karaṇa, dravya-bhāṇdāra-karaṇa, aṃśuka-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhāṇdāra-karaṇa, vārigṛha-karaṇa, devaveśma-karaṇa, gaṇikā-karaṇa,%}
[Page-146+ 40]
<div n="lb">{%karaṇa, hastiśālā-karaṇa, aśvaśālā-karaṇa, kalabhaśālā-karaṇa, śreṇi-%}
<div n="lb">{%karaṇa, vyāpāra-karaṇa, tantra-karaṇa, koṣṭhāgāra-karaṇa, upakrama-%}
<div n="lb">{%karaṇa, karākara-karaṇa, sthāna-karaṇa, deva-karaṇa, sandhi [vigraha]-%}
<div n="lb">{%karaṇa, mahākṣapāla-karaṇa, mahārasa-karaṇa, jayanaśālā-karaṇa.,%}
<div n="lb">{%sattrāgāra-karaṇa, antaḥpura-[karaṇa]%} and {%koṣṭhikā-[karaṇa].%}
<div n="P">({%CII%} 3, 4), a document.
<div n="P">{%Cf. Karaṇam%} (SII 1; SITI), Tamil; also spelt {%Karṇam;%}
<div n="lb">a document; an accountant, also called {%Kaṇakka%}ṉ or {%Karaṇikka.%}
<div n="P">({%IA%} 17), name of the half of a {%tithi.%}
<LEND>

<div n="lb">be the carpenter, the blacksmith, the potter, the barber and
<div n="lb">the washerman.

<div n="lb">as {%kāru-deya.%}

<L>2644<pc>150<k1>kASu<k2>kASu
{%kāśu%}¦ (SII 1), Tamil; money; a coin; ‘a tax’; cf. {%kāśu-%}
<div n="lb">{%kaḍamai,%} tax payable in cash.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-8), name of a coin; sometimes called {%dīnāra%} (q. v.);
<div n="lb">cf. {%ūr-kāśu%} (EI 28), {%vīrapañcālaṅ-kāśu%} (SITI), {%sambiraṇippalaṅ-%}
<div n="lb">{%gāśu;%} also {%ī%}l13{%a-kkāśu%} (EI 28), ‘the Ceylonese coin’; {%śo%}l13{%iya-kkāśu%}
<div n="lb">(SITI), name of a copper coin believed to have been intro-
<div n="lb">duced by the Col13as; {%palaṅ-kāśu, nat-kāśa, nal-kāśu%} (SII 12);
<div n="lb">generally regarded as (1/100) of a {%paṇam;%} cf. {%triśūla-kāśu%} (SII 3).
<div n="P">{%Cf. āśuva-kkāśu%} (SITI), or {%ājīvaka-kāśu,%} tax payable by the
<div n="lb">Ājīvakas.
<div n="P">{%Cf. aḍimai-kkāśu%} (SITI), fees collected from the temple
[Page-151+ 40]
<div n="lb">servants; also {%adi-kkāśu,%} tax collected from stall-keepers in the
<div n="lb">markets.
<div n="P">{%Cf. uppu-kkāśu%} (SITI), salt-tax.
<div n="P">{%Cf. vagainda-kāśu%} (SITI), tax payable in cash for marking
<div n="lb">details of land, etc.; fees for the division of land; also the fee
<div n="lb">for settlement of a dispute, etc.
<div n="P">Cf. {%veli-kkāśu, veli-ppaya%}ṟ{%u%} (SITI), Tamil; tax payable in
<div n="lb">cash, the exact nature of which is not clear. Cf. {%veli-kku%}l13{??}-
<div n="lb">{%ppaṇam.%}
<div n="P">{%Cf. inavari-kkāśu%} (SITI), communal tax payable in coin;
<div n="lb">cf. {%jāti-siddh-āya%} of Telugu inscriptions.
<div n="P">({%SITI%}), Tamil; a measure of weight equal to (1/4) {%palam.%}
<LEND>

<L>2682<pc>153<k1>kendra<k2>kendra
{%kendra%}¦ (IE 7-1-2), ‘four’.
<div n="P">({%CII%} 3), anomaly of the moon, taken to be her distance
<div n="lb">from apogee, from which point it is always reckoned by Hindu
<div n="lb">astronomers; the annual variation in the moon's {%kendra%} is 3
<div n="lb">signs 2 degrees and 6.2 minutes, or 7 {%tithis%} 9 {%ghaṭīs%} and 42
<div n="lb">{%palas.%} See also {%nīcocca-māsa, tithi-kendra, tithi-madhyama-kendra%}
<div n="lb">and {%tithi-spaṣṭa-kendra.%}

<L>2699<pc>154<k1>Kajjana<k2>Kajjana, KajjaRa, KajjAna, KajjaRaka
{%khajjana, khajjaṇa, khajjāna, khajjaṇaka%}¦ (IE 8-8; EI 33),
<div n="lb">same as Marāṭhī and Koṅkaṇī {%khājaṇ;%} an area near the
<div n="lb">sea shore, on which a thin layer of sand accumulates after
<div n="lb">the ebbtide coming through inlets; a rice field created out of
<div n="lb">such an area near a hillock by erecting embankments on the
<div n="lb">three other sides; a field created by reclaiming a river bed;
<div n="lb">cultivable land created from the bed of a river which carries
<div n="lb">the flood-water from the sea; a salty marsh or meadow; a
<div n="lb">rice field created near the bed of a nullah on the sea shore
<div n="lb">by putting embankments. See {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXIII, pp.
<div n="lb">53-54. It is sometimes called {%pukkoli-khajjana, pukkoli%} probably
<div n="lb">meaning a similar kind of land.
<LEND>

<L>2700<pc>154<k1>Kala<k2>Kala

<L>2770<pc>158<k1>kIrti<k2>kIrti
{%kīrti%}¦ (EI 20, 24; CII 3, 4), literally, ‘the thing that
<div n="lb">speaks of or glorifies one’; used in the special meaning of ‘any
<div n="lb">work which renders the constructor of it famous’; a merit-
<div n="lb">orious work; a pious deed; same as {%kīrtana, kīrtanā;%} often inter-
<div n="lb">preted as ‘a building or temple’; but actually, ‘any fame-
<div n="lb">producing work’. See {%kīrti-sthāna.%}
<div n="P">(CII 1), fame of a dead person; cf. {%yaśo vā kīrtir = vā.%}

<L>2856<pc>162<k1>kfta<k2>kfta
{%kṛta%}¦ (EI 12, 14, 23; BL; CII 3), literally ‘accomplished’.
<div n="lb">i. e. ‘completed’; used in earlier records in connection with the
<div n="lb">era later associated with Vikramāditya. Often spelt
<div n="lb">{%krita,%} possibly standing for {%krīta%} meaning ‘purschased’, which
<div n="lb">was a name sometimes applied to certain foreign rulers of
<div n="lb">North-Western Bhāratavarṣa ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXIII, p.
<div n="lb">152).
<div n="P">({%IE%} 7-1-2), ‘four’.
<div n="P">({%CII%} 1), ‘arranged for’, ‘made arrangements for’.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 23), fruit, booty, reward.
<div n="P">({%Sel. Ins.,%} p. 202), ‘engraved’.
<div n="P">({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXIV, p. 41, verse 13), written, drafted or
<div n="lb">composed.
<LEND>

<L>2869<pc>163<k1>kzattf<k2>kzattf
{%Kṣattṛ%}¦ (HD), a chamberlain. See {%Hist. Dharm.,%} Vol.
<div n="lb">III, p. 111. According to Manu (X. 16) and Yājñavalkya
<div n="lb">(I. 94), the offspring of a Kṣatriya woman from a Śūdra male
<div n="lb">was called {%Kṣattṛ.%} This apparently refers to a tribe or community.

<L>2909<pc>165<k1>kulika<k2>kulika
{%Kulika%}¦ (EI 15, 35), ‘the head of a guild’; but
<div n="lb">cf. {%Prathama-kulika,%} ‘the foremost among the Kulikas’, who
<div n="lb">was the member of a board of administration like the {%Pañcāyat%}
<div n="lb">Board. Some inscriptions of the Gupta age mention a board
<div n="lb">of administration consisting of the {%Nagara-śreṣṭhin Sārthavāha,%}
<div n="lb">{%Prathama-Kulika%} and {%Prathama-Kāyastha%} ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XV,
<div n="lb">p. 130), where {%Kulika%} seems to mean ‘an artisan’. {%Kulika%}
<div n="lb">is also mentioned as a people probably meaning mercenary
<div n="lb">soldiers of the Kullu valley (ibid., Vol. XVII, p. 321); cf.
<div n="lb">Vogel, {%Ant. Ch. St.,%} pp. 126-27.
<div n="P">({%HD%}), an officer in charge of ten villages who was granted
<div n="lb">a {%kula%} of land for his salary (Manu, VII. 119, and Kullūka
<div n="lb">thereon); also ‘an arbitrator as a tribunal’ ({%IHQ,%} Vol. XIX, p. 14).
<LEND>

<L>2918<pc>166<k1>kumAragadyARa<k2>kumAra-gadyARa
{%kumāra-gadyāṇa%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 4; HRS), probably, a tax
<div n="lb">of one {%gadyāṇa%} (i. e. the coin of that name) payable on the
<div n="lb">occasion of a prince's birth. See {%kumāra-gadiāṇaka, komarina-%}
<div n="lb">{%gadyāṇa,%} etc. Cf. Tamil {%kumara-kaccāṇam%} (EI 21), supposed to
<div n="lb">be a tax payable in coin for the maintenance of the temple of
<div n="lb">Kumāra or Subrahmaṇya (SITI). But {%kumāra-gadyāṇa%} is found in
<div n="lb">the records of the Gāhaḍavālas of Vārāṇasī, in whose dominions
<div n="lb">the god in question was not as popular as in the South.
<LEND>

<L>2922<pc>166<k1>kumArAmAtya<k2>kumAr-AmAtya
{%Kumār-āmātya%}¦ (IE 8-3; CII 3, 4; BL; HD), probably
<div n="lb">‘an {%Amātya%} enjoying the status of a {%Kumāra%}’. Cf. Tamil
<div n="lb">{%piḻḻaigaḻ-tanam%} (SITI), ‘the status of a {%Piḻḻai%} (prince)’, an
<div n="lb">officers’ cadre mainly composed of the junior members of
<div n="lb">the royal family. See {%Proc. 6th AIOC,%} pp. 211 ff.; Vogel,
<div n="lb">{%Ant. Ch. St.,%} p. 123.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3), in one case, a {%Kumār-āmātya%} was at first a
<div n="lb">{%Mantrin,%} but later became a {%Mahābalādhikṛta;%} in another case,
<div n="lb">a {%Kumārāmātya%} was also a {%Mantrin.%} Cf. {%Kumāra-mahāpātra,%} etc.
<div n="P">{%Cf. Kumāra-varga=piḻḻaigaḻ-tanam%} (SITI), literally, ‘the
<div n="lb">status of the {%Piḻḻai%} or prince’; supposed to be an officers’ cadre
<div n="lb">composed mainly of the junior members of the royal family.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3), also called {%Khādya(kū*)ṭapākika, Sāndhivigrahika,%}
<div n="lb">{%Mahādaṇdanāyaka,%} etc., additionally.
<LEND>

<L>3039<pc>172<k1>lokapAla<k2>lokapAla
{%Lokapāla%}¦ (CII 3, etc.), a guardian of one of the quarters
<div n="lb">of the world, originally conceived as four in number and later
<div n="lb">as eight.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 15), cf. the king called ‘the fifth {%Lokapāla%}’, the four
<div n="lb">{%Lokapālas%} (guardians of the four quarters) being originally
<div n="lb">Yama of the south, Varuṇa of the west, Kubera of the north
<div n="lb">and Vāsava of the east. In the same sense, the king was
<div n="lb">also called {%madhyama-loka-pāla,%} though {%madhyama-loka%} may
<div n="lb">also mean ‘the earth’ standing midway between the heavens
<div n="lb">and the netherworld. See {%Suc. Sāt.,%} pp. 196, 202; {%Ep. Ind.,%}
<div n="lb">Vol. XXXII, p. 93. Cf. {%Pañcama-lokapāla.%}
<LEND>

[Page-173+ 40]
<div n="lb">{%māḍa, gaṇḍa-māḍa, kulottuṅga-māḍa%} (EI 29), {%gandhavāraṇamāḍa%} (or
<div n="lb">{%gandhahasti-māḍa%}), {%cāmara-māḍa, uttama-gaṇḍamāḍa, padmanidhi-%}
<div n="lb">{%malla-māḍa, rājarāja-māḍa, rājendraco%}l13{%a-māḍa,%} etc. The {%gaṇḍa-māḍa%}
<div n="lb">is sometimes called {%kārṣāpaṇa, niṣka%} and {%gaṇḍaniṣka%} and is also
<div n="lb">characterised in a few cases with the epithet ‘small’. See
<div n="lb">{%māḍai, māḍha.%} Note names like {%kulottuṅga-māḍa,%} a coin issued by
<div n="lb">the Col13a king Kulottuṅga. See {%JNSI,%} Vol. XVI, p. 43.
<div n="P">({%CITD%}), Telugu; half a {%pagoda;%} half of a {%dīnār%} or the
<div n="lb">tenth of a {%paṇa%} (cf. {%badi-māḍuvulu%}); half or 50 per cent of
<div n="lb">revenue, etc.; a weight of gold; money in general. Four
<div n="lb">{%māḍas%} are equal to one {%carṣam (karṣa?).%}
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-5), probably, payment of 50 per cent; see {%māḍalu.%}
<LEND>

<L>3043<pc>173<k1>mAqabaqipAtuka<k2>mAqa-baqi-pAtuka
{%māḍa-baḍi-pātuka%}¦ (CITD), Telugu; an unknown coin
<div n="lb">with a fraction of the value of a {%māḍa. Baḍi%} means ‘petty’ and
<div n="lb">{%pātika%} ‘a quarter’.

<div n="lb">See {%Kārtākṛtika.%}
