<L>3155<pc>179<k1>mahAmaRqaleSvara<k2>mahAmaRqaleSvara
{%Mahāmaṇḍaleśvara%}¦ (IE 8-2; EI 30; CII 4; HD; BL;
<div n="lb">SITI; CITD), according to the lexicons, a sovereign ruler
[Page-180+ 40]
<div n="lb">who is the lord of 40 {%yojanas%} of land and a lakh of villages; but,
<div n="lb">in inscriptions, generally, the governor of a district or pro-
<div n="lb">vince; title of a feudatory ruler or governor (see {%Bomb. Gaz.,%}
<div n="lb">Vol. XXI, p. 354); see {%Maṇḍaleśvara%} essentially meaning ‘the
<div n="lb">ruler of a {%maṇḍala%} or district’; also called {%Mahāmaṇḍalika,%} etc.,
<div n="lb">cf. {%Mahāmaṇḍaleśvar-ādhipati.%} The status of a {%Mahāmaṇdal-%}
<div n="lb">{%eśvara%} seems to have been superior to that of a {%Maṇḍaleśvara,%}
<div n="lb">while {%Mahāmaṇḍaleśvarādhipati%} apparently enjoyed a still higher
<div n="lb">rank.
<LEND>

<L>3156<pc>180<k1>mahAmaRqaleSvarADipati<k2>mahAmaRqaleSvar-ADipati
{%Mahāmaṇḍaleśvar-ādhipati%}¦ (IE 8-2; EI 23), title of a
<div n="lb">feudatory higher in rank than a {%Mahāmaṇḍaleśvara%} (cf. {%Mahā-%}
<div n="lb">{%sāmantādhipati%}); a feudatory who had some subordinate chiefs
<div n="lb">under him; cf. {%Mahāmaṇḍaleśvara, Maṇḍaleśvara.%}

<L>3162<pc>180<k1>mahAmAtra<k2>mahAmAtra
{%Mahāmātra%}¦ (IE 8-3), cf. Prakrit {%Mahāmāta%} (EI 3); a high
<div n="lb">executive officer employed in various capacities; cf. {%Nagara-%}
<div n="lb">{%vyavahārika-mahāmātra, Stryadhyakṣa-mahāmātra, Dharma-mahāmātra,%}
<div n="lb">etc.; adopted in Greek as {%Mamātrai.%} See {%CII,%} Vol. I, p. 92,
<div n="lb">etc.; {%Arthaśāstra,%} I. 12, V. 1; etc.; {%Kāmasūtra,%} V. 5. 17. 33 and
<div n="lb">35. The word {%Mahāmātra%} in Manu, IX. 259, is explained by
<div n="lb">Medhātithi as ‘the {%Mantrin, Purohita%} and others’ and by Kullūka
<div n="lb">as meaning ‘the professional tamers of elephants’. (SITI)
<div n="lb">explained as ‘a senior minister.’ See {%Mātra%} in a similar sense.
<div n="P">{%Cf. Antaḥpura-mahāmātra%} in the Masulipatnam plates of
<div n="lb">Amma II ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXIV, p. 276).

<L>3222<pc>184<k1>mahArAja<k2>mahArAja
{%Mahārāja%}¦ (IE 8-2; EI 30; CII 3, 4; HD), royal title
<div n="lb">first assumed by the foreign rulers of India and later adopted by
<div n="lb">indigenous rulers; originally, an imperial title; later (when the
<div n="lb">emperors assumed more dignified titles), a title of feudatories
<div n="lb">and smaller rulers; cf. Greek {%Basileos Megalou%} and Old Persian
<div n="lb">{%Kshāyathiya vazrka.%} Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. IV, p. 211.
[Page-185+ 40]
<div n="P">(IE 8-2), one of the designations sometimes included in
<div n="lb">the {%pañca-mahāśabda;%} cf. the case of Maitraka Dhruvasena I.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3), sometimes also called {%Mahāsāmanta, Mahāpratīhāra,%}
<div n="lb">{%Mahāpīlupati, Pañcādhikaraṇ-oparika, Pāṭy-uparika, Purapāl-oparika,%}
<div n="lb">etc., additionally.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-2), often used in the South even when {%Mahārājā-%}
<div n="lb">{%dhirāja%} became the popular imperial title in the North.
<div n="P">({%ASLV%}), designation of a priest of the members of the
<div n="lb">Vallabhācārya sect. Cf. {%Mahanta-mahārāja,%} title of pontiffs.

<div n="lb">Vol. IX, p. 107.

<div n="lb">literally, ‘an elder [of a town or village]’; according to Stein
<div n="lb">({%Rājataraṅgiṇī,%} VII. 659); a chamberlain, a village headman

<div n="lb">council; cf. Hindī {%Mahato;%} Gujaratī {%Mahetā.%} Cf. {%Ind. Ant.,%}
<div n="lb">Vol. VI, p. 114 {%(rāṣṭra-grāma-mahattara); Daśakumāracarita,%} III,
<div n="lb">p. 77 ({%janapada-mahattara%}).

<div n="lb">administrative board of the {%aṣṭakula%} headed by the {%Mahattara%}’;
<div n="lb">see {%Mahattara%} and {%aṣṭakul-ādhikaraṇa.%}

<div n="lb">was smaller than the {%vīthī%} or subdivision.

<div n="lb">to indicate a country.

<div n="lb">or {%deśa.%} Here {%maṇḍala%} means a kingdom or territory.

<L>3401<pc>195<k1>maRqapa<k2>maRqapa
{%maṇḍapa%}¦ (IE 8-3), customs house; Marāṭhī {%māṇḍavī,%} from
<div n="lb">Sanskrit {%maṇḍapikā;%} explained by some as ‘a market place’
[Page-196+ 40]
<div n="lb">(Hindī {%maṇḍī%}); but Hindī {%maṇḍī%} seems to be derived from the
<div n="lb">same word because the toll-stations were often situated in market-
<div n="lb">places.
<div n="P">({%BL%}), name of a structure in front of a temple.
<div n="P">({%LL%}), a porch or hall.
<div n="P">({%CII%} 4), the hall in a temple.
<div n="P">({%CII%} 4), a temple.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 31), a temple or public building.
<div n="P">{%Cf. vaiccamudu-maṇḍapa%} (SITI), kitchen; same as {%maḍaip-%}
<div n="lb">{%paḻḻi.%}
<div n="P">{%Cf. vakkāṇikku-maṇḍapa%} (SITI), hall where disputations
<div n="lb">in the {%śāstras%} are held. Cf. {%śanivāra-maṇḍapa.%}
<LEND>

<L>3402<pc>196<k1>maRqapikA<k2>maRqapikA
{%maṇḍapikā%}¦ (EI 1, 3, 33), customs house; same as {%śulka-%}
<div n="lb">{%maṇḍapikā%} ({%Ind. Ant.,%} Vol. XI, p. 339 and note 31). See
<div n="lb">Ghoshal, {%H. Rev. Syst.,%} pp. 238-39.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 3; CII 4); market; a market pavilion.

<L>3638<pc>208<k1>nagara<k2>nagara
{%nagara%}¦ (IE 8-4), city; palace; cf. {%navara.%}
<div n="P">({%EI%} 21; SITI), a commercial guild; guild of merchants;
<div n="lb">a mercantile town; often spelt in Kannaḍa inscriptions as {%nakara%}
<div n="lb">or {%nakhara;%} cf. {%pañca-nagara.%}
<div n="P">({%CITD%}), in Telugu inscriptions, a territorial assembly
<div n="lb">like the {%sabhā%} and {%ūr;%} the merchant community in general or
<div n="lb">the organization of the merchant community of a town. In
<div n="lb">some places, the {%nagara%} and {%ūr%} carried on their functions side
<div n="lb">by side. The word is sometimes used to indicate occupational
<div n="lb">groups like {%śāleyanagarattom.%} Cf. K. A. Nilakanta Sastri,
<div n="lb">{%The Co%}l13{%as,%} Vol. II, 1st ed., p. 294.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 4), same as Kaliṅga-nagara. Cf. {%śrī-Nagara-bhukti=%}
<div n="lb">{%Pāṭaliputra-bhukti%} ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XVII, p. 311).
<div n="P">({%IA%} 17), represented in Prakrit by {%nera%} further corrupted
<div n="lb">to {%ner%} or {%nar.%} See {%nagarī.%}
<LEND>

<L>3671<pc>210<k1>nala<k2>nala
{%nala%}¦ (IE 8-6), measuring rod; same as {%daṇḍa;%} sometimes
<div n="lb">regarded as 12 cubits, 22 cubits, 56 cubits, etc., in length; cf.
<div n="lb">{%Samataṭīya-nala,%} ‘the rod as used in the Samataṭa country’;
<div n="lb">{%Vṛṣabhaśaṅkara-nala,%} ‘the rod introduced by king Vṛṣabha-
<div n="lb">śaṅkara’, ‘the rod of the village of Pattiyamattavura’, etc.
<div n="lb">See {%kol, kolu, ghaḻe,%} etc.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-6), cf. {%aṣṭaka-navaka-nala, ṣaṭka-nala,%} etc., the first
<div n="lb">probably referring to the custom of measuring the length and
<div n="lb">breadth of a plot of land by rods of different length.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 28), used in some Orissan inscriptions in the sense of
<div n="lb">measurement of the area [of the gift land] ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol.
<div n="lb">XXXI, p. 20).
<div n="P">({%EI%} 21), a measure.

{%ni%}¦ (IE 8-1; EI 33), abbreviation of {%nibaddha%} or {%nirīkṣita,%}
<div n="lb">i. e. registered or approved.
<div n="P">({%Select Inscriptions,%} pp. 238-39, 247-48), explained as an
<div n="lb">abbreviation of {%nija%} and as a sort of genitive suffix often with a
<div n="lb">word indicating relationship understood.
<LEND>

<L>3758<pc>215<k1>nI<k2>nI
{%nī%}¦ (LP), used for the verb {%ānī.%}
<div n="P">({%LP%}), to make.
<LEND>

<L>3759<pc>215<k1>nibadDa<k2>nibadDa
{%nibaddha%}¦ (IE 8-1; EI 29), explained as ‘registered’.
<div n="P">({%IA%} 13), used in respect of a copper-plate grant and trans-
<div n="lb">lated as ‘prepared’.
<div n="P">({%IA%} 15), interpreted as ‘assigned’.
<LEND>

{%nibandh%}¦ ({%Select Inscriptions,%} p. 202), to register.

<div n="P">({%SII%} 2), also spelt {%nivanda%} or {%nimanda%} in Tamil; the fixed
<div n="lb">requirements of a temple; cf. {%Nivandakkārar,%} temple servants

<div n="lb">the same point again; its duration is 27 days, 33 {%ghaṭīs%}

<L>3768<pc>216<k1>niDi<k2>niDi

<L>3909<pc>224<k1>pAdAnuDyAnarata<k2>pAd-AnuDyAna-rata

<L>3910<pc>224<k1>pAdAnuDyAta<k2>pAd-AnuDyAta
{%Pād-ānudhyāta%}¦ (IE 8-2; EI 2; CII 3), ‘meditating on the
<div n="lb">feet or favoured by the feet of … ’, a technical expression for
<div n="lb">the relations of a feudatory to his paramount sovereign, of a
<div n="lb">subordinate to a chief, of a successor to his predecessor, of a son
<div n="lb">to his parents, of a nephew to his uncle, of a grandson to his
<div n="lb">grandfather, and of a younger to his elder brother; used also in
<div n="lb">respect of gods. In rare cases, the word {%pāda%} is omitted. Cf
<div n="lb">{%Pāda-bhakta%} and {%Pād-ānudhyāna-rata.%}
<LEND>

<L>3911<pc>224<k1>pAdapadmopajIvin<k2>pAda-padm-opajIvin
{%Pāda-padm-opajīvin%}¦ (CII 3; IA 18), ‘subsisting [like a bee]
<div n="lb">on the lotuses that are the feet of … ’; a technical expression
<div n="lb">(often occurring in medieval South Indian inscriptions) for the
<div n="lb">relations of a feudatory or officer to his master; cf. {%Pāda-piṇḍ-%}
<div n="lb">{%opajīvin, Pād-opajīvin.%}
<LEND>

<L>3912<pc>224<k1>pAdapASa<k2>pAda-pASa
{%pāda-pāśa%}¦ (SITI), name of a foot-ornament.

<L>3913<pc>224<k1>pAdapiRqopajIvin<k2>pAda-piRq-opajIvin
{%Pāda-piṇḍ-opajīvin%}¦ (CII 3, etc.), ‘subsisting on the food
<div n="lb">supplied by the feet of … ’; a technical expression to denote
<div n="lb">the relationship of officials or subordinates to their master;

<L>3941<pc>225<k1>padra<k2>padra

<L>3942<pc>226<k1>padraka<k2>padraka

<div n="lb">as the termination of the name of a village; interpreted as ‘com-
<div n="lb">mon-land’ in expressions like {%Bhumbhusa-padraka%} and {%Śivaka-%}
<div n="lb">{%padraka.%} Wilson's Glossary explains {%pādar%} (i. e. {%padra%}) as
<div n="lb">‘common-land, land adjacent to a village left uncultivated’.

<L>3951<pc>226<k1>pagod<k2>pagod, pagoda
{%pagod, pagoda%}¦ (EI 8-8), also called ‘star pagoda’; English
<div n="lb">name of the gold coin called {%hūn (hon)%} or {%varāha;%} probably so
<div n="lb">called because the coins often bore the representation of a
<div n="lb">temple called {%pagod%} or {%pagoda%} by the early European travellers.
<div n="lb">The word seems to have been derived from Sanskrit {%bhagavat%} or
<div n="lb">{%bhagavatī%} meaning the deities worshipped in the temples and
<div n="lb">also often figuring on the coins. Cf. ‘{%ṭaṅkakas%} stamped with the
<div n="lb">figure of the {%Bhagavat%}’ (Bhandarkar's List, No. 2033).
<div n="P">{%Cf. Cīna-pagoda%} (SII 12), ‘the Chinese temple’; name of
<div n="lb">a Buddhist shrine at Nāgapaṭṭanam.
<LEND>

<L>3952<pc>226<k1>pAhuqa<k2>pAhuqa
{%pāhuḍa,%}¦ Sanskrit {%prābhṛta;%} cf. {%pāhuḍa-pramāṇena%} (LP), ‘in
<div n="lb">proportion to the gift given by him’.
<LEND>

<L>3990<pc>228<k1>paRa<k2>paRa
{%paṇa%}¦ (IE 8-8; EI 23, 24, 30; SII 11-1), same as Tamil
<div n="lb">{%paṇam,%} spelt in English as {%fanam;%} cf. {%Yādavarāyan-paṇam%} (SITI),
<div n="lb">name of a coin issued by the Yādavarāyas; name of a coin
<div n="lb">80 ratis in weight; same as the copper {%kārsāpaṇa;%} equal to 80
<div n="lb">cowrie-shells according to the {%Līlāvatī;%} copper coin (1/16) of a
<div n="lb">silver {%kārṣāpaṇa%} according to the {%Kṛtyakalpataru%} (Vyavahāra-
<div n="lb">kāṇḍa, ed. K.V. Rangaswami Aiyangar, p. 125), and (1/48) of a
[Page-229+ 40]
<div n="lb">{%suvarṇa%} ({%JNSI,%} Vol. II, p. 7); also used to indicate ‘money’.
<div n="lb">In Tamil, {%paṇam%} means a particular coin (usually, a small gold
<div n="lb">coin), or money in general, or taxes; cf. {%paṇa-vargam%} (SITI), a
<div n="lb">class of taxes payable in cash, same as {%kāśāya-vargam;%} also {%paṇa-%}
<div n="lb">{%vāśi,%} ‘discount payable for the exchange of coins; amount pay-
<div n="lb">able to make up the wear in the coin’. Cf. {%vil-paṇam%} (SITI),
<div n="lb">sale-tax; also understood as a tax on bows or archery; {%vāśal-%}
<div n="lb">{%paṇam%} (SITI), door-tax or periodical payment due to the
<div n="lb">palace.
<div n="P">({%ASLV%}), a sect or caste, eighteen in number theoretically.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 19), a land measure.
<LEND>

<L>4007<pc>230<k1>paYcakarmAra<k2>paYca-karmAra

<div n="lb">castes of artisans, viz., goldsmith, blacksmith, brassmith, car-
<div n="lb">penter and stone-mason.

<L>4009<pc>230<k1>paYcakula<k2>paYcakula
{%pañcakula%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 5, 25; CII 4; LP; HRS), the {%Pañ-%}
<div n="lb">{%cāyat%} Board; an assembly of administrators and arbitrators,
<div n="lb">usually consisting of five members; a board of administration
<div n="lb">charged with control of the customs house, with the deposit of
<div n="lb">property of persons dying without heirs into the royal treasury,
<div n="lb">etc.; also called {%pañcapa%} (EI 4); members of such a board; ac-
<div n="lb">cording to some, an officer over a certain number of villages
<div n="lb">(HD). Cf. {%Ind. Ant.,%} Vol. XI, p. 242. Cf. {%Pañcavīra, Pāñca-%}
<div n="lb">{%kulika, añjaṣṭa-sabhā,%} etc.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">or {%Pañcāyat%} board; cf. {%Caturjātakīya.%}

<L>4018<pc>230<k1>paYcamahApAtaka<k2>paYca-mahApAtaka
{%pañca-mahāpātaka%}¦ (EI 26; CII 3; CITD), the five great
<div n="lb">sins or heinous crimes, viz., killing a Brāhmaṇa, drinking intoxi-
<div n="lb">cating liquors, stealing gold, committing adultery with the
<div n="lb">wife of a {%guru%} and associating with any one guilty of these
<div n="lb">crimes. Cf. {%daś-āparādha, pañc-ānantarya.%}
<LEND>

<L>4019<pc>230<k1>paYcamahASabda<k2>paYca-mahASabda
{%pañca-mahāśabda%}¦ (IE 8-2; EI 30; CII 3, 4; SITI; CITD;
<div n="lb">BL), refers to the privilege of enjoying the sounds of five
<div n="lb">musical instruments, or five titles beginning with {%mahat;%} five
<div n="lb">official designations or musical instruments mentioned in con-
<div n="lb">nection with feudatories; five official designations beginning
<div n="lb">with the word {%mahā%} in the North and five kinds of musical
<div n="lb">instruments in the South; in South India, it was the same as
<div n="lb">{%pañca-mahānināda,%} i. e. the sounds of the five great musical ins-
<div n="lb">truments called the {%pañca-mahāvādya%} enumerated by some as a
[Page-231+ 40]
<div n="lb">horn, a tabor, a conch-shell, a kettle-drum and a gong; in
<div n="lb">some parts of North India, the expression indicated five
<div n="lb">official designations with the prefix {%mahā.%}
<div n="P">({%CII%} 3), sounds of five musical instruments, the use of
<div n="lb">which was allowed to persons of high rank and authority;
<div n="lb">usually a title of feudatories; cf. {%tat-pradatta-pañcamahāśabda%} (IE
<div n="lb">8-2), used in respect of feudatory rulers who received the right
<div n="lb">of enjoying the {%pañca-mahāśabda%} from their overlords; rarely
<div n="lb">used in the South by independent monarchs. Cf. {%pañca-vādya%} (EI
<div n="lb">4) and {%pañca-mahāvādya.%} See {%Samadhigata-pañcamahāśabda,%} etc.
<div n="P">{%Cf. pañca-māśattam%} (SITI), the five musical instruments,
<div n="lb">to the use of which a nobleman was entitled; sometimes enu-
<div n="lb">merated as {%ceṇḍai, timilai, śegaṇḍi,%} cymbals and {%kāhaḻam%} or as
<div n="lb">{%tattaḻi, maddaḻi, karaḻikai,%} cymbals and {%kāhaḻam.%}
<div n="P">({%SII%} 11-1), cf. grant of 40 {%mattars%} of land to a piper for
<div n="lb">arranging to play the five musical instruments.
<LEND>

<L>4020<pc>231<k1>paYcamahAvAdya<k2>paYca-mahAvAdya
{%pañca-mahāvādya%}¦ (EI 12), enumerated as the horn, conch-
<div n="lb">shell, tambourine, trumpet and gong. See {%pañca-mahāśabda.%}
<LEND>

<L>4021<pc>231<k1>paYcamahAyajYa<k2>paYca-mahAyajYa

{%pannasa,%}¦ also spelt {%pannāsa, pannāsu%} (IE 8-6; EI 5, 12; {%Ep.%}
<div n="lb">{%Ind.,%} Vol. XV, p. 336, note 3), Kannaḍa; probably derived from
<div n="lb">Sanskrit {%pañchāśat%} in the sense of a tenure in which the donee
<div n="lb">enjoyed fifty per cent of the revenue of the donated land. Cf.
<div n="lb">{%pannavīsa.%} ({%EI%} 20), explained as ‘a gift’.
<LEND>

<L>4080<pc>234<k1>pannAsa<k2>pannAsa
{%pannāsa%}¦ (EI 30; IA 11), Kannaḍa; same as {%pannasa%} (q. v.).

<div n="lb">twentyfive per cent of the revenue of the donated land. Cf.

<L>4160<pc>238<k1>parihAra<k2>parihAra
{%parihāra%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 6; SITI), same as {%maryādā-parihāra;%}
[Page-239+ 40]
<div n="lb">exemptions from taxes and obligations granted to the donees of
<div n="lb">rent-free land; privileges of the donee of rent-free holdings; for
<div n="lb">many such privileges, see Appendix I. Cf. certain privileges
<div n="lb">in respect of a number of taxes and obligations enumerated in
<div n="lb">Tamil records as follows: {%vaṭṭi-nāḻi%} (payment of one {%nāḻi%} per
<div n="lb">{%vaṭṭi%}), {%pudā-nāḻi%} (or {%pidāº,%} cess on each door or tax for the main-
<div n="lb">tenance of sluices), {%maṇṟupādu%} (fine imposed by a court of law),
<div n="lb">{%ūrāṭci%} (tax for running the village administration), {%taragu%} (tax
<div n="lb">on brokers), {%kūlam%} (tax on grains), {%ī%}l13{%am-puṭi%} (tax on toddy-
<div n="lb">drawers), {%nāḍu-kāval%} (tax for the policing of a district), {%ūḍupokku%}
<div n="lb">(meaning uncertain), {%uppu-kocceygai%} (tax for the manufacture of
<div n="lb">salt), {%nall-ā%} (tax for maintaining specimen cows), {%nallerudu%} (tax
<div n="lb">for maintaining specimen buffaloes), {%nerv-āypuvum%} (meaning un-
<div n="lb">certain) and others. See {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XVIII, p. 124.
<div n="P">({%IA%} 17), a ring.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">gested by the {%Arthaśāstra;%} privileges enjoyed by the donee
<div n="lb">of a rent-free holding.

<div n="lb">minor taxes; cf. {%sa-parikara%} (EI 23) which is the same as {%s-opari-%}
<div n="lb">{%kara.%}

<L>4417<pc>253<k1>prabanDa<k2>prabanDa
{%prabandha,%}¦ name of hymnal compositions in Tamil by
<div n="lb">ancient Vaiṣṇava devotees. The contributions of hymns and
<div n="lb">prayers by the twelve {%ā%}l13{%vārs%} in praise of Viṣṇu make up the
<div n="lb">{%Nālāyiradivyaprabandham. Nālāyira%} (four thousand) indicates the
<div n="lb">rough total number of items and {%prabandham%} is regarded as mean-
<div n="lb">ing a compilation. The first thousand is known as {%Tirumo%}l13{%i%} and
<div n="lb">comprises hymns of Periyāl13vār, Āṇḍāl, Kulaśekhara, etc.; the
<div n="lb">second thousand contains the hymns of Tirumaṅgai; the third
<div n="lb">comprises the compositions of the first three {%ā%}l13{%vārs%} called
<div n="lb">{%Iya%}ṟ{%pā,%} viz. Tirumal13iśai, Nammāl13var and Tirumaṅgai, and the
<div n="lb">fourth called {%Tiruvāymo%}l13{%i%} is entirely the work of Nammāl13vār.
<div n="lb">Nāthamunigal13 is stated to be the compiler of this anthology.
<div n="lb">See M. S. Purnalingam Pillai, {%Tamil Literature,%} pp. 181 ff.
<LEND>

{%prabarha%}¦ (EI 13), a worthy.

<L>4458<pc>255<k1>prakfti<k2>prakfti
{%prakṛti%}¦ (HD); cf. {%Mahābhārata,%} II. v. 23, speaking of
<div n="lb">the seven {%prakṛtis%} which Nīlakaṇṭha explains as referring to
<div n="lb">{%Durg-ādhyakṣa%} (commandant of the citadel), {%Bal-ādhyakṣa%} (con-
<div n="lb">troller general of the army), {%Dharma-ādhyakṣa%} (chief of the
<div n="lb">departments of charity and justice), {%Camūpati%} (commander of
<div n="lb">the army in the field), chaplain, physician and astrologer. The
<div n="lb">{%Milindapañha%} (IV. i. 36) mentions six officers, e.g., the com-
<div n="lb">mander-in-chief, prime minister, chief judge, chief treasurer,
<div n="lb">bearer of the sun-shade and bearer of the sword of state (cf. {%Ep.%}
<div n="lb">{%Ind.,%} Vol. XV, p. 77, note 6). Cf. {%Mātra.%}
<div n="P">({%EI%} 16), a temple official.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 7-1-2), ‘twentyone.’
<div n="P">({%EI%} 9), the Kṣatriya community.
<div n="P">{%Cf. sa-tantuvāya-gokuṭa-śauṇḍik-ādi-prakṛtika%} (IE 8-5);
<div n="lb">subjects of a king.
<div n="P">({%CII%} 1), usage.

<div n="lb">(EI 3, 23), ‘a door-keeper’; but cf. {%Mahāpratihāra%} who was a
<div n="lb">high officer; officer in charge of the defence of the royal palace
<div n="lb">or bed-chamber or the head of the guards of the city gate; a
<div n="lb">chamberlain or inditer of grants, according to some (HD);

<div n="lb">{%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. VIII, p. 73; Vol. IX, p. 192; Bṛhaspati quoted by

<div n="lb">known from the Gāhaḍavāla records; a minor tax other than
<div n="lb">what was {%bhāga-bhoga-kara,%} according to some; explained by
<div n="lb">some as a tax levied from a class of merchants. See {%pravaṇivāda.%}
<div n="P">({%IA%} 15), explained as {%hiraṇya%} or tax in cash.
<LEND>

<L>4659<pc>266<k1>pUrRimAnta<k2>pUrRimAnta
{%pūrṇimānta%}¦ (CII 3, etc.), the technical name for the scheme
<div n="lb">of the lunar months in Northern India, according to which
<div n="lb">the months end with the full-moon day, and the dark fortnights
<div n="lb">precede the bright; Fleet states that in astronomical works, it
<div n="lb">is always the {%amānta%} arrangement that is actually taken for
<div n="lb">calculations though, even in Southern India, the {%pūrṇimānta%}
<div n="lb">arrangement was used with the Śaka years, for the civil reckoning,
<div n="lb">up to between 804 and 866 A. D.; on the other hand, according
<div n="lb">to him, even in Northern India, it was not used with the Newar
<div n="lb">era in Nepal, though it was adopted there when the Newar
<div n="lb">era was followed by the Vikrama era in its northern variety.
<LEND>

<L>4660<pc>266<k1>puroga<k2>puroga
{%Puroga%}¦ (EI 23), prominent among a particular class of
<div n="lb">people; sometimes wrongly taken to be the same as {%Purohita.%}
<LEND>

<L>4661<pc>266<k1>purohita<k2>purohita
{%Purohita%}¦ (CII 4; SII 1; BL; ASLV; HD), a priest; a
<div n="lb">family priest; the royal priest; occurs in the list of functionaries
<div n="lb">in records like those of the Gāhaḍavālas ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. IX, p.
<div n="lb">305) and Senas (ibid., Vol. XII, p. 9). See {%Hist. Dharm.,%} Vol.
<div n="lb">III, pp. 111-12, 117.
<LEND>

<L>4697<pc>268<k1>puwwi<k2>puwwi
{%puṭṭi%}¦ (CITD), Telugu; a measure equal to twenty {%tūmus;%}
<div n="lb">also called {%khaṇḍi%} (spelt {%candy%} in English and found as {%khaṇḍikā%}
<div n="lb">in Sanskrit inscriptions) and regarded as equal to between 800
<div n="lb">and 1000 seers. {%Khaṇḍi%} at Masulipatam has 3 weights, viz.
<div n="lb">488 pounds for tobacco, 500 pounds for metals, hardware, etc.,
<div n="lb">and 560 pounds for sugar, dates and other soft articles. The
<div n="lb">{%puṭṭi%} and its fractions also denote the area of the land that is
<div n="lb">supposed by some to produce the particular quantities of
<div n="lb">grain. According to some, it is a land measure equal to 8
<div n="lb">acres being presumably the area which can be sown with a
<div n="lb">{%puṭṭi%} of grain. There were different kinds of {%puṭṭis,%} e. g. {%gāl-%}
<div n="lb">{%puṭṭi.%} Cf. also {%pelle-puṭṭi%} regarded as equal to 80 {%kuñcas%} and
<div n="lb">{%Malaca-puṭṭi%} or Malacca ton as equal to 300 to 240 {%kuñcas.%}
<div n="P">({%EI%} 4, 27), a land and grain measure.
[Page-269+ 38]
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-5), same as Telugu {%puṭṭi-dosillu,%} ‘a fee of two hand-
<div n="lb">fuls from each {%puṭṭi%} of grain paid to the village-servants’.
<LEND>

<L>4698<pc>269<k1>puwwidosillu<k2>puwwi-dosillu
{%puṭṭi-dosillu%}¦ (EI 33), a levy; see {%puṭṭi.%}
<LEND>

{%pyoḍā%}¦ (Chamba), a grain measure; also spelt {%piṭha, piḍā,%}
<div n="lb">{%peḍā.%}
<LEND>

<L>4739<pc>271<k1>rAjakula<k2>rAjakula

<div n="lb">hold; the king, royal officers and members of the royal family.

<div n="lb">family’; and then ‘a royal officer’; later, a title of nobility, same

<L>4760<pc>272<k1>rAjaputra<k2>rAja-putra
{%Rāja-putra%}¦ (EI 30; CII 3; 4; HD), originally ‘a prince’;
<div n="lb">title of princes and subordinate rulers; but later a title of nobi-
<div n="lb">lity especially in the modified forms {%Rāvata, Rāuta,%} etc.; some-
<div n="lb">times also used in the sense of ‘a Rājpūt’ often explained as ‘a
<div n="lb">horse-man’. Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XVII, p. 321. See {%Rāja-%}
<div n="lb">{%putraka.%}

<L>4779<pc>273<k1>rAjasTAnIya<k2>rAjasTAnIya
{%Rājasthānīya%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 24, 26, 30; CII 3, 4; BL; HD),
<div n="lb">‘an officer acting for the king’; generally a viceroy; probably
<div n="lb">also a subordinate ruler; but cf. {%Rājasthān-ādhikāra%} who was
<div n="lb">also a judge; an official title indicating a viceroy in some areas
<div n="lb">and a judge in others; an officer who carried out the object
<div n="lb">of protecting subjects, according to some ({%Ind. Ant.,%} Vol. V,
<div n="lb">p. 207). Cf. {%CII,%} Vol. III, p. 157; Vogel, {%Ant. Ch. St.,%} p.
<div n="lb">112; {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XI, p. 176 (probably, a chief justice),
<div n="lb">explained wrongly as ‘an officer connected with other kings,
<div n="lb">i. e. a foreign secretary’ ({%Ind. Ant.,%} Vol. XII, p. 122, note 76).
<LEND>

<div n="P">({%CITD%}), enjoyment of splendour other than {%aṅga-bhoga%}
<div n="lb">or personal decoration; gift land received for {%raṅga-bhoga.%} See
<div n="lb">{%aṅga-bhoga.%}

<div n="lb">his overlord. See {%mahāśabda,%} etc.

<div n="lb">taken as {%samavāya%} or concord.

<L>5163<pc>293<k1>saMvat<k2>saMvat
{%saṃvat%}¦ (IE 8-1), originally an abbreviation of {%saṃvatsara%}
<div n="lb">(a year) or any of its declensional cases that can be used in ex-
<div n="lb">pressing a date; later stereotyped in the sense of ‘a year’ or
<div n="lb">‘an era’. It was generally regarded as indeclinable; but we
<div n="lb">have some cases of the use of forms with case-endings, e. g.,
<div n="lb">{%saṃvataḥ, saṃvatā, saṃvati%} and {%saṃvatām.%} See also {%saṃvate%} (IE
<div n="lb">8-1), the seventh case-ending of {%saṃvata,%} a corrupt form of
<div n="lb">{%saṃvat.%} Since the late medieval age, the word specially indi-
<div n="lb">cates the Vikrama era, although originally it was used with the
<div n="lb">name of any reckoning in quoting the dates of records, especially
<div n="lb">the regnal reckoning. The word is used in inscriptions in a
<div n="lb">large number of corrupt forms, e. g., {%samvata, samvatta, samata,%}
<div n="lb">{%samanta, samatta, saṃmat, samasta, smat, samvatu, samvatū,%} etc., etc.
<LEND>

<L>5164<pc>293<k1>samvat<k2>samvat
{%samvat%}¦ (IE 8-1), mistake for {%saṃvat,%} originally an abbre-
<div n="lb">viation of {%saṃvatsara.%}
<LEND>

<L>5165<pc>293<k1>saMvatsara<k2>saMvatsara
{%saṃvatsara%}¦ (CII 3; 4; IA 17), ‘a year’; ‘an cra’, the
<div n="lb">earlier years of the Indian eras being quoted by this term (or
<div n="lb">by its abbreviations {%saṃ, saṃvat,%} etc.), without any dynastic or
<div n="lb">other appellation just as in the case of the year of a regnal
<div n="lb">reckoning.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">‘service in the temple in the morning and evening’; daily wor-
<div n="lb">ship in temples; special worship offered in the names of persons
<div n="lb">who arrange for it by creating endowments, etc.

<L>5215<pc>296<k1>saNgam<k2>saNgam
{%saṅgam,%}¦ Tamil; same as Sanskrit {%saṅgha;%} an assembly of
<div n="lb">ancient Tamil poets; the name given to an assembly of poets
<div n="lb">reported in tradition to have functioned in three different pe-
<div n="lb">riods. The poets are believed to have been both literary critics
<div n="lb">and composers. Literary compositions of the age were later
<div n="lb">collected and compiled into anthologies known as {%Eṭṭuttokai,%}
<div n="lb">{%Pattuppāṭṭu%} and {%Padineṇkīḻkaṇakku%} according to their contents
<div n="lb">and size. The {%saṅgam%} is stated to have flourished at Kūḍal
<div n="lb">(also called Madurai in later literature) in the first and last
<div n="lb">period and at Kavāṭapuram in the middle period. The latest
<div n="lb">limit for the first two anthologies may be placed round about
<div n="lb">700 A.D. See M. S. Purnalingam Pillai, {%Tamil Literature,%}
<div n="lb">pp. 14-18; S. Vaiyapuri Pillai, {%History of Tamil Language and%}
<div n="lb">{%Literature,%} p. 38.
<LEND>

<L>5216<pc>296<k1>saNGa<k2>saNGa
{%saṅgha%}¦ (ASLV), a social organisation.
<div n="P">({%BL%}), a community of Buddhist monks; the Buddhist Church.
<div n="P">({%HA%}), a Jain congregation; the Jain Church (made up
<div n="lb">of four constituents, viz. {%sādhu, sādhvī, śrāvaka%} and {%śrāvikā%})
<div n="lb">also called {%Jaina-saṅgha;%} a group of pilgrims going together on
[Page-297+ 40]
<div n="lb">pilgrimage under the leadership of a {%Saṅghapati%} (q. v.).
<div n="P">({%EI%} 22), a tribe.
<div n="P">{%Cf.%} Tamil {%saṅgam%} (q. v.).
<LEND>

<L>5272<pc>299<k1>saptamacakravartin<k2>saptama-cakravartin
{%Saptama-cakravartin%}¦ (LP), ‘the seventh emperor’, i. e. the
<div n="lb">ruling monarch; according to the {%Abhidhānacintāmaṇi,%} the six
[Page-300+ 40]
<div n="lb">older {%Cakravartins%} are: {%Māndhātā Dhundhumāraś = ca Hariścan-%}
<div n="lb">{%draḥ Purūravāḥ | Bharataḥ Kārtavīryaś = ca ṣaḍ = ete cakravartinaḥ ||%}
<LEND>

<L>5278<pc>300<k1>saptasantAna<k2>sapta-santAna
{%sapta-santāna%}¦ (SITI), also called {%sapta-santati;%} merit equal
<div n="lb">to that obtainable through progeny from their performance of
<div n="lb">seven kinds of great deeds, viz. digging of tanks, hoarding of
<div n="lb">treasure, founding of {%agrahāras,%} erection of temples, creation
<div n="lb">of flower gardens, getting literary works written by poets, and
<div n="lb">the establishment of Choultries. An inscription ({%Ep. Ind.,%}
<div n="lb">Vol. III, pp. 88 ff.) mentions the following seven meritorious
<div n="lb">acts a man ought to perform during his lifetime; viz. procrea-
<div n="lb">tion of sons, accumulation of wealth, planting of groves, help-
<div n="lb">ing people (Brāhmaṇas) to marry, getting poems composed,
<div n="lb">erection of temples and excavation of tanks.
<LEND>

<L>5279<pc>300<k1>saptasantati<k2>sapta-santati
{%sapta-santati%}¦ (SITI), same as {%sapta-santāna.%}
<LEND>

<L>5282<pc>300<k1>sArA<k2>sArA
{%sārā%}¦ (EI 9; LP), care; cf. {%etair = aṣṭabhir = goṣṭhikaiḥ … sārā%}
<div n="lb">{%karaṇīyā,%} ‘[this place of worship] has to be taken care of by the
<div n="lb">following eight trustees’. Cf. also Gujarātī {%sāravār.%}
<div n="P">({%EI%} 8, 11), supervision.
<LEND>

<L>5283<pc>300<k1>SaraBaNga<k2>SaraBaNga
{%Śarabhaṅga%}¦ (IE 8-3; 8-8; EI 23), a leader of forces; an
<div n="lb">officer of the military department; possibly, a military governor;
<div n="lb">same as Persian {%Sarhang%} and Hindī {%Serāṅg;%} also spelt {%Sarabhaṅga%}
<div n="lb">and {%Sarobhaṅga;%} Wilson's Glossary explains {%Sarhang%} as ‘a com-
<div n="lb">mander’ and says, “but [it is] generally applied in India to
<div n="lb">the headman of a native crew, whether on board a ship or a
<div n="lb">boat; also to the headman of a gang of natives attached to artill-
<div n="lb">ery, dragging guns, or to the army in general, as tent-pitchers,
<div n="lb">and the like, or to the head of gangs of a superior order of labour-
<div n="lb">ers employed in public or private works, in docks, buildings,
[Page-301+ 40]
<div n="lb">etc.’ Cf. Vogel, {%Ant. Ch. St.,%} pp. 123, 166 (spelt {%Sarobhaṅga%}),
<div n="lb">{%Ind. Cult.,%} Vol. VII, p. 309. Kane ({%Hist. Dharm.,%} Vol. III,
<div n="lb">p. 1005) is certainly wrong when he thinks that it may be con-
<div n="lb">nected with {%śarayantra%} and {%Śarayantrin%} (a title bestowed in Mithilā
<div n="lb">upon a very learned man who faced the ordeal of answering
<div n="lb">satisfactorily all questions on any {%śāstra%} put to him by learned
<div n="lb">{%Ācāryas%} and also the questions put by common people). See {%Ep.%}
<div n="lb">{%Ind.,%} Vol. XXXV, pp. 95. ff. See {%Sarāṅgha, Sarāhang,%} etc.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">Brāhmī and was prevalent in the Kashmir region.

<L>5319<pc>303<k1>sarvamAnya<k2>sarva-mAnya
{%sarva-mānya%}¦ (IE 8-5, SITI; CITD), a free tenure; a
<div n="lb">rent-free holding; land exempted from taxes; lands and villages
<div n="lb">fully exempt from all taxes. This corresponds to the
<div n="lb">{%iṟaiyili%} class of land mentioned in the Col13a inscriptions. Often
<div n="lb">this is associated with {%aṣṭa-bhoga,%} i. e. the eight forms of enjoy-
<div n="lb">ing the land. For a discussion of this form of land tenure, see
<div n="lb">{%JAHRS,%} Vol. X, pp. 123-32. It is noteworthy that even the
<div n="lb">so-called tax-free ({%i%}ṟ{%aiyili%}) lands paid to the king certain dues
<div n="lb">of the nature of taxes. See K. A. Nilakanta Sastri, {%The%}
<div n="lb">{%Co%}l13{%as,%} 2nd ed., pp. 534-35. See {%sarva-namasya,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>5425<pc>309<k1>senApati<k2>senApati
{%Senāpati%}¦ (IE 8-3), leader of forces; mentioned separately
<div n="lb">along with {%Bal-ādhyakṣa;%} probably, a subordinate of the latter;
<div n="lb">the military governor of a district, according to some
<div n="lb">(HD); commander-in-chief (ASLV), also called {%Sarva-sainy-%}
<div n="lb">{%ādhikārin%} and {%Dalavāya,%} i. e. the chief officer in charge of the
<div n="lb">military department. See {%Bṛhaspati%} quoted by Viśvarūpa on
<div n="lb">{%Yājñavalkyasmṛti,%} I. 307; {%Ind. Ant.,%} Vol. XV, p. 187. Puṣya-
<div n="lb">mitra, the founder of the Śuṅga dynasty, was called {%Senāpati%}
<div n="lb">even after his accession to the Maurya throne. See {%Sen-ādhipa,%}
<div n="lb">etc.; cf. also {%Anusenāpati%} (EI 18).
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3), sometimes called {%Mahāpradhāna, Bāhattara-%}
<div n="lb">{%niyogādhiṣṭhāyaka, Paṭṭa-sāhan-ādhipati,%} etc., additionally.

<div n="lb">remains of flowers, raw rice and other offerings made to an idol
<div n="lb">or used in a {%śubha-kārya%} and afterwards distributed among the

<div n="lb">raw rice over which incantations have been pronounced and

<div n="lb">rites.

<L>5444<pc>310<k1>sidDa<k2>sidDa

<div n="lb">an emancipated person.

<div n="lb">saints who are invoked in the plural.

<L>5587<pc>317<k1>SrI<k2>SrI
{%śrī%}¦ (CII 3, etc.), honorific prefix to names often rendered
<div n="lb">variously in English; e. g., in the case of paramount sovereigns
<div n="lb">and their wives by ‘glorious’; of feudatories and other ordinary
<div n="lb">persons by ‘illustrious’; of priests, teachers, etc., by ‘saintly’;
<div n="lb">of gods by ‘holy’; sometimes {%śrī%} is used before consonants and
<div n="lb">{%śrīmat%} before vowels. The honorific {%śrī%} is sometimes used in
<div n="lb">South Indian records along with the words {%vijaya%} or {%vijaya-śiva%}
<div n="lb">(q. v.). Cf. {%śrī-ni, Śrīcaraṇa,%} etc.
<div n="P">({%IA%} 17), cf. {%śrī-pūrva%} used for {%śrī-yuta; śrī%} is sometimes
<div n="lb">repeated for emphasis, e. g., ‘{%śrī%} 108’ is written to indicate the
<div n="lb">repetition of the word for 108 times.
<LEND>

<L>5723<pc>326<k1>SukanAsa<k2>Suka-nAsa
{%śuka-nāsa,%}¦ cf. {%śukanāsi%} ({%Arch. Rev.,%} 1960-61, Section III)
<div n="lb">literally, ‘a parrot's nose’ explained as ‘a gargoyle or
<div n="lb">the water spout in a building’ (Acharya, {%Ind. Arch.,%} p. 169)
<div n="lb">and ‘a vestibule’ (R. Narasiṃhachar, {%The Keśava Temple of%}
<div n="lb">{%Somanāthapur,%} p. 3); but also as ‘the projection of the main
<div n="lb">body of the {%śikhara%} of a temple originally at the front-
<div n="lb">side’ (Kramrisch, {%Hindu Temple,%} p. 241); also called {%śuk-%}
<div n="lb">{%āṅghri.%} The {%Dīpārṇava%} (ed. Prabhāśaṅkar O. Sompurā, p. 116)
<div n="lb">has the following stanzas on the subject:
{%agre kolī kapolas = tu śuka-nāsas = tu nāsikā |%}
<div n="lb">{%sāndhāre stambha-rekhā ca kartavyā madhya-koṣṭhake ||%}
<div n="lb">{%prāsādasya puro-bhāge nirvāṇa-mūla-śṛṅgakam |%}
<div n="lb">{%tad-agre śuka-nāśaṃ ca ek-ādi saptam = udgamam ||%}
<div n="lb">{%tasy = opari siṃhaḥ sthāpyo maṇḍapa-kalaśa-samaḥ |%}
<div n="lb">{%dvi-stambhaḥ śuka-nās-āgre vijñeyaḥ pāda-maṇḍapaḥ ||%}

<L>5739<pc>327<k1>Sulka<k2>Sulka
{%śulka%}¦ (IE 8-5; EI 12, 23, 25, 30; CII 4; CITD), tolls;
<div n="lb">customs duties; octroi duties; taxes particularly levied at ferries
<div n="lb">and passes and on roads, etc.; cf. {%krīḍara-śulka%} (EI 5), name of
<div n="lb">a tax; also {%śuṅgam, śuṅkam%} (SITI), customs, tolls.
<div n="P">({%HRS%}), tax, probably identical with {%bali%} according to
<div n="lb">early authorities; ferry dues, tolls and transit duties according
<div n="lb">to the {%Smṛtis%} and lexicons; according to the {%Arthaśāstra,%} (1)
<div n="lb">duties levied upon articles imported into a city, (2) port-dues,
<div n="lb">(3) duty upon the sale of liquors, (4) customs collected by
<div n="lb">the ferrymen and boundary-officers, (5) duty upon mining
<div n="lb">products, (6) duty upon imported salt, and (7) duty upon
<div n="lb">animals intended for slaughter; according to Śukra, tolls and
<div n="lb">duties upon building-sites, etc. The {%Amarakoṣa%} explains {%śulka%}
<div n="lb">as {%ghaṭṭ-ādi-deya%} and Kṣīrasvāmin enumerates the dues as ferry
<div n="lb">duties, tolls paid at military stations or police outposts and
<div n="lb">transit duties paid by merchants.
<LEND>

<L>5740<pc>327<k1>SulkADikAra<k2>Sulk-ADikAra
{%śulk-ādhikāra,%}¦ cf. {%suṅk-ādhikāra%} (EI 5), ‘office for the collec-
<div n="lb">tion of tolls [of the Banavāsi District]’. Same as {%Śulk-ā-dhyakṣa.%}

<L>5760<pc>328<k1>surahI<k2>surahI
{%surahī%}¦ (HA), Sanskrit {%surabhi;%} inscribed stone with the
<div n="lb">representation of a cow with her calf and the sun and the moon
<div n="lb">in the upper part, the inscriptions usually recording gifts or
<div n="lb">donations or exemptions from obligations or taxes declared
<div n="lb">by kings. This indicated permanence and inviolability.

<L>5864<pc>333<k1>talAra<k2>talAra
{%Talāra%}¦ (IE 8-2; EI 22; LP; BL; HD), administrator of
<div n="lb">a city or prefect of the city police; same as {%Talavara, Talārī%} or
<div n="lb">{%Kotwāl. Talavara%} of early South Indian inscriptions means
<div n="lb">a {%Rājasthānīya%} (a Duke or a viceroy) according to some
[Page-334+ 40]
<div n="lb">commentators and the {%Kotwāl%} or a city magistrate according to
<div n="lb">others. A subdivision of high class Khatris of the Punjab is
<div n="lb">called {%Tālwār.%} Cf. {%Tala-rakṣa%} or {%Tal-ārakṣa;%} also called {%Ārakṣika%}
<div n="lb">and {%Daṇḍapāśika.%} See Bhandarkar's List, No. 579; {%IHQ,%} 1960,
<div n="lb">p. 266.

<L>5917<pc>337<k1>tantrin<k2>tantrin
{%Tantrin%}¦ (SITI; ASLV), a soldier; a trooper; a leader
<div n="lb">of the army; a temple priest; a weaver. It has been sup-
<div n="lb">posed that the Tamil words {%Kaikkoḻar%} and {%Aṭavi%} came to signify
<div n="lb">both a soldier and a weaver on the analogy of the word {%Tantrin%}
<div n="lb">used in both the senses. Cf. {%Tantrimār,%} members of the army
<div n="lb">corps; a class of persons who perform worship in temples; a priest.

<L>5961<pc>340<k1>Wakkura<k2>Wakkura
{%Ṭhakkura%}¦ (IE 8-3; EI 23, 30; CII 4; HD), supposed
<div n="lb">to be a title derived from a Turkish word ({%Tegin%}); occurs as a
<div n="lb">title in the {%Rājataraṅgiṇī,%} VII. 290, 706, 738; probably, a
<div n="lb">fief-holder; sometimes mentioned in the list of subordinates;
<div n="lb">generally used as a title of particular persons indicating their
<div n="lb">rank or office. The significance of the word possibly varied
<div n="lb">in different localities and ages. Its foreign origin is sup-
<div n="lb">ported by its unpopularity in the South. Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol.
<div n="lb">XIII, p. 297; Vol. XIX, p. 243.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3), probably a fief-holder; mentioned as {%Pātra.%}
<div n="P">({%EI%} 9), explained as ‘the lord-in-waiting’.
<LEND>

<L>5991<pc>341<k1>tiTi<k2>tiTi
{%tithi%}¦ (CII 3; IA 17), a lunar day; one mean {%tithi%} is equal
<div n="lb">to 0.9843529572 of a mean solar day and night; the mean
<div n="lb">{%tithis%} in a solar year are 371, and 3 {%ghaṭīs%} and 53.4 {%palas;%} gener-
<div n="lb">ally the term {%tithi%} means the end of a {%tithi,%} not its beginning
<div n="lb">or duration, and the week-day of a {%tithi%} is the week-day on
<div n="lb">which that {%tithi%} ends; the {%tithis%} given in the {%Pañcāṅga%} are
<div n="lb">apparent, not mean, and they are intended to be given from
<div n="lb">apparent sunrise.
<div n="P">{%Cf.%} Tamil {%tiyadi, tedi%} (SITI), a date.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 7-1-2), ‘fifteen’.
<div n="P">({%EI%} 16), same as {%mahā-tithi,%} an auspicious {%tithi;%} cf. {%saptamī%}
<div n="lb">called the {%tithi%} of the sun-god and {%aṣṭamī%} that of the god Śiva
<div n="lb">({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. V, p. 168, note 4).
<LEND>

<div n="lb">the libation of water; also referred to in Tamil as {%udakañśeydu%}
<div n="lb">and {%udakaṃ paṇṇi.%} See {%udaka-pūrvam,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>6099<pc>347<k1>udakapUrvam<k2>udaka-pUrvam
{%udaka-pūrvam%}¦ (IA 7), also expressed as {%udak-ātisargeṇa,%}
<div n="lb">‘with libations of water’; refers to the custom of pouring water
<div n="lb">in the hand of the donee while making the ceremonial gift of an
<div n="lb">object which cannot be placed in the latter's hands. Cf. {%Dra-%}
<div n="lb">{%vyasya nāma gṛhnīyād=dadān=īti tathā vadet | toyaṃ dadyāt=tato%}
<div n="lb">{%haste dāne vidhir=ayaṃ smṛtaḥ ||%} ({%Agni Purāṇa,%} Ch. 209,
<div n="lb">verses 49-50).
<LEND>

<L>6100<pc>347<k1>udakasarga<k2>udaka-sarga

<div n="lb">{%pūrvam%}).
<LEND>

<div n="lb">{%pānīya-sametā%} (IE 8-5), translated as ‘together with the fruit-

<L>6132<pc>349<k1>udraNga<k2>udraNga
{%udraṅga%}¦ (IE 8-3; 8-5; EI 22; CII 3, 4; HRS), explained
<div n="lb">as ‘the fixed tax’, ‘the land tax’, ‘the principal tax’ or ‘the
<div n="lb">tax on the permanent tenants’; generally mentioned along
<div n="lb">with {%uparikara,%} i. e. minor taxes or the tax on temporary
<div n="lb">tenants; same as {%kḻpta. Udraṅga%} may have been paid in grains
<div n="lb">at least in soem regions since the {%Audraṅgika%} (collector of {%ud-%}
<div n="lb">{%raṅga%}) is sometimes separately mentioned together with the
<div n="lb">{%Hiraṇyasāmudāyika%} (collector of revenue in cash). In one
<div n="lb">case, the land is said to have been granted after making it
<div n="lb">{%udraṅga,%} i. e. {%s-odraṅga.%} See {%s-odraṅga%} (IA 10), {%draṅga, uttāra.%}
<div n="lb">Cf. {%mah-odraṅga%} in {%pravartita-mahodraṅg-ādi-dāna-vyasan-ānupajāta-%}

<L>6188<pc>352<k1>uparika<k2>uparika
{%Uparika%}¦ (IE 8-3; CII 3; BL; HD), a viceroy; the
<div n="lb">governor of a province. An {%Uparika%} was appointed by the
<div n="lb">emperor and he himself appointed the governor of the district
<div n="lb">(cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XV, p. 130). He is sometimes styled
<div n="lb">{%Mahārāja%} and {%Rājaputra.%} Viśvarūpa on the {%Yājñavalkyasmṛti,%}
<div n="lb">I. 307, quotes a prose passage from {%Bṛhaspati%} where the re-
<div n="lb">quisite qualities of an {%Uparika%} are set out. See Vogel, {%Ant. Ch.%}
<div n="lb">{%St.,%} p. 123. The word literally means ‘one placed at the top’.
<div n="P">({%IE%} 8-3), cf. {%Auparika,%} a viceroy.
<div n="P">{%Cf. Bṛhad-uparika%} (IE 8-3).
<LEND>

<L>6292<pc>357<k1>vaqqavAra<k2>vaqqa-vAra
{%vaḍḍa-vāra%}¦ (EI 13; CITD), Telugu-Kannaḍa;' Satur-
<div n="lb">day or Thursday (A. Venkatasubbiah, {%Some Śaka Dates in%}
<div n="lb">{%Inscriptions,%} pp. 57. ff.); same as {%bṛha-vāra.%} The word in the
<div n="lb">Telugu part of an inscription is explained as {%śanaiścara-vāra%} in
<div n="lb">the Sanskrit portion of the said record; sometimes wrongly
<div n="lb">supposed to stand for some other day, e. g. Friday (IA 23)
<div n="lb">or Sunday (Venkatasubbiah, {%op. cit.,%} p. 58). Cf. {%Ep. Ind.,%}
<div n="lb">Vol. XII, p. 147; XIII, p. 16; Vol. XXXI, p. 100, note 1; Vol.
<div n="lb">XXXIII, p. 1, note 2; {%Ind. Ant.,%} Vol. XXII, pp. 111, 251-52;
<div n="lb">XXIII, p. 168. {%Vaḍḍa=vṛddha%} or {%bṛhat.%}

<L>6847<pc>386<k1>yukta<k2>yukta
{%Yukta%}¦ (EI 8-3; HD), an officer in general; also an offi-
<div n="lb">cial designation ({%CII,%} Vol. 1, p. 4); the word used in Rock
<div n="lb">Edict III of Aśoka is explained by some scholars as the designa-
<div n="lb">tion of a class of officers, although there also the word may be
<div n="lb">understood in the sense of ‘an officer’; but it is an official desig-
[Page-387+ 22]
<div n="lb">nation in passages like {%yukta-niyukta-vāsāvak-ādhikārika%} ({%Ep. Ind.,%}
<div n="lb">Vol. XXI, p. 144) where it may be the same as {%Āyuktaka.%}
<div n="P">{%Cf. Yuktaka, Āyukta,%} etc.

<L>6854<pc>388<k1>aBawacCAtraprAveSya<k2>a-Bawa-cCAtra-prAveSya
{%a-bhaṭa-cchātra-prāveśya%}¦ (EI 26, 27; CII 3), same as {%a-cāṭa-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhaṭa-prāveśya, Chātra%} (literally, ‘the umbrella-bearer’) being used
<div n="lb">for {%Cāṭa%} probably meaning ‘the leader of a group of {%Bhaṭas%} (i. e.
<div n="lb">{%Pāiks%} or {%Piādas%})’; same as {%a-prāveśya,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>6855<pc>388<k1>aBawaprAveSya<k2>a-Bawa-prAveSya

<div n="lb">{%papesa%} ({%Select Inscriptions,%} p. 435).

<div n="lb">{%prāveśya,%} etc.

<L>6865<pc>388<k1>AcandrArkArRavakzitisaritparvatasamakAlIna<k2>A-candr-Ark-ArRava-kziti-sarit-parvata-sama-kAlIna

<L>6866<pc>388<k1>AcandratArakam<k2>A-candra-tArakam
{%ā-candra-tārakam,%}¦ ‘as long as the moon and stars endure’
<div n="lb">({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXV, p. 149, text line 12), i. e. permanently.
<LEND>

<L>6867<pc>388<k1>acArAsanacarmANgAra<k2>a-cAr-Asana-carm-ANgAra
{%a-cār-āsana-carm-āṅgāra%}¦ (IE; EI 27), refers to the freedom of
<div n="lb">the gift village from the obligation to supply conveyance, accom-
<div n="lb">modation, hide (i. e. hide-seats) and charcoal free of charges
<div n="lb">to the touring officers on their visit. The word {%cāra%} meaning
[Page-389+ 40]
<div n="lb">‘passage or conveyance’ is sometimes substituted by {%pāra%} meaning
<div n="lb">‘ferrying’.
<LEND>

<L>6868<pc>389<k1>acArasidDika<k2>a-cAra-sidDika
{%a-cāra-siddhika%}¦ (EI 26), explained by some as ‘without
<div n="lb">grazing right for the royal cattle’. Cf. {%a-vāra-siddhika.%}
<LEND>

<L>6869<pc>389<k1>acarmANgAraka<k2>a-carm-ANgAraka
{%a-carm-āṅgāraka,%}¦ refers to the freedom of the gift village
<div n="lb">from the obligation to supply hide-seats and charcoal to the king
<div n="lb">or landlord on occasions or to the touring royal officers on their
<div n="lb">visit. Cf. Prakrit {%a-camm-aṅgālaka%} ({%Select Inscriptions,%} p. 409).
<LEND>

<L>6870<pc>389<k1>acAwaBawagocara<k2>a-cAwa-Bawa-gocara
{%a-cāṭa-bhaṭa-gocara%}¦ (EI 22), same as {%a-cāṭa-bhaṭa-praveśa,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>6871<pc>389<k1>acAwaBawapraveSa<k2>a-cAwa-Bawa-praveSa
{%a-cāṭa-bhaṭa-praveśa%}¦ (EI 27, 29; CII 3), refers to the free-
<div n="lb">dom of the gift village from the entry of the {%Cāṭas%} (leaders of
<div n="lb">groups of {%Pāiks%} and {%Piādas%}) and the {%Bhaṭas%} ({%Pāiks%} and {%Piādas%});
<div n="lb">cf. {%a-bhaṭa-praveśa, a-bhaṭa-chātra-prāveśya, a-bhṛta-praveśa,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>6872<pc>389<k1>acAwaBawaprAveSya<k2>a-cAwa-Bawa-prAveSya
{%a-cāṭa-bhaṭa-prāveśya%}¦ (CII 3, 4), same as {%a-cāṭa-bhaṭa-pra-%}
<div n="lb">{%veśa;%} refers to the freedom of the gift land from being entered
<div n="lb">by the {%Bhaṭas%} (the king's {%Pāiks%} and {%Piādas%}) and the {%Cāḷa%} (the
<div n="lb">leader of a group of {%Pāiks%} and {%Piādas%}); cf. {%Chātra%} in place of {%Cāṭa%}
<div n="lb">in {%a-bhaṭa-cchātra-prāveśya;%} also {%Bhṛta%} for {%Bhaṭa%} in {%a-bhṛta-praveśya.%}
<LEND>

<L>6873<pc>389<k1>acawwaBawwapraveSa<k2>a-cawwa-Bawwa-praveSa
{%a-caṭṭa-bhaṭṭa-praveśa%}¦ (EI 27), same as {%a-cāṭa-bhaṭa-praveśa.%}

<L>6874<pc>389<k1>acullakakUraKawvAgrahaRa<k2>a-cullaka-kUra-KawvA-grahaRa

<L>6875<pc>389<k1>adugDadaDigrahaRa<k2>a-dugDa-daDi-grahaRa
{%a-dugdha-dadhi-grahaṇa,%}¦ refers to the freedom of the gift
<div n="lb">village from the obligation of supplying milk and curs to the
<div n="lb">king or landlord on occasions or to the touring officials on their
<div n="lb">visit. Cf. Prakrit {%a-dudha-dadhi-gahaṇa%} ({%Select Inscriptions,%} p. 439).
<LEND>

<L>6876<pc>389<k1>aharItakaSAkapuzpagrahaRa<k2>a-harItaka-SAka-puzpa-grahaRa
{%a-harītaka-śāka-puṣpa-grahaṇa,%}¦ refers to the freedom of the
<div n="lb">gift land from the supply of myrobalan, vegetables and flowers
<div n="lb">to the king or landlord on occasions or to the touring officers
<div n="lb">on their visit. Cf. Prakrit {%a-haritaka-sāka-pupha-gahaṇa%} ({%Select%}
<div n="lb">{%Inscriptions,%} p. 439).
<LEND>

<L>6877<pc>389<k1>aharItaparRaSAkapuzpaPaladugDadaDiGftatakragrahaRa<k2>a-harIta-parRa-SAka-puzpa-Pala-dugDa-daDi-Gfta-takra-grahaRa

<L>6878<pc>389<k1>ahastaprakzepaRIya<k2>a-hasta-prakzepaRIya

<LEND>

<L>6879<pc>389<k1>ahiraRyaDAnyapraRayapradeya<k2>a-hiraRya-DAnya-praRaya-pradeya
{%a-hiraṇya-dhānya-praṇaya-pradeya%}¦ (EI 26), refers to the
<div n="lb">freedom of the gift land from the payment of revenue in cash,
<div n="lb">the king's grain share and the benevolence or emergency
<div n="lb">imposts. Cf. Prakrit {%a-hiraṇṇa-dhaṇṇa-ppaṇaya-ppadeya%} ({%Select-%}
<div n="lb">{%Inscriptions,%} pp. 408-09).
<LEND>
[Page-390+ 40]

<L>6880<pc>390<k1>akarada<k2>a-karada
{%a-karada%}¦ (EI 26), refers to the freedom of the donee of
<div n="lb">the gift land from paying taxes in general.
<LEND>

<L>6881<pc>390<k1>akaradAyin<k2>a-karadAyin
{%a-karadāyin%}¦ (EI 26, 27), same as {%a-karada.%}
<LEND>

<L>6882<pc>390<k1>akaravAtottara<k2>a-kara-vAt-ottara
{%a-kara-vāt-ottara%}¦ (IE; EI 32), sometimes with {%āvāta, vāt-ādeya,%}
<div n="lb">{%bhūt-opātta-pratyāya,%} etc., in place of {%vāt-ottara;%} cf. {%sa-bhūta-vāta-%}
<div n="lb">(or {%pāta%}) {%-pratyāya,%} etc; ‘free from the collections resulting from
<div n="lb">storms (e. g. uprooted trees, fruits, etc.).’
<LEND>

<L>6883<pc>390<k1>akaravizwikoYjalla<k2>a-kara-vizwi-koYjalla
{%a-kara-viṣṭi-koñjalla%}¦ (IE), refers to the freedom of the donee
<div n="lb">of the gift land from the payment of taxes and the obligation to
<div n="lb">supply free labour and {%koñjalla (kāñji)%} to the king's labourers.
<div n="lb">Cf. {%Select Inscriptions,%} p. 439.
<LEND>

<L>6884<pc>390<k1>aKawvAcullakavEnASika<k2>a-KawvA-cullaka-vEnASika
{%a-khaṭvā-cullaka-vaināśika,%}¦ cf. Prakrit {%a-khaṭṭa-collaka-veṇe-%}
<div n="lb">{%sika%} (EI 26), refers to the freedom of the gift village from the
<div n="lb">obligation to supply cots, food and attendant or fuel to the
<div n="lb">touring royal officers on their visit or to the king or landlord
<div n="lb">on occasions. Cf. {%a-kūra-cullaka-vināśi-khaṭv-āvāsa,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>6885<pc>390<k1>akiYcitkara<k2>a-kiYcit-kara
{%a-kiñcit-kara,%}¦ ‘not to pay even a small amount as rent or
<div n="lb">tax’; epithet of gift land; same as {%a-kiñcit-pragrāhya.%} It has to
<div n="lb">be noted that sometimes a small amount of tax was fixed for
<div n="lb">the gift lands. Cf. {%kara-śāsana.%}
<LEND>

<L>6886<pc>390<k1>akiYcitkaragrAhya<k2>a-kiYcit-kara-grAhya
{%a-kiñcit-kara-grāhya%}¦ (EI 27), same as {%a-kiñcit-kara,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>6887<pc>390<k1>akiYcitpragrAhya<k2>a-kiYcit-pragrAhya
{%a-kiñcit-pragrāhya%}¦ (EI 29), refers to the freedom of the gift
<div n="lb">land from the payment of taxes and the obligation of supplying
<div n="lb">articles to the king or landlord on occasions and to the touring
<div n="lb">officers on their visit; same as {%a-kiñcit-kara,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>6888<pc>390<k1>akiYcitpratikara<k2>a-kiYcit-pratikara
{%a-kiñcit-pratikara%}¦ (EI 23), ‘[land] free from any yield
<div n="lb">of revenue’; cf. {%utpratikara.%} But {%pratikara%} also means
<div n="lb">‘compensation’.
<LEND>

<L>6889<pc>390<k1>akUracullakavEnASiKawvAvAsa<k2>a-kUra-cullaka-vEnASi-Kawv-AvAsa
{%a-kūra-cullaka-vaināśi-khaṭv-āvāsa%}¦ (or {%ºsaṃvāsa%}), cf. {%a-kūra-%}
<div n="lb">{%yollaka-venesi-khaṭṭ-āvāsa%} (EI 26); refers to the freedom of the
<div n="lb">gift village from the obligation of supplying boiled or unboiled
<div n="lb">rice, pots or fire-places for cooking, attendant or fuel, cot and
<div n="lb">shelter to the king or landlord on occasions or to the touring
<div n="lb">officers on their visit; same as {%a-kūra-cullaka-vināśi-khaṭvā-saṃvāsa,%}
<div n="lb">etc. See {%sāmant-āmātya-dūtānām=anyeṣām c=ābhyupāgame śayanīy-%}
<div n="lb">{%āsana-siddh-ānnaṃ na dāpayet%} ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXX, p. 171).
<LEND>

<L>6890<pc>390<k1>alavaRaguqakzoBa<k2>a-lavaRa-guqa-kzoBa
{%a-lavaṇa-guḍa-kṣobha%}¦ (EI 26), same as {%a-lavaṇa-khātaka,%}

<div n="lb">{%khātaka.%}

<L>6891<pc>390<k1>alavaRaKAtaka<k2>a-lavaRa-KAtaka

[Page-391+ 40]
<div n="lb">to the freedom of the gift land from being dug out or its trees
<div n="lb">being pierced for salt.

<div n="lb">sometimes wrongly spelt {%kliṇva,%} probably, ‘toddy, sugar, etc.’

<L>6896<pc>391<k1>aleKanIpraveSatayA<k2>a-leKanI-praveSatayA
{%a-lekhanī-praveśatayā%}¦ (EI 29), probably refers to the absence
<div n="lb">of the right to re-grant the gift land to any other party on the
<div n="lb">part of the king and to alienate the gift land on the part of the
<div n="lb">donee; {%lekhanī-praveśa%} may mean that the gift land should not
<div n="lb">be made the subject of another document.
<LEND>

<L>6916<pc>392<k1>arAzwrasAMvinayika<k2>a-rAzwra-sAMvinayika

<div n="lb">text lines 36-37), translated as ‘the established customs [of the
<div n="lb">gift land] are withheld from [injury by] the enterprise of

<L>6926<pc>393<k1>BogasambanDanirvacanIya<k2>BogasambanDa-nirvacanIya
{%bhogasambandha-nirvacanīya%}¦ (EI 12), ‘the relations [of

<L>6927<pc>393<k1>BUmicCidranAyena<k2>BUmi-cCidra-nAyena
{%bhūmi-cchidra-nāyena%}¦ or {%ºcchidra-pidhāna-vyāyena,%} ‘in accor-
<div n="lb">dance with the principle of cultivating the land for the first
<div n="lb">time and enjoying it free of taxes as a result’. The word {%chidra%}
<div n="lb">in the first means ‘cultivation’ and {%chidra-pidhāna%} in the second
<div n="lb">‘reclamation of uncultivable land for the first time.’ Some-
<div n="lb">times {%vidhāna%} is wrongly used for {%pidhāna.%} See {%Ind. Ep.,%} pp. 397-98.
<LEND>

<L>6928<pc>393<k1>BUtaBavizyadvartamAnaniHSezAdAtyasahita<k2>BUta-Bavizyad-vartamAna-niHSez-AdAtya-sahita

<L>6935<pc>394<k1>cOravarjam<k2>cOra-varjam
{%caura-varjam,%}¦ also quoted as {%cora-varjam, cora-daṇḍa-varjam,%}
<div n="lb">{%cora-rājāpathyakāri-varjam,%} etc.; according to some ‘with immu-
<div n="lb">nity from the police tax’, while others take it to be related to
<div n="lb">{%a-cāṭa-bhaṭa-praveśa%} and think that the policemen were prohi-
<div n="lb">bited from entering a gift village except in connection with the
<div n="lb">apprehension of criminals; may also mean ‘without any right
<div n="lb">to inflict punishment of thieves, etc., or to levy fines from
<div n="lb">thieves, etc.’ See {%CII,%} Vol. III, p. 109.
<LEND>

<L>6936<pc>394<k1>coradaRqavarja<k2>cora-daRqa-varja
{%cora-daṇḍa-varja%}¦ (EI 27), same as {%caura-varja,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>6937<pc>394<k1>coravarja<k2>cora-varja
{%cora-varja%}¦ (IE), ‘without the right to punish the thieves and to
<div n="lb">realise stolen articles’; cf. {%sa-caur-oddharaṇa.%} But see also {%cauravarjam.%}
<LEND>

<L>6938<pc>394<k1>deSamaryAdAruvaRAnvila<k2>deSa-maryAd-AruvaR-Anvila
{%deśa-maryād-āruvaṇ-ānvila%}¦ ({%Ind. Ant.%} Vol. XIX, p. 247, text
<div n="lb">line 103), refers to the right to levy the tax called {%āruvaṇa%}
<div n="lb">(Sanskrit {%ṣaṭ-paṇa%}) according to the local custom.
<LEND>

<L>6939<pc>394<k1>devabrAhmaRaBuktivarja<k2>deva-brAhmaRa-Bukti-varja
{%deva-Brāhmaṇa-bhukti-varja%}¦ (EI 23, 30), ‘excluding the
<div n="lb">property of the gods (i. e. temples) and Brāhmaṇas’.
<LEND>

<L>6940<pc>394<k1>devakulapuzkariRyADikaM<k2>devakula-puzkariRy-ADikaM kArayitvA
{%devakula-puṣkariṇy-ādhikaṃ kārayitvā,%}¦ refers to the right of
<div n="lb">the donee to build temples and excavate tanks in the gift land
<div n="lb">without the permission of the king or landlord as was necessary
<div n="lb">in the case of ordinary tenants. Cf. Majumdar, {%Ins. Beng.,%}
<div n="lb">Vol. III, p. 125.
<LEND>

<L>6941<pc>394<k1>gogOqasameta<k2>go-gOqa-sameta
{%go-gauḍa-sameta,%}¦ ‘together with the cattle and herdsmen
<div n="lb">[of state farms] or with the grazing tax’; epithet of gift village.
<div n="lb">{%Go-gauḍa%} may be the same as {%go-kara.%} Cf. {%Ind. Ep.,%} p. 402.
<LEND>

<L>6942<pc>394<k1>grAmanilayanAqasarvabADAparihAreRa<k2>grAma-nilaya-nAqa-sarva-bADA-parihAreRa
{%grāma-nilaya-nāḍa-sarva-bādhā-parihāreṇa%}¦ (EI 9), ‘with the
<div n="lb">exemption of all troubles connected with [the administration
<div n="lb">of] the village, subdivision (literally, habitation) and district [in
<div n="lb">which the gift land is situated]’. Cf. {%a-rāṣṭra-sāṃvinayika,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>6942.1<pc>394<k1>gfhAvataraRaharitapakvasasyekzucAraRalavanopamardanarocikAciwolAgrahaRapIWakapIWikAKawvApaharaRakAzWenDana<k2>gfh-AvataraRa-harita-pakva-sasy-ekzu-cAraRa-lavan-opamardana-rocikA-ciwolA-grahaRa-pIWaka-pIWikA-Kawv-ApaharaRa-kAzW-enDana-
{%gṛh-āvataraṇa-harita-pakva-sasy-ekṣu-cāraṇa-lavan-opamardana-rocikā-ciṭolā-grahaṇa-pīṭhaka-pīṭhikā-khaṭv-āpaharaṇa-kāṣṭh-endhana-%}¦
<div n="lb">
[Page-395+ 40]
<div n="lb">{%ghāsa-bus-ādikaṃ na kenacit = [kartavyaṃ] pragrāhyaṃ [ca],%}
<div n="lb">‘no one should enter into the donce's house, should graze one's
<div n="lb">cattle on the green crops in his fields, should harvest the ripe
<div n="lb">crops in his fields, should crush his sugar-cane, should accept
<div n="lb">{%rocikā%} and {%ciṭolā%} from him, should take stools, seats and cots
<div n="lb">from him and should take wood, fuel, grass, chaff, etc., from
<div n="lb">him’. For {%gṛh-āvataraṇa,%} see {%umbara-bheda.%} Words like {%rocikā,%}
<div n="lb">{%ciṭolā,%} etc., are not intelligible, although they certainly refer
<div n="lb">to certain obligations or levies. Cf. {%Ind. Ep.,%} p. 394.
<LEND>

<L>6943<pc>395<k1>guvAkanArikelAdikaM<k2>guvAka-nArikel-AdikaM laggAvayitvA
{%guvāka-nārikel-ādikaṃ laggāvayitvā,%}¦ refers to the right of
<div n="lb">planting arecanut and coconut palms in the gift land without
<div n="lb">the permission of the king or landlord as was necessary in the
<div n="lb">case of ordinary tenants; cf. {%sa-guvāka-nārikela.%} Cf. Majum-
<div n="lb">dar, {%Ins. Beng.,%} Vol. III, p. 125.
<LEND>

<L>6943.1<pc>395<k1>hastidaRqavarabalIvarda<k2>hastidaRqa-varabalIvarda-...
{%hastidaṇḍa-varabalīvarda-coṭāla-andhā(rthā?)ruvā-pratyandhā-%}¦
<div n="lb">{%(rthā?)ruvā-adattā-padātijīva-ahidaṇḍa-ānta(tu?)rāvaḍḍi-bandha-%}
<div n="lb">{%daṇḍa-vijayavandāpanā-mārgaṇika-prabhṛti-bhaviṣyat-kara-sahita,%} refers
<div n="lb">to the donee's right to enjoy various taxes the nature of some of
<div n="lb">which is doubtful. These include the tax for keeping elephants
<div n="lb">and prize bullocks, tax for the maintenance of the king's {%Padātis%}
<div n="lb">(footmen or {%Pāiks%}), tax on the professional snake-charmers,
<div n="lb">ransom in lieu of imprisonment, presents to be made to the
<div n="lb">king on his return from a victorious campaign and tax to be paid
<div n="lb">for using the road in the gift village for the transit of articles of
<div n="lb">merchandise. See the expressions separately as noticed above.
<div n="lb">See also {%suvarṇa-daṇḍa-ahidaṇḍa … %} below. Cf. {%Ind. Ep.,%} p. 401.
<LEND>

<L>6944<pc>395<k1>janaDanasahita<k2>jana-Dana-sahita
{%jana-dhana-sahita%}¦ ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXV, p. 135), ‘to-
<div n="lb">gether with the tenants and revenue income [of the village]’;
<div n="lb">some as {%sa-jana-dhana.%}
<LEND>

<L>6945<pc>395<k1>kuSalatApUtahastodakena<k2>kuSa-latA-pUta-hast-odakena

<div n="lb">{%Ep.,%} p. 395

<L>6946<pc>395<k1>mahAdozavivarjita<k2>mahAdoza-vivarjita
{%mahādoṣa-vivarjita%}¦ (EI 23), ‘excluding fines for great
<div n="lb">crimes’; cf. {%doṣa%} and {%daṇḍa-doṣa%} (fines) noticed above.

<L>6947<pc>395<k1>muktoparikara<k2>mukt-oparikara
{%mukt-oparikara%}¦ (EI 29), free from minor taxes or without
<div n="lb">freedom from them. Cf. {%s-oparikara.%}
<LEND>

<L>6948<pc>395<k1>nAnAvfkzasameta<k2>nAnA-vfkza-sameta
{%nānā-vṛkṣa-sameta,%}¦ ‘together with the various trees’; epithet
<div n="lb">of gift village. Some of the trees not to be enjoyed by unpri-
<div n="lb">vileged tenants were mango, {%madhūka,%} jack, coconut, arecanut,
<div n="lb">palmyra palm, sīsu, tamarind tree, etc. But the group was
<div n="lb">different in different parts of the country. Cf. {%Ind. Ep.,%} p. 402.
<LEND>
[Page-396+ 40]

<L>6949<pc>396<k1>navaniDAnasahita<k2>nava-niDAna-sahita
{%nava-nidhāna-sahita%}¦ (IA 11), probably, ‘with the taxes fixed
<div n="lb">afresh’, though {%nidhāna%} is often the same as {%nikṣepa%} (q. v.).
<LEND>

<L>6949.1<pc>396<k1>niDinikzepapAzARArAmAdicatuzprakArabIravaRapAriKAyasahita<k2>niDi-nikzepa-pAzAR-ArAm-Adi-catuzprakAra-bIravaRa-pAriK-Aya-sahita

<div n="lb"> ({%Ind. Int.,%} Vol. XIX, p. 247), mentioned along with
<div n="lb">{%aṣṭabhoga-tejassvāmy-daṇḍaśulka-yukta.%} See the expressions as sepa-
<div n="lb">rately noticed above.
<LEND>

<L>6950<pc>396<k1>niDinikzepAputrakaDanadaRqopajAtakasahita<k2>niDi-nikzep-AputrakaDana-daRq-opajAtaka-sahita
{%nidhi-nikṣep-āputrakadhana-daṇḍ-opajātaka-sahita,%}¦ ‘together
<div n="lb">with the right to enjoy treasure-trove and the occasional finds
<div n="lb">and accumulations on the land and to confiscate the property
<div n="lb">of persons dying without leaving any son, and to enjoy the right
<div n="lb">to appropriate the income derived from fines’; epithet of gift
<div n="lb">village. Cf. {%Ind. Ep.,%} 406.
<LEND>

<L>6951<pc>396<k1>niDinikzepasahita<k2>niDi-nikzepa-sahita
{%nidhi-nikṣepa-sahita,%}¦ see {%sa-vṛkṣamālā-nīdhi-nikṣepa-sahita.%}

<L>6952<pc>396<k1>niDyupaniDihastidantavyAGracarmanAnAvanacarasameta<k2>niDy-upaniDi-hastidanta-vyAGracarma-nAnAvanacara-sameta
{%nidhy-upanidhi-hastidanta-vyāghracarma-nānāvanacara-sameta,%}¦
<div n="lb">refers to the right of the donee to treasure-troves, occasional
<div n="lb">finds or accumulations on the ground, elephants’ tusks, tiger's
<div n="lb">skin and certain prized animals without surrendering them
<div n="lb">to the king as ordinary tenants had to do; epithet of the gift
<div n="lb">village. Cf. {%Ind. Ep.,%} p. 402.
<LEND>

<L>6962<pc>396<k1>pUrvaprattadevabrahmadeyarahita<k2>pUrva-pratta-deva-brahma-deya-rahita
{%pūrva-pratta-deva-brahma-deya-rahita,%}¦ sometimes with {%dāya%} in
<div n="lb">place of {%deya;%} refers to the absence of the donee's right to have
[Page-397+ 40]
<div n="lb">any control over that land in the gift village which was already
<div n="lb">a rent-free holding in the possession of gods or Brāhmaṇas;
<div n="lb">same as {%deva-brahmaṇa-bhukti-varja,%} etc. Cf. {%Ind. Ep.,%} p. 398.

<L>6963<pc>397<k1>putrapOtrAdisantatikrameRa<k2>putra-pOtrAdi-santati-krameRa

<L>6966<pc>397<k1>putrapOtrAnvayakramopaBogya<k2>putra-pOtr-Anvaya-kram-opaBogya
{%putra-pautr-ānvaya-kram-opabhogya,%}¦ refers to the permanent
<div n="lb">nature of a gift of land to be enjoyed by the donee as well as
<div n="lb">his descendants; same as {%putra-putr-ānugamaka%} ({%I.E.,%} p. 398).
<LEND>

<L>6967<pc>397<k1>rAjaBAvyasarvapratyAyasameta<k2>rAja-BAvya-sarva-pratyAya-sameta
{%rāja-bhāvya-sarva-pratyāya-sameta%}¦ (EI 23), {%bhāvya%} being
<div n="lb">often changed to {%ābhāvya;%} same as {%a-kiñcit-pragrāhya,%} etc.

{%rājasevakānāṃ vasatidaṇḍa-prayāṇadaṇḍau na staḥ,%}¦ refers to

<L>6972<pc>397<k1>ramya<k2>ramya
{%ramya%}¦ ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXV, p. 135), refers to the fact
<div n="lb">that the gift land had nothing unpleasant about it.

<L>6973<pc>397<k1>fRAdAyAdisambanDavarjita<k2>fR-AdAy-Adi-sambanDa-varjita

<div n="lb">dom of the gift land from confiscation for the realisation of debts
<div n="lb">incurred by the donee.

<L>6974<pc>397<k1>sabAhyAByantarAdAya<k2>sa-bAhy-AByantar-AdAya
{%sa-bāhy-ābhyantar-ādāya,%}¦ ‘together with the external and

<L>6975<pc>397<k1>saBoga<k2>sa-Boga
{%sa-bhoga%}¦ (EI 27; IA 9), ‘together with the {%aṣṭa-bhoga%}’.
<LEND>

<L>6976<pc>397<k1>saBUtapAtapratyAya<k2>sa-BUta-pAta-pratyAya
{%sa-bhūta-pāta-pratyāya%}¦ (CII 3), refers to the income from
<div n="lb">the gift land as a result of some action of nature's agencies.
<div n="lb">Sometimes {%vāta%} and {%āvāta%} are found for {%pāta%} probably in the
[Page-398+ 40]
<div n="lb">sense of ‘a storm’ (cf. {%udvāta%}) and also {%upātta,%} ‘realised’.
<LEND>

<L>6977<pc>398<k1>saBUtavAtapratyAya<k2>sa-BUta-vAta-pratyAya
{%sa-bhūta-vāta-pratyāya%}¦ (EI 23), with {%pāta%} sometimes in
<div n="lb">place of {%vāta;%} ‘together with the income arising out of a change
<div n="lb">of the natural phenomena (such as due to earthquakes, storms,
<div n="lb">etc.)’; epithet of gift land.
<LEND>

<L>6978<pc>398<k1>saBUtopAttapratyAya<k2>sa-BUt-opAtta-pratyAya
{%sa-bhūt-opātta-pratyāya%}¦ (EI 23), same as {%sa-bhūta-vāta-pra-%}
<div n="lb">{%tyāya,%} etc. The word {%upātta%} means ‘realised’.
<LEND>

<L>6979<pc>398<k1>sacOrodDaraRa<k2>sa-cOr-odDaraRa
{%sa-caur-oddharaṇa%}¦ (EI 12, 23, 29), ‘together with the right
<div n="lb">to punish thieves and recover stolen property or fines’; epithet
<div n="lb">of gift villages. Cf. {%caura-varja,%} etc.
<LEND>

<L>6980<pc>398<k1>sadaRqadoza<k2>sa-daRqa-doza
{%sa-daṇḍa-doṣa%}¦ (EI 23), ‘together with [the right to] levy fines
<div n="lb">for crimes’; the meaning of {%doṣa%} is really doubtful in the context.
<LEND>

<L>6981<pc>398<k1>sadaRqanigraha<k2>sa-daRqa-nigraha
{%sa-daṇḍa-nigraha%}¦ (EI 24), refers to the king's power to
<div n="lb">punish [culprits] by fines or corporal punishment.
<LEND>

<L>6982<pc>398<k1>sadaSApacAra<k2>sa-daS-ApacAra
{%sa-daś-āpacāra,%}¦ same as {%sa-daś-āparādha;%} cf. {%Ind. Ep.,%}
<div n="lb">p. 397.
<LEND>

<L>6983<pc>398<k1>sadaSAparADa<k2>sa-daS-AparADa
{%sa-daś-āparādha%}¦ (EI 27), also quoted as {%sa-daś-āpacāra;%}
<div n="lb">‘together with the right to punish and realise fines for the ten
<div n="lb">offences (murder, theft, etc.)’; epithet of gift village; cf.
<div n="lb">{%sahya-daś-āparādha%} probably meaning that the crimes committed
<div n="lb">in the gift village should not be punished by the king.
<LEND>

<L>6984<pc>398<k1>sadeyameya<k2>sa-deya-meya
{%sa-deya-meya%}¦ (EI 7), same as {%sa-dhānya-hiraṇy-ādeya,%} etc.

<L>6985<pc>398<k1>saDAnyahiraRyAdeya<k2>sa-DAnya-hiraRy-Adeya
{%sa-dhānya-hiraṇy-ādeya%}¦ (EI 11, 12, 23; IA 9), ‘together
<div n="lb">with the king's grain share and taxes in cash’.

<L>6986<pc>398<k1>sADaUrDva<k2>s-ADa-UrDva
{%s-ādha-ūrdhva,%}¦ ‘together with what is [produced or found]

<L>6987<pc>398<k1>sAgamaniramapraveSa<k2>s-Agama-nirama-praveSa

<L>6988<pc>398<k1>sagartAvaskara<k2>sa-gart-Avaskara
{%sa-gart-āvaskara%}¦ ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXV, p. 135), mentioned
<div n="lb">along with {%s-oṣara.%} The word {%avaskara%} (also {%avakara%}) probably
<div n="lb">means ‘a mound’.
<LEND>

<L>7125<pc>406<k1>supallikApeta<k2>su-pallik-Apeta

<L>7125.1<pc>406<k1>suvarRadaRqaahidaRqa<k2>suvarRadaRqa-ahidaRqa-...
{%suvarṇadaṇḍa-ahidaṇḍa%}¦{%-vartmadaṇḍa-vandāpanā-vijayandāpanā-%}
<div n="lb">{%tṛṇodaka-śāsanārdhika-cara(vara ?)balīvarad-ārthāruvā-pratyarthāruvā-%}
<div n="lb">{%padātijīvya-ādattā-āturāvaḍḍi-bhaviṣyat-kar-ādi-sahita,%} refers to the
<div n="lb">right of the donee to levy various taxes, the nature of some of
<div n="lb">which is uncertain (see the different expressions as noticed above).
<div n="lb">These include tax on the goldsmiths and snake-charmers, tolls to
<div n="lb">be collected for using the road passing through the gift village for
<div n="lb">the transit of articles of merchandise, presents to be made to
<div n="lb">the king or landlord on occasions, especially on his return from
<div n="lb">a victorious campaign, etc. See {%hastidaṇḍa-varabalīvarda … %}
<div n="lb">above. Cf. {%Ind. Ep.,%} p. 402.
<LEND>

<L>7126<pc>406<k1>svacCandopaBogen<k2>svacCand-opaBogen = opaBoktum
{%svacchand-opabhogen = opabhoktum,%}¦ refers to the right of the
[Page-407+ 40]
<div n="lb">donee to enjoy the gift land according to his own free will.
<div n="lb">Cf. {%Ind. Ep.,%} p. 399.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">thet of gift land.

<L>7146.1<pc>408<k1>yaTAdIyamAna<k2>yaTAdIyamAna-...
{%yathādīyamāna%}¦-{%bhāgabhogakara-paravaṇikara-kūṭaka-prabhṛti-sa-%}
<div n="lb">{%mast-ādāya,%} sometimes with {%turuṣka-daṇḍa%} and {%kumāra-gady-%}
<div n="lb">{%āṇaka%} in place of {%kūṭaka,%} and {%hiraṇya, jalakara, gokara, nidhi-%}
<div n="lb">{%nikṣepa, yamali-kambali,%} etc., added to the list. {%Bhāga-bhoga-%}
<div n="lb">{%kara%} means ‘taxes in general together with the king's share
<div n="lb">of grains and the periodical offerings payable to him.’ For {%pravaṇi-%}
<div n="lb">{%kara, kūṭaka%} and {%yamalikambali,%} see the words as noticed above.
<div n="lb">{%Turuṣkadaṇḍa%} was a tax levied from the Muhammadan sub-
<div n="lb">jects or for the defence of the kingdom from Muhammadan
<div n="lb">attacks and {%Kumāra-gadyāṇa%} may be a tax of one {%gaḍyāṇa%} levied
<div n="lb">on the occasion of a prince's birth. {%Hiraṇya%} is ‘tax in cash’,
<div n="lb">{%jala-kara%} fishing tax, {%go-kara%} grazing tax, {%nidhi%} treasure-trove
<div n="lb">and {%nikṣepa%} valuables found or accumulated on the land. Cf.
<div n="lb">{%Ind. Ep.,%} p. 397.
<LEND>

<L>7147<pc>408<k1>yaTApradIyamAnaBAgaBogahiraRyAdika<k2>yaTA-pradIyamAna-BAga-Boga-hiraRy-Adika
{%yathā-pradīyamāna-bhāga-bhoga-hiraṇy-ādika%}¦ (EI 23), ‘what-
<div n="lb">ever is payable as {%bhāga-bhoga, hiraṇya,%} etc.’ See the words
<div n="lb">as noticed separately; also {%yathā-samucita-bhāga-bhoga-kara-%}
<div n="lb">{%hiraṇy-ādi-sarva-rāja-bhāvya-pratyāya%} ({%Ind. Ep.,%} p. 394).
<LEND>

<L>7148<pc>408<k1>yaTotpadyamAnaBAgaBogAdika<k2>yaT-otpadyamAna-BAga-Bog-Adika
{%yath-otpadyamāna-bhāga-bhog-ādika%}¦ (EI 23), ‘with the power
<div n="lb">to realise {%bhāga, bhoga,%} etc., whenever they become due.’ See
<div n="lb">the words as noticed separately above.

; ADDITIONS AND CORRECTIONS

[Page556+ 35]
<H>Addenda et Corrigenda
<HI>N. B.--Misprints that may be more or less easily corrected
<>by the readers include (1) a few cases of {%ṛ%} written as {%ṛi%} (e. g.,
<>p. 388--{%bhṛta,%} p. 393--{%tṛṇa%}) and {%cha%} written for {%ca%} (p. 324,
<>line 3); (2) wrong use of capital and small letters at the
<>beginning of entries meant for indicating persons and objects
<>respectively; (3) entries put away from their proper places
<>(e. g., p. 10--{%agahara,%} p. 49--{%bhamāti%} and {%Bhāṇaka,%} p. 211--{%naṅga%}
<>and {%Nāṇī,%} p. 257--{%prāstarika-śreṇī,%} p. 412--{%aradu dogarāca-ppaṇṇu,%}
<>p. 433--{%jīrṇa-viśvamalla-priya%}), and (4) occasional omission of
<>diacritical marks in {%ā, ĕ, ŏ, ḍ, ṇ, ś, ṭ,%} etc.
<HI>Page 5, line 26--{%Read%}--mortgaged
<HI>Page 9--Add--{%ādya-stamba,%} ‘covered with original
<>shrubs’, i.e. yielding no revenue income,
<>never cultivated.
<HI>Page 11, line 17--Read--{%āgrahāyanī%}
<HI>Page 16--Add--{%ā-mā,%} abbreviation of {%ādya-māṣa%} (i. e.
<>the original {%māṣa%} of 5 {%ratis%}).
<HI>Page 26, line 27--Read--{%Ārakṣ-ādhikṛta.%}
<HI>Page 28, line 12--Read--{%Arhad-āyatana.%}
<HI>Page 35, line 14--{%Add%}--Cf. {%Bṛhad-aśvavāra.%}
<HI>Page, 35, line 23--{%Add%}--RE XIII of Aśoka seems to speak of
<>the {%Aṭavī%} or foresters as habitually criminal.
<HI>Page 35, lines 29ff.--Read--{%aṭha-gānī,%} a billon coin equal to
<>8 copper {%jitals%} and to (1/6) of a silver {%ṭaṅka.%}
<HI>Page 40, line 26--{%Add%}--Cf. also {%nivāta.%}
<HI>Page 44, line 13--{%Add%}--See {%vāhyāli.%}
<HI>Page 45-- Add--{%Balisādhaka,%} tax-collector (Ghoshal,
<>{%Ag. Syst.,%} p. 25).
<HI>Page 47, line 35--{%Add%}--Cf. {%pāga.%}
<HI>Page 48, line 13--{%Add%}--In {%bhoga-bhāga-dhānya-hiraṇya%} of the
<>Kurud plates ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXI, p.
<>264), we have probably to understand
<>{%dhānya-hiraṇya%} realised as {%bhoga-bhāga.%}
<HI>Page 48, line 36--{%Add%}--See {%pagoda.%}
[Page557+ 39]
<HI>Page 61 line 34--{%Ada%}--tenure of (1/20) of the revenue of an
<>area granted to the Brāhmaṇas.
<HI>Page 62--Add--{%Bṛhad-aśvavāra,%} a cavalry officer
<>(Tripathi, {%History of Kanauj,%} p. 137).
<HI>Page 64, line 35--{%Read%}--(1/20) of a rupee.
<HI>Page 71, line 8--Read--{%Cau.%}
<HI>Page 77--Add--{%daivaka;%} see {%rājaka-daivaka.%}
<HI>Page 80, line 4--{%Add%}--May also be {%Dāṇḍa (Dāṇḍanāyaka)%}
<>and {%Bhogika.%}
<HI>Page 88--. Add--{%deva-hala,%} same as {%deva-bhoga-hala;%} cf.
<>{%hala-nyāya, bhikṣu-hala.%} See {%Suc. Sat.,%} pp.
<>84, etc.
<HI>Page 91, line 7--Add--{%Bhoga-bhāga-dhānya-hiraṇya%} of the
<>Kurud plates ({%Ep. Ind.,%} Vol. XXXI, p.
<>264) probably means {%dhānya-hiraṇya%} realised
<>as {%bhoga-bhāga.%}
<HI>Page 91 line 38--Read--{%dhārā-datta.%}
<HI>Page 97--Add--{%Digvijayin,%} ‘the conqueror of the
<>quarters’; title of some rulers conventionally
<>claiming to have conquered the {%cakravarti-%}
<>{%kṣetra%} (q. v.).
<HI>Page 97 line 13--{%Add%}--It normally means ‘the conquest of
<>the quarters’, conventional claim of a
<>type of Indian rulers.
<HI>Page 101, line 2--Read--collection of revenue (cf. {%Rājatar.,%}
<>VII. 2010)
<HI>Page 101 line 12--{%Read%}--watch-station for the collection of
<>tolls
<HI>Page 101 line 15--Read--{%Audraṅgika.%}
<HI>Page 101 line--Add-{%dukra,%} (1/5) of a {%phadiyā.%}
<HI>Page 111, line 12--{%Read%}--EI 9.
<HI>Page 111, line 34-35--Read--{%gānī,%} cf. {%aṭha-gānī,%} a billon coin
<>equal to 8 copper {%jitals%} and to (1/6) of a
<>silver {%ṭaṅka.%}
<HI>Page 115, line 22--Read--{%ghaṭikā-sthāna.%}
<HI>Page 119, line 29--Read--{%go-yuthī.%}
<HI>Page 125--Add--{%hala-nyāya,%} custom followed in grant-
<>ing rent-free holdings; same as {%brahmadeya-%}
<>{%maryādā,%} etc.
[Page558+ 40]
<>Page 129, last line--{%Add%}--Also cf. {%suvarṇ-ādāya, svarṇ-āya.%}
<HI>Page 131, line 16--Read--{%indr-āsana.%}
<HI>Page 131 line 28--{%Add%}--Cf. {%Mahābhārata,%} XII, 103. 2: {%atr=āpy=%}
<>{%udāharant=īmam=itihāsaṃ purātanam |%}
<>{%Bṛhaspateś = ca saṃvādam=Indrasya ca Yudhiṣ-%}
<>{%ṭhira ||%}
<HI>Page 138, line 17--Add--{%Kaivarta-bhoga%} and {%Kaivarta-vṛtti%}
<>really mean the land enjoyed by the fisher-
<>men for their service, e. g., ferrying, supply
<>of fish and boats, etc.
<HI>Page 144, line 30--{%Add%}--Note that {%boḍi%} or {%voḍi%} is also the same
<>as Bengali {%buḏi%} which is (1/4) of a {%paṇa%} and is
<>equal to 20 cowrie-shells.
<HI>Page 150, line 31--{%Add%}--probably derived from Sanskrit {%karṣa.%}
<HI>Page 150 line 36--Read--{%nat-kāśu.%}
<HI>Page 151, line 38--{%Add%}--explained as ‘a commander of the
<>elephant force’ (Tripathi, {%History of Kanauj,%}
<>p. 137).
<HI>Page 158, line Add--{%kedāra,%} coin of the Kidāra-Kuṣāṇas
<>(Bhandarkar, {%Carm. Lect.,%} 1921, p. 205).
<HI>Page 158, line 12--Read--{%kliṇva-kreṇi%} (for {%klinna-kreṇi%})
<HI>Page 164, line 34--{%Add%}--Same as {%Senabova%} (q. v.).
<HI>Page 165, line 6--Read--{%Kulavārika.%}
<HI>Page 166, line 39--{%Read%}--occurs, {%for%}--occury.
<HI>Page 170--Add--{%laṅkā,%} islet in a river ({%Kākatīya-%}
<>{%saṃcika,%} No. 31).
<HI>Page 182, line 18--Read--{%Pañcāyat%} board.
<HI>Page 190, line 19--{%Read%}--IE 8-2
<HI>Page 197, line 6--Read--{%maṅgalikā.%}
<HI>Page 200, line 5--Read--{%marīci.%}
<HI>Page 216--Add--{%Nigrāhaka,%} tax-collector (Ghoshal,
<>{%Ag. Syst.,%} p. 25). cf. {%Koṭṭa-nigraha.%}
<HI>Page 220--Add--{%nivāta;%} see {%s-oṣar-āvaskara-sthāna-nivāta-%}
<>{%lavaṇ-ākara%} (EI 22); same as {%āvāta.%}
<HI>Page 228, line 3--{%Add%}--The expression {%pāli-ddhaya%} in Apa-
<>bhraṃśa is explained as ‘small flags’
<>({%Bhār. Vid.,%} Vol. XXV, p. 34).
<HI>Page 230, line 23--{%Add%}--Bengali {%pāñcālī%} is a kind of versified
<>composition so called probably because it
<>was originally sung either before the
[Page559+ 40]
<>members of the Pañcāyat board or at
<>puppet shows.
<HI>Page 232 Add--{%pañcāṅgula,%} impression the plam with
<>outstretched fingers dipped in sandal paste
<>or any such thing; also called {%Pañcāṅgulika.%}
<HI>Page 242, line 19--Read--religious teachers.

<>Keralas; {%Guhila-putra,%} descendant of Guhila.
